<p>I'd use apprach #3 too. I'm using a similar approach in my projects, and it is used by COM too (interfaces inherithed by private implementation class).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It is really easy to detect errors and maintain code in that way! Unfortunately you will end  implementing all functions as virtual, but it should not be a big issue...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Separating the interface will keep it really clean and understandable!</p>&#xA;

 i'd use apprach #3 too. i'm using a similar approach in my projects, and it is used by com too (interfaces inherithed by private implementation class). . ;. ; it is really easy to detect errors and maintain code in that way! unfortunately you will end  implementing all functions as virtual, but it should not be a big issue... . ;. ; separating the interface will keep it really clean and understandable! . ;

i d use apprach #3 too
i m using a similar approach in my projects and it is used by com too interfaces inherithed by private implementation class
it is really easy to detect errors and maintain code in that way
unfortunately you will end implementing all functions as virtual but it should not be a big issue.
separating the interface will keep it really clean and understandable

<p>If you really want to do this in one line, I'd write a function to make a <code>B</code>, call <code>func</code> on it and return it. Hopefully in your real code you'll be able to come up with a good name for it, which is arguably the most important consideration for things like this </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>template &lt;typename T&gt;&#xA;std::unique_ptr&lt;T&gt; make_and_func () {&#xA;    auto ptr = std::make_unique&lt;T&gt;();&#xA;    func(ptr.get());&#xA;    return ptr;&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;int main()&#xA;{&#xA;    std::unique_ptr&lt;BIf&gt; ptr = nullptr;&#xA;    //...&#xA;    ptr = make_and_func&lt;B&gt;();&#xA;    //...&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you <em>really</em> want to use a lambda, you could do this (untested):</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>int main()&#xA;{&#xA;    std::unique_ptr&lt;BIf&gt; ptr = nullptr;&#xA;    auto make_and_func = [&amp;ptr]() {&#xA;        auto p = std::make_unique&lt;B&gt;();&#xA;        func(p);&#xA;        ptr = std::move(p);&#xA;    };&#xA;    //...&#xA;    make_and_func();&#xA;    //...&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I think this is a pretty bad idea though. The local variable mutation is hidden behind the lambda, which probably lead to bugs and maintenance issues. I'd recommend using the first option.</p>&#xA;

 if you really want to do this in one line, i'd write a function to make a  b , call  func  on it and return it. hopefully in your real code you'll be able to come up with a good name for it, which is arguably the most important consideration for things like this  . ;. ;  . ;. ; if you  really  want to use a lambda, you could do this (untested): . ;. ;  . ;. ; i think this is a pretty bad idea though. the local variable mutation is hidden behind the lambda, which probably lead to bugs and maintenance issues. i'd recommend using the first option. . ;

if you really want to do this in one line i d write a function to make a b call func on it and return it
hopefully in your real code you ll be able to come up with a good name for it which is arguably the most important consideration for things like this
if you really want to use a lambda you could do this untested
i think this is a pretty bad idea though
the local variable mutation is hidden behind the lambda which probably lead to bugs and maintenance issues
i d recommend using the first option



<p>You are using one more item and probably accessing outside the bounds of array</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>while (table[i++] != NULL);  &#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>should be</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>while (table[i] != NULL) i++;  &#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There is a <a href="http://c-faq.com/lib/qsort1.html" rel="nofollow">reference</a> in the C-FAQ about using <code>qsort</code> and <code>strcmp</code>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Q</strong>: I'm trying to sort an array of strings with qsort, using strcmp as the comparison function, but it's not working.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>A</strong>: By array of strings you probably mean array of pointers to char. The arguments to qsort's comparison function are pointers to the objects being sorted, in this case, pointers to pointers to char. strcmp, however, accepts simple pointers to char. Therefore, strcmp can't be used directly. Write an intermediate comparison function like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>/* compare strings via pointers */&#xA;int pstrcmp(const void *p1, const void *p2)&#xA;{&#xA;    return strcmp(*(char * const *)p1, *(char * const *)p2);&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The comparison function's arguments are expressed as generic pointers, const void *. They are converted back to what they really are (pointers to pointers to char) and dereferenced, yielding char *'s which can be passed to strcmp.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The call to qsort might look like</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;&#xA;char *strings[NSTRINGS];&#xA;int nstrings;&#xA;/* nstrings cells of strings[] are to be sorted */&#xA;qsort(strings, nstrings, sizeof(char *), pstrcmp);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(Don't be misled by the discussion in K&amp;R2 Sec. 5.11 pp. 119-20, which is not discussing the Standard library's qsort, and makes a quiet, unnecessary assumption about the equivalence of char * and void *).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>For more information on qsort comparison functions--how they are called and how they must be declared--see question 13.9.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>References: ISO Sec. 7.10.5.2&#xA;H&amp;S Sec. 20.5 p. 419 </p>&#xA;

 you are using one more item and probably accessing outside the bounds of array . ;. ;  . ;. ; should be . ;. ;  . ;. ; there is a  reference  in the c-faq about using  qsort  and  strcmp : . ;. ;  q : i'm trying to sort an array of strings with qsort, using strcmp as the comparison function, but it's not working. . ;. ;  a : by array of strings you probably mean array of pointers to char. the arguments to qsort's comparison function are pointers to the objects being sorted, in this case, pointers to pointers to char. strcmp, however, accepts simple pointers to char. therefore, strcmp can't be used directly. write an intermediate comparison function like this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; the comparison function's arguments are expressed as generic pointers, const void  . they are converted back to what they really are (pointers to pointers to char) and dereferenced, yielding char  's which can be passed to strcmp. . ;. ; the call to qsort might look like . ;. ;  . ;. ; (don't be misled by the discussion in k r2 sec. 5.11 pp. 119-20, which is not discussing the standard library's qsort, and makes a quiet, unnecessary assumption about the equivalence of char   and void  ). . ;. ; for more information on qsort comparison functions--how they are called and how they must be declared--see question 13.9. . ;. ; references: iso sec. 7.10.5.2. ;h s sec. 20.5 p. 419  . ;

<p>On Linux, I can do:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$ FOO=BAR ./myscript&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>to call "myscript" with the environment variable FOO being set.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is something similar possible in Powershell, i.e. without having to first set the variable, call the command, and then unset the variable again?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>To be more clear about my use case - I don't want to use this as part of a script. So being able to alternate between typing</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$ OPTION=1 ./myscript&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>and </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$ ./myscript&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>would just be very handy.</p>&#xA;

<p>The simplest way to do what you want is ensuring that both terms are tables in the first place.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>local a = "a string"&#xA;local b = {"a table", "containing", "a string"}&#xA;&#xA;...&#xA;&#xA;-- Make sure that a is a table&#xA;if type(a) ~= 'table' then a = {a} end&#xA;&#xA;if a == b then -- now you can use metatables here&#xA;...&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>However, I must warn you against doing this. If, as you said, you want to 'check that a is inside b', I would not use the equality operator for that. Instead, I would use something more explicit, like:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>if tableContains(b,a) then -- this is less confusing; equality doesn't mean composition&#xA;...&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 the simplest way to do what you want is ensuring that both terms are tables in the first place. . ;. ;  . ;. ; however, i must warn you against doing this. if, as you said, you want to 'check that a is inside b', i would not use the equality operator for that. instead, i would use something more explicit, like: . ;. ;  . ;

the simplest way to do what you want is ensuring that both terms are tables in the first place
however i must warn you against doing this
if as you said you want to check that a is inside b i would not use the equality operator for that
instead i would use something more explicit like

<p>I suggest you use the <a href="http://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/string_split.htm" rel="nofollow">split()</a> method.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>split() allows you to specify the separator of your choice. Provided the sequence title (here 1EK9) is always separated from the rest of the sequence by a colon, you could first pass ":" as your separator. You could then split the remainder of the sequence to recover the numbered positions (e.g. A.41,52) using ";" as a separator.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I hope this helps!</p>&#xA;

 i suggest you use the  split()  method. . ;. ; split() allows you to specify the separator of your choice. provided the sequence title (here 1ek9) is always separated from the rest of the sequence by a colon, you could first pass ":" as your separator. you could then split the remainder of the sequence to recover the numbered positions (  a.41,52) using ";" as a separator. . ;. ; i hope this helps! . ;

i suggest you use the split method
split allows you to specify the separator of your choice
provided the sequence title here 1ek9 is always separated from the rest of the sequence by a colon you could first pass as your separator
you could then split the remainder of the sequence to recover the numbered positions a.41 52 using
as a separator
i hope this helps

<p>The <code>secret_key_base</code> is used to securely sign the cookies that Rails creates. It needs to be set to some suitably long, arbitrary String that's different for each Rails deployment and kept secret.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>What I usually do to generate a new one is run something like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>ruby -rsecurerandom -e 'p SecureRandom.hex(32)'&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>... and then copy and paste that into my <code>secrets.yml</code>, in the section matching the <code>RAILS_ENV</code>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>production:&#xA;  secret_key_base: '553e8330b465c2c51789a8f957932e7c8d9144a5e1b93431d2db7b6bd9b681f6'&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>You can use <code>getSelection()</code> method of the kendoEditor. <p>I want to write some code to do acoustic analysis and I'm trying to determine the proper tool(s) for the job. I would normally write something like this in Python using numpy and scipy and possibly Cython for the analysis part. I've discovered that the world of Python audio libraries is a bit chaotic, with scads of very limited packages in various states of development.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I've also come across a bunch of audio/acoustic specific languages like SuperCollider, Faust, etc. that seem to make the audio processing easy but may be limited in terms of IO and analysis capability.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I'm currently working on Linux with Alsa and PulseAudio installed by default. I would prefer not to involve and of the various and sundry other audio packages like Jack if possible, though that is not a hard requirement.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My primary interest in this question is to determine whether there is a domain specific language that will provide for quicker prototyping and testing or whether a general language like Python is more appropriate. Thanks.</p>&#xA;

 i want to write some code to do acoustic analysis and i'm trying to determine the proper tool(s) for the job. i would normally write something like this in python using numpy and scipy and possibly cython for the analysis part. i've discovered that the world of python audio libraries is a bit chaotic, with scads of very limited packages in various states of development. . ;. ; i've also come across a bunch of audio/acoustic specific languages like supercollider, faust, etc. that seem to make the audio processing easy but may be limited in terms of io and analysis capability. . ;. ; i'm currently working on linux with alsa and pulseaudio installed by default. i would prefer not to involve and of the various and sundry other audio packages like jack if possible, though that is not a hard requirement. . ;. ; my primary interest in this question is to determine whether there is a domain specific language that will provide for quicker prototyping and testing or whether a general language like python is more appropriate. thanks. . ;

i want to write some code to do acoustic analysis and i m trying to determine the proper tool s for the job
i would normally write something like this in python using numpy and scipy and possibly cython for the analysis part
i ve discovered that the world of python audio libraries is a bit chaotic with scads of very limited packages in various states of development
i ve also come across a bunch of audio acoustic specific languages like supercollider faust etc
that seem to make the audio processing easy but may be limited in terms of io and analysis capability
i m currently working on linux with alsa and pulseaudio installed by default

my primary interest in this question is to determine whether there is a domain specific language that will provide for quicker prototyping and testing or whether a general language like python is more appropriate
thanks



<p>Finally I need to read the response and parse it into claims manually, here's how I did it just for reference:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>//Response from Azure ACS is stored in wresult parameter&#xA;string samlResponse = Request.Params["wresult"];&#xA;&#xA;var xmlTextReader = new XmlTextReader(new StringReader(samlResponse));&#xA;&#xA;//Only interested in Assertion section of the response&#xA;xmlTextReader.ReadToFollowing("Assertion", "urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:assertion");&#xA;&#xA;SecurityTokenHandlerCollection handlers = FederatedAuthentication.ServiceConfiguration.SecurityTokenHandlers;&#xA;&#xA;// read the token&#xA;var securityToken = handlers.ReadToken(xmlTextReader);&#xA;&#xA;// validate the token and create the identity collection&#xA;var claimsIdentityCollection = handlers.ValidateToken(securityToken);&#xA;&#xA;// create ClaimsPrincipal&#xA;var claimsPrincipal = new ClaimsPrincipal(claimsIdentityCollection); &#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Although it works, I'm not sure whether this is the best way, so I still leave the question open for anyone who has better answer</p>&#xA;

<pre><code>a = new Boolean()&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>The [[PrimitiveValue]] internal property of the newly constructed Boolean object is set to ToBoolean(value). <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-15.6.2.1" rel="nofollow">See here</a></p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This means a is a <code>Boolean</code> object with the primitive value of <code>false</code> (<code>ToBoolean(undefined)</code>).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>a == false // true&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>If Type(x) is Boolean, return the result of the comparison ToNumber(x) == y. <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-11.9.3" rel="nofollow">See here</a></p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p><code>ToNumber(a)</code> will be <code>0</code> because the primitive value of <code>a</code> is <code>false</code>. <code>0==false</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Boolean(a) // true&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>When Boolean is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it performs a type conversion. <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-15.6.1" rel="nofollow">See here</a></p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Since <code>a</code> is an object, <code>Boolean(a)</code> will be <code>true</code>. All objects are converted to <code>true</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>if (a) doStuff()&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The same thing as above, a is an object, so it is coerced to true in an if statement.</p>&#xA;

  . ;. ; . ;   the [[primitivevalue]] internal property of the newly constructed boolean object is set to toboolean(value).  see here  . ; . ;. ; this means a is a  boolean  object with the primitive value of  false  ( toboolean(undefined) ). . ;. ; . ;. ;  . ;. ; . ;   if type(x) is boolean, return the result of the comparison tonumber(x) == y.  see here  . ; . ;. ;  tonumber(a)  will be  0  because the primitive value of  a  is  false .  . ;. ; . ;. ;  . ;. ; . ;   when boolean is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it performs a type conversion.  see here  . ; . ;. ; since  a  is an object,  boolean(a)  will be  true . all objects are converted to  true . . ;. ; . ;. ;  . ;. ; the same thing as above, a is an object, so it is coerced to true in an if statement. . ;

this means a is a boolean object with the primitive value of false toboolean undefined
if type x is boolean return the result of the comparison tonumber x y
see here
tonumber a will be 0 because the primitive value of a is false
when boolean is called as a function rather than as a constructor it performs a type conversion
see here
since a is an object boolean a will be true
all objects are converted to true
the same thing as above a is an object so it is coerced to true in an if statement

<p>Calculate <code>pow(4, p) - 1</code> modulo <code>3*q</code>, and divide the result by 3. To do the exponentiation, use a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_exponentiation" rel="nofollow">Modular exponentiation</a> algorithm.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Edit: This will give you integer division (i.e. rounding down the result). See @lisyarus's answer for division in the ring of integers modulo <code>q</code>. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If <code>q</code> is not divisible by 3 then both answers should give the same result, because <code>pow(4, p) - 1</code> is always divisible by 3 so the rounding-down of integer division won't come into play. If <code>q</code> is divisible by 3 then there is no multiplicative inverse and only this method can be used.</p>&#xA;

 calculate  pow(4, p) - 1  modulo , and divide the result by 3. to do the exponentiation, use a  modular exponentiation  algorithm. . ;. ; edit: this will give you integer division (  rounding down the result). see @lisyarus's answer for division in the ring of integers modulo  q .  . ;. ; if  q  is not divisible by 3 then both answers should give the same result, because  pow(4, p) - 1  is always divisible by 3 so the rounding-down of integer division won't come into play. if  q  is divisible by 3 then there is no multiplicative inverse and only this method can be used. . ;

calculate pow 4 p - 1 modulo and divide the result by 3
to do the exponentiation use a modular exponentiation algorithm
edit this will give you integer division rounding down the result
see lisyarus s answer for division in the ring of integers modulo q
if q is not divisible by 3 then both answers should give the same result because pow 4 p - 1 is always divisible by 3 so the rounding-down of integer division won t come into play
if q is divisible by 3 then there is no multiplicative inverse and only this method can be used



<p>I have a quick question about normilization (3NF). If I have a table that is defined as...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Customer(<strong>username</strong>, firstName, lastName, age, gender, race)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And <strong>username</strong> determines firstName, lastName, age, gender, race</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But.. for the sake of argument we can also assume that firstName, lastName can be used to uniquely identify a row in the table, so firstName, lastName determines <strong>username</strong>, age, gender, race</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is the table in 3NF because some non-prime attributes (firstName, lastName) can be used to determine other attributes in the table, but the PK (<strong>username</strong>) can determine the non-prime attributes that are then used to determine other attributes. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I understand that this is not in BCNF because of that circular dependency issue, but I'm hoping it's at least in 3NF.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Thanks in advance for any help. </p>&#xA;

 i have a quick question about normilization (3nf). if i have a table that is defined as... . ;. ; customer( username , firstname, lastname, age, gender, race) . ;. ; and  username  determines firstname, lastname, age, gender, race . ;. ; but.. for the sake of argument we can also assume that firstname, lastname can be used to uniquely identify a row in the table, so firstname, lastname determines  username , age, gender, race . ;. ; is the table in 3nf because some non-prime attributes (firstname, lastname) can be used to determine other attributes in the table, but the pk ( username ) can determine the non-prime attributes that are then used to determine other attributes.  . ;. ; i understand that this is not in bcnf because of that circular dependency issue, but i'm hoping it's at least in 3nf. . ;. ; thanks in advance for any help.  . ;

<p>The way I'm reading your question, you're doing a <code>union</code>, and you want to see which value is in table A, and which is in table B. If that's the case, then creating your category is very easy, as you just specify the value you want for the table you're in. Like so:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>select&#xA;    name,&#xA;    period,&#xA;    value,&#xA;    '1' as category&#xA;from&#xA;    A&#xA;union all&#xA;select&#xA;    name,&#xA;    period,&#xA;    value,&#xA;    '2' as category&#xA;from&#xA;    B&#xA;order by&#xA;    name, period, category&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 the way i'm reading your question, you're doing a  union , and you want to see which value is in table a, and which is in table b. if that's the case, then creating your category is very easy, as you just specify the value you want for the table you're in. like so: . ;. ;  . ;

the way i m reading your question you re doing a union and you want to see which value is in table a and which is in table b
if that s the case then creating your category is very easy as you just specify the value you want for the table you re in
like so



<p>The problem here is that <code>NSTimer</code> copies the block assigned to <code>userInfo</code>, but the block passed to <code>myMethodWithBlock:</code> is probably an instance of <code>NSStackBlock</code>, which is <em>not equal to its copies</em>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Let's consider three scenarios, where <code>myObject</code> is an instance of <code>MyObject</code>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>// A&#xA;void(^myBlock)(void) = ^{&#xA;    NSLog(@"1");&#xA;};&#xA;[myObject myMethodWithBlock:myBlock];&#xA;&#xA;// B&#xA;int one = 1;&#xA;void(^myBlock)(void) = ^{&#xA;    NSLog(@"%d", one);&#xA;};&#xA;[myObject myMethodWithBlock:myBlock];&#xA;&#xA;// C&#xA;int one = 1;&#xA;[myObject myMethodWithBlock:^{&#xA;    NSLog(@"%d", one);&#xA;};];&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>In <strong>A</strong>, the block captures no variables from its context; the block will be an instance of <code>NSGlobalBlock</code>, which simply returns itself when copied.</li>&#xA;<li>In <strong>B</strong>, the block captures the variable <code>one</code>; it will be an instance of <code>NSMallocBlock</code>, which also returns itself when copied.</li>&#xA;<li>In <strong>C</strong>, the block again captures the variable <code>one</code>, but is also <em>not assigned to a variable</em> before being passed to <code>myMethodWithBlock:</code>. In this case, the block is an instance of <code>NSStackBlock</code>, which returns an instance of <code>NSMallocBlock</code> when copied.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The result of this is that in a situation like scenario C, the <code>NSStackBlock</code> will be added to <code>allBlocks</code>, while an <code>NSMallocBlock</code> will be assigned to the timer's <code>userInfo</code>. When the timer fires, <code>removeObject:</code> does nothing since the block assigned to the timer isn't equal to any of the blocks in the array.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The solution is to always copy the block before storing it in the array. This way, the same block instance will be stored in the array and assigned to the timer:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>- (void)myMethodWithBlock:(void(^)(void))block&#xA;{&#xA;    block = [block copy];&#xA;    [NSTimer scheduledTimerWithTimeInterval:5.0f&#xA;                                     target:self&#xA;                                   selector:@selector(timerFired:)&#xA;                                   userInfo:block&#xA;                                    repeats:NO];&#xA;    [self.allBlocks addObject:block];&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 the problem here is that  nstimer  copies the block assigned to  userinfo , but the block passed to  mymethodwithblock:  is probably an instance of  nsstackblock , which is  not equal to its copies . . ;. ; let's consider three scenarios, where  myobject  is an instance of  myobject : . ;. ;  . ;. ; . ; in  a , the block captures no variables from its context; the block will be an instance of  nsglobalblock , which simply returns itself when copied. . ; in  b , the block captures the variable  one ; it will be an instance of  nsmallocblock , which also returns itself when copied. . ; in  c , the block again captures the variable  one , but is also  not assigned to a variable  before being passed to  mymethodwithblock: . in this case, the block is an instance of  nsstackblock , which returns an instance of  nsmallocblock  when copied. . ; . ;. ; the result of this is that in a situation like scenario c, the  nsstackblock  will be added to  allblocks , while an  nsmallocblock  will be assigned to the timer's  userinfo . when the timer fires,  removeobject:  does nothing since the block assigned to the timer isn't equal to any of the blocks in the array. . ;. ; the solution is to always copy the block before storing it in the array. this way, the same block instance will be stored in the array and assigned to the timer: . ;. ;  . ;

the problem here is that nstimer copies the block assigned to userinfo but the block passed to mymethodwithblock is probably an instance of nsstackblock which is not equal to its copies
let s consider three scenarios where myobject is an instance of myobject
in a the block captures no variables from its context
the block will be an instance of nsglobalblock which simply returns itself when copied
in b the block captures the variable one
it will be an instance of nsmallocblock which also returns itself when copied
in c the block again captures the variable one but is also not assigned to a variable before being passed to mymethodwithblock
in this case the block is an instance of nsstackblock which returns an instance of nsmallocblock when copied
the result of this is that in a situation like scenario c the nsstackblock will be added to allblocks while an nsmallocblock will be assigned to the timer s userinfo
when the timer fires removeobject does nothing since the block assigned to the timer isn t equal to any of the blocks in the array
the solution is to always copy the block before storing it in the array
this way the same block instance will be stored in the array and assigned to the timer



<p>In python3, things like <code>map</code>, <code>zip</code> return generators instead of a list. I think the generator brings the overhead that make your code TLE. To make a real list, use list comprehension <code>[int(line) for line in std.sys]</code></p>&#xA;

 in python3, things like  map ,  zip  return generators instead of a list. i think the generator brings the overhead that make your code tle. to make a real list, use list comprehension  . ;

in python3 things like map zip return generators instead of a list
i think the generator brings the overhead that make your code tle
to make a real list use list comprehension



<p>I want to run a jar file on every Monday that can be executed from command prompt only not by mouse double click. I have used windows task scheduler and it is showing the last run time of file but it is not able to perform the desired action!</p>&#xA;

<p>Matrix U returned by <code>X.computeSVD</code> has dimensions m x k where <em>m</em> is the number of rows of the original (distributed) RowMatrix X. One would expect <em>m</em> to be large (possibly larger than <em>k</em>), so it is not advisable to collect it in the driver if we want our code to scale to really large values of <em>m</em>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I would say both of the solutions below suffer from this flaw. The answer given by @<code>Alexander Kharlamov</code> calls <code>val U = svd.U.toBlockMatrix().toLocalMatrix()</code> which collects the matrix in the driver. The same happens with the answer given by @<code>Climbs_lika_Spyder</code> (btw your nick rocks!!), which calls <code>svd.U.rows.collect.flatMap(x =&gt; x.toArray)</code>. I would rather suggest to rely on a distributed matrix multiplication such as the Scala code posted <a href="https://www.bigdatapartnership.com/2015/11/23/scalable-matrix-multiplication-using-spark-2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>.</p>&#xA;

 matrix u returned by  x.computesvd  has dimensions m x k where  m  is the number of rows of the original (distributed) rowmatrix x. one would expect  m  to be large (possibly larger than  k ), so it is not advisable to collect it in the driver if we want our code to scale to really large values of  m . . ;. ; i would say both of the solutions below suffer from this flaw. the answer given by @ alexander kharlamov  calls  which collects the matrix in the driver. the same happens with the answer given by @ climbs_lika_spyder  (btw your nick rocks!!), which calls . i would rather suggest to rely on a distributed matrix multiplication such as the scala code posted  here . . ;

matrix u returned by x.computesvd has dimensions m x k where m is the number of rows of the original distributed rowmatrix x
one would expect m to be large possibly larger than k so it is not advisable to collect it in the driver if we want our code to scale to really large values of m
i would say both of the solutions below suffer from this flaw
the answer given by alexander kharlamov calls which collects the matrix in the driver
the same happens with the answer given by climbs_lika_spyder btw your nick rocks
which calls
i would rather suggest to rely on a distributed matrix multiplication such as the scala code posted here



<p>I solved this using WCF callbacks. Clients 'subscribe' to the server, the server then iterates over the subscribed callbacks and calls them with the data to be pushed. When a client process is ended it issues an unsubscribe. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There are loads of examples of this on the net that are fairly easy to follow. For anyone interested these links might help.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163537.aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc163537.aspx</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://dotnetaddict.dotnetdevelopersjournal.com/wcf_alarmclock.htm" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://dotnetaddict.dotnetdevelopersjournal.com/wcf_alarmclock.htm</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://idunno.org/archive/2008/05/29/wcf-callbacks-a-beginners-guide.aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://idunno.org/archive/2008/05/29/wcf-callbacks-a-beginners-guide.aspx</a></p>&#xA;

 i solved this using wcf callbacks. clients 'subscribe' to the server, the server then iterates over the subscribed callbacks and calls them with the data to be pushed. when a client process is ended it issues an unsubscribe.  . ;. ; there are loads of examples of this on the net that are fairly easy to follow. for anyone interested these links might help. . ;. ;     . ;. ;     . ;. ;     . ;

i solved this using wcf callbacks
clients subscribe to the server the server then iterates over the subscribed callbacks and calls them with the data to be pushed
when a client process is ended it issues an unsubscribe
there are loads of examples of this on the net that are fairly easy to follow
for anyone interested these links might help

<p>Someone kindly helped me out by testing this on another phone on another continent. <p>For a simple key/value store in the cloud check out <a href="http://aws.amazon.com/simpledb/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Amazon SimpleDB</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>For complex relational data use a database. If you want a database in the cloud check-out <a href="http://aws.amazon.com/rds/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Amazon RDS</a>. </p>&#xA;

for complex relational data use a database

<p>Personally, I'd go with <code>malloc</code> and <code>free</code>.  However, you could go all out with <code>new[]</code>, placement <code>new</code> and <code>delete[]</code>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>#include &lt;new&gt;&#xA;&#xA;struct MyBuffer {&#xA;    int length;&#xA;    char data[1];&#xA;};&#xA;&#xA;MyBuffer* make_a_buffer(int size)&#xA;{&#xA;    // allocate buffer large enough for what we want&#xA;    char* raw_memory = new char[sizeof(MyBuffer) + size];&#xA;&#xA;    // call placement new to put a MyBuffer in the raw memory&#xA;    MyBuffer* buffer = new (raw_memory) MyBuffer;&#xA;    buffer-&gt;length = size;&#xA;    return buffer;&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;void destroy_a_buffer(MyBuffer* buffer)&#xA;{&#xA;    // in this case, MyBuffer has a trivial (default) destructor, so this isn't&#xA;    // really needed, but in other cases you may need to call the&#xA;    // destructor&#xA;    //&#xA;    // NOTE: there is placement new, but no placement delete&#xA;    // this is the only way to correctly destroy the object&#xA;    buffer-&gt;~MyBuffer();&#xA;&#xA;    // we've destroyed the object, and now we need to release the&#xA;    // memory, luckily we know we got it from new[], so we can&#xA;    // delete[] it&#xA;    delete[] static_cast&lt;char*&gt;(static_cast&lt;void*&gt;(buffer));&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 personally, i'd go with  malloc  and  free .  however, you could go all out with , placement  new  and : . ;. ;  . ;

personally i d go with malloc and free
however you could go all out with placement new and

<p>The first argument to the event is of type object, here it should be the ListView, and the second argument will be <code>PagePropertiesChangingEventArgs</code> which is expecting StartRowIndex and MaximumRow, both are of type integer, so you can call that method like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>int startRowIndex =2,MaximumRow=3;&#xA;lvPL_PagePropertiesChanging(lvSample, new PagePropertiesChangingEventArgs(startRowIndex , MaximumRow));&#xA;// where lvSample is the listview&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In the case of the second example, you have to call the method like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>ddlCount_SelectedIndexChanged(ddlCount, EventArgs.Empty);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>This code given a DOM Document will return a new DOM Document in which a given set of namespace URI translations have been applied (uriMap). The keys must be the URIs in the source document, the values the replacement URIs in the destination document. Unknown namespace URIs pass through unchanged. It knows to change the value of xmlns:* attributes, but will not change other attributes that might happen to have namespace URIs as their values (e.g. XSD targetNamespace)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>private static Node makeClone(Node kid, Node to, Map&lt;String, String&gt; uriMap) {&#xA;   Document doc = to.getNodeType() == Node.DOCUMENT_NODE ?&#xA;           (Document) to :&#xA;           to.getOwnerDocument();&#xA;   if (kid.getNodeType() == Node.ELEMENT_NODE) {&#xA;      String newURI =&#xA;              uriMap.containsKey(kid.getNamespaceURI()) ?&#xA;              uriMap.get(kid.getNamespaceURI()) :&#xA;              kid.getNamespaceURI();&#xA;      Element clone = doc.createElementNS(newURI, kid.getNodeName());&#xA;      to.appendChild(clone);&#xA;      for (int i = 0; i &lt; kid.getAttributes().getLength(); i++) {&#xA;         Attr attr = (Attr) kid.getAttributes().item(i);&#xA;         String newAttrURI =&#xA;                 uriMap.containsKey(attr.getNamespaceURI()) ?&#xA;                 uriMap.get(attr.getNamespaceURI()) :&#xA;                 attr.getNamespaceURI();&#xA;         String newValue = attr.getValue();&#xA;         if (attr.getNamespaceURI() != null &amp;&amp;&#xA;                 attr.getNamespaceURI().equals(&#xA;                 "http://www.w3.org/2000/xmlns/") &amp;&amp;&#xA;                 uriMap.containsKey(attr.getValue()))&#xA;            newValue = uriMap.get(attr.getValue());&#xA;         clone.setAttributeNS(newAttrURI, attr.getNodeName(), newValue);&#xA;      }&#xA;      return clone;&#xA;   }&#xA;   Node clone = kid.cloneNode(false);&#xA;   doc.adoptNode(clone);&#xA;   to.appendChild(clone);&#xA;   return clone;&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;private static void copyKidsChangingNS(Node from, Node to,&#xA;        Map&lt;String, String&gt; uriMap) {&#xA;   NodeList kids = from.getChildNodes();&#xA;   for (int i = 0; i &lt; kids.getLength(); i++) {&#xA;      Node kid = kids.item(i);&#xA;      Node clone = makeClone(kid, to, uriMap);&#xA;      copyKidsChangingNS(kid, clone, uriMap);&#xA;   }&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;public static Document changeDocNS(Document doc, Map&lt;String, String&gt; uriMap)&#xA;        throws Exception {&#xA;   DocumentBuilderFactory dbf = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance();&#xA;   dbf.setNamespaceAware(true);&#xA;   DocumentBuilder db = dbf.newDocumentBuilder();&#xA;   Document newDoc = db.newDocument();&#xA;   copyKidsChangingNS(doc, newDoc, uriMap);&#xA;   return newDoc;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 this code given a dom document will return a new dom document in which a given set of namespace uri translations have been applied (urimap). the keys must be the uris in the source document, the values the replacement uris in the destination document. unknown namespace uris pass through unchanged. it knows to change the value of xmlns:  attributes, but will not change other attributes that might happen to have namespace uris as their values (  xsd targetnamespace) . ;. ;  . ;

this code given a dom document will return a new dom document in which a given set of namespace uri translations have been applied urimap
the keys must be the uris in the source document the values the replacement uris in the destination document
unknown namespace uris pass through unchanged
it knows to change the value of xmlns attributes but will not change other attributes that might happen to have namespace uris as their values xsd targetnamespace



<p>Module-level variables are only shared between requests that use the same process. Apache is almost certainly spinning up multiple processes to serve your site. If your subsequent requests happen to go to the same process that served the initial one, you will see the change; otherwise you won't.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you really need to share data between requests no matter which process serves them, you should use a more persistent place, such as the session or the database.</p>&#xA;

 module-level variables are only shared between requests that use the same process. apache is almost certainly spinning up multiple processes to serve your site. if your subsequent requests happen to go to the same process that served the initial one, you will see the change; otherwise you won't. . ;. ; if you really need to share data between requests no matter which process serves them, you should use a more persistent place, such as the session or the database. . ;

module-level variables are only shared between requests that use the same process
apache is almost certainly spinning up multiple processes to serve your site
if your subsequent requests happen to go to the same process that served the initial one you will see the change
otherwise you won t
if you really need to share data between requests no matter which process serves them you should use a more persistent place such as the session or the database



<p>In your code when you execute <code>$compile(element)(scope);</code> it is actually compiling the <code>element</code> which do not contain the html you just added in the previous line. It is because <code>element.after</code> adds the html after the <code>element</code>. So you have to get a reference to the dynamic element inserted and then call <code>$compile</code> on it, it should work fine.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>if (addMessages) {&#xA;    var $htmlToInsert = $('&lt;div&gt;&lt;span ng-if="form.' + scope.fieldName + '.$error.maxlength"&gt;Please keep it under ' + property.length + ' characters.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;' +&#xA;        '&lt;div&gt;&lt;span ng-if="form.' + scope.fieldName + '.$error.required"&gt;This field is required&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;');&#xA;    angular.element(element).after($htmlToInsert)&#xA;    element.removeAttr("my-directive");&#xA;    $compile($htmlToInsert)(scope);&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Demo</strong> <a href="http://plnkr.co/edit/Vjt1PTGfbLa6zA0iRYSz?p=preview" rel="nofollow">http://plnkr.co/edit/Vjt1PTGfbLa6zA0iRYSz?p=preview</a></p>&#xA;

 in your code when you execute  it is actually compiling the  element  which do not contain the html you just added in the previous line. it is because  element.after  adds the html after the  element . so you have to get a reference to the dynamic element inserted and then call  on it, it should work fine. . ;. ;  . ;. ;  demo      . ;

in your code when you execute it is actually compiling the element which do not contain the html you just added in the previous line
it is because element.after adds the html after the element
so you have to get a reference to the dynamic element inserted and then call on it it should work fine

<p>I am currently working on a project that has two phases, one of which is to be dropped later on. Development for phase 2 must begin, but bug-fixes for phase 1 will be on-going during this time. I want to branch from the phase 1 repo to start on phase 2 work, but many of the files will no longer be needed. I need to integrate any changes made into the phase 2 branch, but i dont want the hassle of repeatedly removing files that are no longer relevant to me, in otherwords i only want to merge changes where we have files in common. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Let me illustrate with an example, lets say i have my phase 1 work in this repo:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Phase1&#xA; - a.txt&#xA; - b.txt</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I then branch to phase 2, and remove a.txt as i will not need it further:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Phase2&#xA; - b.txt</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now lets say as part of phase1 bug fixes, both a.txt and b.txt are updated. I only care about b.txt, but if i do a merge i get:&#xA;+N a.txt.OTHER&#xA; M b.txt</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is there a way to do this with bazaar?</p>&#xA;

 i am currently working on a project that has two phases, one of which is to be dropped later on. development for phase 2 must begin, but bug-fixes for phase 1 will be on-going during this time. i want to branch from the phase 1 repo to start on phase 2 work, but many of the files will no longer be needed. i need to integrate any changes made into the phase 2 branch, but i dont want the hassle of repeatedly removing files that are no longer relevant to me, in otherwords i only want to merge changes where we have files in common.  . ;. ; let me illustrate with an example, lets say i have my phase 1 work in this repo: . ;. ; phase1. ; - a.txt. ; - b.txt . ;. ; i then branch to phase 2, and remove a.txt as i will not need it further: . ;. ; phase2. ; - b.txt . ;. ; now lets say as part of phase1 bug fixes, both a.txt and b.txt are updated. i only care about b.txt, but if i do a merge i get:. ;+n a.txt.other. ; m b.txt . ;. ; is there a way to do this with bazaar? . ;

<p>Quoting <a href="https://github.com/navasmdc/MaterialDesignLibrary#how-to-use" rel="nofollow">the documentation</a>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>If you want use this library, you only have to download MaterialDesign project, import it into your workspace and add the project as a library in your android project settings.</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Step #1: Download the project, whether via the ZIP file that GitHub gives you or by using <code>git</code> to clone the repository</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Step #2: Move the <code>MaterialDesign/</code> directory into your project directory, as a peer of your existing <code>app/</code> module</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Step #3: Modify your <code>settings.gradle</code> in your project directory to include <code>:MaterialDesign</code> in the list of modules to build</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Step #4: In your <code>app</code> module's <code>build.gradle</code> file, add <code>compile project(':MaterialDesign')</code> to your <code>dependencies</code></p>&#xA;

 quoting  the documentation : . ;. ; . ;   if you want use this library, you only have to download materialdesign project, import it into your workspace and add the project as a library in your android project settings. . ; . ;. ; step #1: download the project, whether via the zip file that github gives you or by using  git  to clone the repository . ;. ; step #2: move the  materialdesign/  directory into your project directory, as a peer of your existing  app/  module . ;. ; step #3: modify your  settings.gradle  in your project directory to include  :materialdesign  in the list of modules to build . ;. ; step #4: in your  app  module's  build.gradle  file, add  compile project(':materialdesign')  to your  dependencies  . ;

quoting the documentation
if you want use this library you only have to download materialdesign project import it into your workspace and add the project as a library in your android project settings
step #1 download the project whether via the zip file that github gives you or by using git to clone the repository
step #2 move the materialdesign directory into your project directory as a peer of your existing app module
step #3 modify your settings.gradle in your project directory to include materialdesign in the list of modules to build
step #4 in your app module s build.gradle file add compile project materialdesign to your dependencies



<p>You're going to have to manually gzip them and then upload them to S3.  S3 doesn't have the ability to gzip on the fly like your web server does.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>EDIT:  Images are already compressed so don't gzip them.</p>&#xA;

 you're going to have to manually gzip them and then upload them to s3.  s3 doesn't have the ability to gzip on the fly like your web server does. . ;. ; edit:  images are already compressed so don't gzip them. . ;

s3 doesn t have the ability to gzip on the fly like your web server does
edit images are already compressed so don t gzip them

<p>I've come across a problem while trying to build a simple jQuery plugin, having to do with scopes I guess.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><em>The problem in short: A class (A) creates an object (B), in which a property (C) is set to one of the class methods (D). How can I access class A's methods not contained inside the object (B) through the property ( C)?</em> </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Longer version (code below): I'm declaring an object (lets call it publicMethods) inside the plugin, comprised of a bunch of methods. These methods should be some default methods (declared inside the plugin), or user declared ones if the user has declared her own when initializing the plugin.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The idea is that when the user defines her own custom method, there should be some functions and variables accessible to her (like this.someVar) in that function.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This creates some limitations though.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I want the default methods to have access to some internal functions and variables, not contained inside the object publicMethods. But when I access these methods through the object they are inside, instead of calling them directly, I do not have access to another variables/functions not inside that object.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I'm trying to find a way to let the default methods have access to it's class siblings. I know I can do some conditional statements before calling the method (if it is user defined or not), or even declare a global variable pointing to "this", but I'd rather keep it clean.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var Plugin = function (opt) {&#xA;    this.settings = $.extend({&#xA;        "someVar"   : "Value",&#xA;        "someFunc"  : null&#xA;    });&#xA;&#xA;    this.anotherVar = "Hello World";&#xA;    this.setPublic();&#xA;    this.run();&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;Plugin.prototype = {&#xA;    setPublic: function() {&#xA;        this.publicMethods.someFunc = this.someFunc;&#xA;        if ($.isFunction(this.settings.someFunc)) {&#xA;            this.publicMethods.someFunc = this.settings.someFunc;&#xA;        } else {&#xA;            this.publicMethods.someFunc = this.someFunc;&#xA;        }&#xA;    },&#xA;    someFunc: function(arg) {&#xA;        return this.anotherVar; // returns type error the second time&#xA;    },&#xA;    run: function () {&#xA;        this.someFunc();&#xA;        this.publicMethods.someFunc();&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 i've come across a problem while trying to build a simple jquery plugin, having to do with scopes i guess. . ;. ;  the problem in short: a class (a) creates an object (b), in which a property (c) is set to one of the class methods (d). how can i access class a's methods not contained inside the object (b) through the property ( c)?   . ;. ; longer version (code below): i'm declaring an object (lets call it publicmethods) inside the plugin, comprised of a bunch of methods. these methods should be some default methods (declared inside the plugin), or user declared ones if the user has declared her own when initializing the plugin. . ;. ; the idea is that when the user defines her own custom method, there should be some functions and variables accessible to her (like this.somevar) in that function. . ;. ; this creates some limitations though. . ;. ; i want the default methods to have access to some internal functions and variables, not contained inside the object publicmethods. but when i access these methods through the object they are inside, instead of calling them directly, i do not have access to another variables/functions not inside that object. . ;. ; i'm trying to find a way to let the default methods have access to it's class siblings. i know i can do some conditional statements before calling the method (if it is user defined or not), or even declare a global variable pointing to "this", but i'd rather keep it clean. . ;. ;  . ;

i ve come across a problem while trying to build a simple jquery plugin having to do with scopes i guess
the problem in short a class a creates an object b in which a property c is set to one of the class methods d
how can i access class a s methods not contained inside the object b through the property c

<p>In <code>AmazonS3Client</code> there is a method <code>doesObjectExist(String bucketName, String objectName)</code>. This method throws an <code>com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.AmazonS3Exception: Bad Request (Service: Amazon S3; Status Code: 400; Error Code: 400 Bad Request;</code> if you are calling it for an encrypted object. Any other way to check if an object exists, without knowing the encryption key that was used when saving it? I do not want to access the object without having the encryption key, I just want to know if an object named 'blabla' exists or not, so I can prompt an error message to a client that wants to upload an object called 'blabla'.</p>&#xA;

 in  amazons3client  there is a method  doesobjectexist(string bucketname, string objectname) . this method throws an  com.amazonaws.services.s3.model.amazons3exception: bad request (service: amazon s3; status code: 400; error code: 400 bad request;  if you are calling it for an encrypted object. any other way to check if an object exists, without knowing the encryption key that was used when saving it? i do not want to access the object without having the encryption key, i just want to know if an object named 'blabla' exists or not, so i can prompt an error message to a client that wants to upload an object called 'blabla'. . ;

<p>I want to create a Spring Server and a Broswer javascript client connecting via sockjs-client. The connection should be secured via Spring Security.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I have the following dilemma: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li><p>Spring Security seems to assume that the websocket handshake happens via an authenticated http session (E.g. JSESSIONID cookie set, login happened).</p></li>&#xA;<li><p>sockjs-client however seems to impose the limitation on developers that <strong>no</strong> authenticated http session must be used (See <a href="https://github.com/sockjs/sockjs-client/issues/196" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/sockjs/sockjs-client/issues/196</a>), enforcing this any way it can.</p></li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is my evaluation of the dilemma correct, and is there any obvious solution to implement security a spring server with websockets such that sockjs-client can <strong>securely</strong> connect?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The proposed solution of passing any authentication token in the GET /info request seem like hacks to circumvent the SockJS security restrictions, if used to create an authenticated HttpSession.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This seems to be the basis for problems for several people, such as:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28087404">No cookies during /info request using sockjs and stomp</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37854062">Authentication model for Spring Websocket + SockJS and sending messages on per-user basis</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20582404">How to get/set the principal and session attributes from Spring 4 stomp websocket methods</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33156282">Securing sockjs with Spring Security</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25082148">Spring Websockets @SendToUser without login?</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30499043">Spring Session Basic Auth token passed as query parameter in Spring-Websocket</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30662903">Spring security websocket and HTTP authentication/authorization</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37657783">Spring Session, Websocket Security integration flow</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28015429">Spring security/Spring session/Web sockets</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28417189">Spring Boot, Websockets cannot obtain user (i.e, java.security.Principal) from Session</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25232948">Spring 4 WebSockect over STOMP Authentication</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://sunitkatkar.blogspot.de/2014/01/spring-4-websockets-with-sockjs-stomp.html" rel="nofollow">http://sunitkatkar.blogspot.de/2014/01/spring-4-websockets-with-sockjs-stomp.html</a></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I see 3 Alternative ways to go:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li>Don't use SockJs, but native Websockets only</li>&#xA;<li>use SockJS over an authenticated Http Session via the query-param Token, and sacrifice some security</li>&#xA;<li>Connect via unauthenticated http connection and implement custom authentication handling for spring-websockets (maybe based on spring session)</li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;

 i want to create a spring server and a broswer javascript client connecting via sockjs-client. the connection should be secured via spring security. . ;. ; i have the following dilemma:  . ;. ; . ;  spring security seems to assume that the websocket handshake happens via an authenticated http session (e.g. jsessionid cookie set, login happened).  . ;  sockjs-client however seems to impose the limitation on developers that  no  authenticated http session must be used (see    ), enforcing this any way it can.  . ; . ;. ; is my evaluation of the dilemma correct, and is there any obvious solution to implement security a spring server with websockets such that sockjs-client can  securely  connect? . ;. ; the proposed solution of passing any authentication token in the get /info request seem like hacks to circumvent the sockjs security restrictions, if used to create an authenticated httpsession. . ;. ; this seems to be the basis for problems for several people, such as: . ;. ; . ;  no cookies during /info request using sockjs and stomp  . ;  authentication model for spring websocket + sockjs and sending messages on per-user basis  . ;  how to get/set the principal and session attributes from spring 4 stomp websocket methods  . ;  securing sockjs with spring security  . ;  spring websockets @sendtouser without login?  . ;  spring session basic auth token passed as query parameter in spring-websocket  . ;  spring security websocket and http authentication/authorization  . ;  spring session, websocket security integration flow  . ;  spring security/spring session/web sockets  . ;  spring boot, websockets cannot obtain user (i.e, java.security.principal) from session  . ;  spring 4 websockect over stomp authentication  . ;     . ; . ;. ; i see 3 alternative ways to go: . ;. ; . ; don't use sockjs, but native websockets only . ; use sockjs over an authenticated http session via the query-param token, and sacrifice some security . ; connect via unauthenticated http connection and implement custom authentication handling for spring-websockets (maybe based on spring session) . ; . ;

i want to create a spring server and a broswer javascript client connecting via sockjs-client
the connection should be secured via spring security
i have the following dilemma
spring security seems to assume that the websocket handshake happens via an authenticated http session e.g
jsessionid cookie set login happened
sockjs-client however seems to impose the limitation on developers that no authenticated http session must be used see enforcing this any way it can
is my evaluation of the dilemma correct and is there any obvious solution to implement security a spring server with websockets such that sockjs-client can securely connect
the proposed solution of passing any authentication token in the get info request seem like hacks to circumvent the sockjs security restrictions if used to create an authenticated httpsession
this seems to be the basis for problems for several people such as
no cookies during info request using sockjs and stomp
authentication model for spring websocket + sockjs and sending messages on per-user basis
how to get set the principal and session attributes from spring 4 stomp websocket methods
securing sockjs with spring security
spring websockets sendtouser without login
spring session basic auth token passed as query parameter in spring-websocket
spring security websocket and http authentication authorization
spring session websocket security integration flow
spring security spring session web sockets
spring boot websockets cannot obtain user i.e java.security.principal from session
spring 4 websockect over stomp authentication
i see 3 alternative ways to go
don t use sockjs but native websockets only
use sockjs over an authenticated http session via the query-param token and sacrifice some security
connect via unauthenticated http connection and implement custom authentication handling for spring-websockets maybe based on spring session

<p>The tableview has a scrollview and you can get the delegates of it to get the scroll events.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Check the docs for the UIScrollViewDelegate protocol, and implement the <code>-scrollViewDidScroll:</code> or <code>-scrollViewWillBeginDragging:</code> methods as appropriate to your situation.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Just implement the methods and it works since the tableview delegates implements the underlying scroll delegates</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Happy coding :)</p>&#xA;

 the tableview has a scrollview and you can get the delegates of it to get the scroll events. . ;. ; check the docs for the uiscrollviewdelegate protocol, and implement the  -scrollviewdidscroll:  or  -scrollviewwillbegindragging:  methods as appropriate to your situation. . ;. ; just implement the methods and it works since the tableview delegates implements the underlying scroll delegates . ;. ; happy coding :) . ;

the tableview has a scrollview and you can get the delegates of it to get the scroll events
check the docs for the uiscrollviewdelegate protocol and implement the -scrollviewdidscroll or -scrollviewwillbegindragging methods as appropriate to your situation
just implement the methods and it works since the tableview delegates implements the underlying scroll delegates
happy coding

<p>I am afraid this is not supported - only single value could be used for an operator. The wrappers uses the following client side equivalent - check <a href="http://docs.kendoui.com/api/framework/datasource#filtervalue-object" rel="nofollow">this part</a> of the documentation. You can try to specify several filters on the same field with OR logic.</p>&#xA;

<p>I had the same issue and to solve it I set <code>View controller-based status bar appearance</code> to <code>NO</code> in the <code>Info.plist</code> and used </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>UIApplication.sharedApplication().setStatusBarHidden(true, withAnimation: UIStatusBarAnimation.None)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>to hide and show the status bar</p>&#xA;

<p>Good morning.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I have created a custom treeview control that paints a normal treeview onto the screen, plus various other things. <p>Add the JQuery javascript library</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Turn the submit into a button</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code> &lt;button id="submitbutton" &gt;Add&lt;/button&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Add ids to your inputs</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;input type="text" id="tag" name="tag" /&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And add the jquery to the click for the button ...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;script type="text/javascript"&gt;&#xA;    $(document).ready(function() {&#xA;     $("#submitbutton").button().click(function(){&#xA;     $.post("tags.php",{id: $("#id").val(), tag: $("#tag").val()});&#xA;  });&#xA;});&#xA;&lt;/script&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 add the jquery javascript library . ;. ; turn the submit into a button . ;. ;  . ;. ; add ids to your inputs . ;. ;  . ;. ; and add the jquery to the click for the button ... . ;. ;  . ;

add the jquery javascript library

add ids to your inputs

<p>And here's an approach in <code>base</code> R, where we fill the entire plot area with rectangles of graduated colour, and subsequently fill the inverse of the area of interest with white.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>shade &lt;- function(x, y, col, n=500, xlab='x', ylab='y', ...) {&#xA;  # x, y: the x and y coordinates&#xA;  # col: a vector of colours (hex, numeric, character), or a colorRampPalette&#xA;  # n: the vertical resolution of the gradient&#xA;  # ...: further args to plot()&#xA;  plot(x, y, type='n', las=1, xlab=xlab, ylab=ylab, ...)&#xA;  e &lt;- par('usr')&#xA;  height &lt;- diff(e[3:4])/(n-1)&#xA;  y_up &lt;- seq(0, e[4], height)&#xA;  y_down &lt;- seq(0, e[3], -height)&#xA;  ncolor &lt;- max(length(y_up), length(y_down))&#xA;  pal &lt;- if(!is.function(col)) colorRampPalette(col)(ncolor) else col(ncolor)&#xA;  # plot rectangles to simulate colour gradient&#xA;  sapply(seq_len(n),&#xA;         function(i) {&#xA;           rect(min(x), y_up[i], max(x), y_up[i] + height, col=pal[i], border=NA)&#xA;           rect(min(x), y_down[i], max(x), y_down[i] - height, col=pal[i], border=NA)&#xA;         })&#xA;  # plot white polygons representing the inverse of the area of interest&#xA;  polygon(c(min(x), x, max(x), rev(x)),&#xA;          c(e[4], ifelse(y &gt; 0, y, 0), &#xA;            rep(e[4], length(y) + 1)), col='white', border=NA)     &#xA;  polygon(c(min(x), x, max(x), rev(x)),&#xA;          c(e[3], ifelse(y &lt; 0, y, 0), &#xA;            rep(e[3], length(y) + 1)), col='white', border=NA)      &#xA;  lines(x, y)&#xA;  abline(h=0)&#xA;  box()  &#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here are some examples:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>xy &lt;- curve(sin, -10, 10, n = 1000)&#xA;shade(xy$x, xy$y, c('white', 'blue'), 1000)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/UgNnU.png" alt="pic1"></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Or with colour specified by a colour ramp palette:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>shade(xy$x, xy$y, heat.colors, 1000)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/3u5UD.png" alt="pic2"></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And applied to your data, though we first interpolate the points to a finer resolution (if we don't do this, the gradient doesn't closely follow the line where it crosses zero).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>xy &lt;- approx(my.spline$x, my.spline$y, n=1000)&#xA;shade(xy$x, xy$y, c('white', 'red'), 1000)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/l2DyP.png" alt="pic3"></p>&#xA;

 and here's an approach in  base  r, where we fill the entire plot area with rectangles of graduated colour, and subsequently fill the inverse of the area of interest with white. . ;. ;  . ;. ; here are some examples: . ;. ;  . ;. ;   . ;. ; or with colour specified by a colour ramp palette: . ;. ;  . ;. ;   . ;. ; and applied to your data, though we first interpolate the points to a finer resolution (if we don't do this, the gradient doesn't closely follow the line where it crosses zero). . ;. ;  . ;. ;   . ;

and here s an approach in base r where we fill the entire plot area with rectangles of graduated colour and subsequently fill the inverse of the area of interest with white
here are some examples
or with colour specified by a colour ramp palette
and applied to your data though we first interpolate the points to a finer resolution if we don t do this the gradient doesn t closely follow the line where it crosses zero



<p>You would normally call C library wrappers for the system calls (for example open() and read() are just wrappers). Wrappers are more friendly.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>As an alternative to do the work yourself in assembly, you can try the <a href="http://linux.die.net/man/2/syscall" rel="nofollow">syscall(2)</a> function from glibc. This function makes a system call without a wrapper, and is specially useful when invoking a system call that has no wrapper function. In this manner you just need to provide symbolic constants for system call numbers, and also i think is more portable than coding the system call in assembler instructions.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Example from the doc:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>#define _GNU_SOURCE&#xA;#include &lt;unistd.h&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;sys/syscall.h&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;sys/types.h&gt;&#xA;int&#xA;main(int argc, char *argv[])&#xA;{&#xA;    pid_t tid;&#xA;    tid = syscall(SYS_gettid);&#xA;    tid = syscall(SYS_tgkill, getpid(), tid);&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 you would normally call c library wrappers for the system calls (for example open() and read() are just wrappers). wrappers are more friendly. . ;. ; as an alternative to do the work yourself in assembly, you can try the  syscall(2)  function from glibc. this function makes a system call without a wrapper, and is specially useful when invoking a system call that has no wrapper function. in this manner you just need to provide symbolic constants for system call numbers, and also i think is more portable than coding the system call in assembler instructions. . ;. ; example from the doc: . ;. ;  . ;

you would normally call c library wrappers for the system calls for example open and read are just wrappers
wrappers are more friendly
as an alternative to do the work yourself in assembly you can try the syscall 2 function from glibc
this function makes a system call without a wrapper and is specially useful when invoking a system call that has no wrapper function
in this manner you just need to provide symbolic constants for system call numbers and also i think is more portable than coding the system call in assembler instructions
example from the doc

<p>If you are developing on a device via usb, try going to the App Manager from the options menu (stack of lines), scrolling down to the OpenCV Manager (assuming you are on OpenCV 2.4.2 or higher) and Force Close it.  Do the same with your Tutorial 0 app.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I have Tutorial 0 working on my ubuntu machine.  However, when I tried to add some OpenCV classes into a pure android project, I got the UnsatisfiedLink error.  After that, my Tutorial 0 stopped working for a while with the "camera not found" error you are getting.  It seems that OpenCV Manager can get messed up, probably having a lock or something on some resources, and needs to restart.  My suggestion fixed the Totorial 0 camera problem, but not the unsatisfiedLink for my pure android + openCV project.</p>&#xA;

 if you are developing on a device via usb, try going to the app manager from the options menu (stack of lines), scrolling down to the opencv manager (assuming you are on opencv 2.4.2 or higher) and force close it.  do the same with your tutorial 0 app. . ;. ; i have tutorial 0 working on my ubuntu machine.  however, when i tried to add some opencv classes into a pure android project, i got the unsatisfiedlink error.  after that, my tutorial 0 stopped working for a while with the "camera not found" error you are getting.  it seems that opencv manager can get messed up, probably having a lock or something on some resources, and needs to restart.  my suggestion fixed the totorial 0 camera problem, but not the unsatisfiedlink for my pure android + opencv project. . ;

<p>They may be the same type, but they are not the same instance.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The solution is to override <code>Equals</code> on <code>TipoIndiceModel</code> to provide member equality rather than the default reference equality. Consider implementing <code>IEquatable&lt;TipoIndiceModel&gt;</code> too!</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Reference:  </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>IEquatable interface: <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms131187.aspx" rel="nofollow">http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms131187.aspx</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>If you implement IEquatable, you should also override the base class implementations of Object.Equals(Object) and GetHashCode so that their behavior is consistent with that of the IEquatable.Equals method.</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Guidelines for Overloading Equals() and Operator ==  <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms173147%28v=vs.80%29.aspx" rel="nofollow">http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms173147%28v=vs.80%29.aspx</a></p>&#xA;

 they may be the same type, but they are not the same instance. . ;. ; the solution is to override  equals  on  tipoindicemodel  to provide member equality rather than the default reference equality. consider implementing  too! . ;. ; reference:   . ;. ; iequatable interface:     . ;. ; . ;   if you implement iequatable, you should also override the base class implementations of object.equals(object) and gethashcode so that their behavior is consistent with that of the iequatable.equals method. . ; . ;. ; guidelines for overloading equals() and operator ==      . ;

they may be the same type but they are not the same instance
the solution is to override equals on tipoindicemodel to provide member equality rather than the default reference equality
consider implementing too
reference
iequatable interface
if you implement iequatable you should also override the base class implementations of object.equals object and gethashcode so that their behavior is consistent with that of the iequatable.equals method
guidelines for overloading equals and operator

<p>All,</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My setup:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>We are storing lat/lng as decimal values (up to 6 decimal places) in database which are mapped in the domain model (loaded entity) as decimal values (of lat/lng)</p></li>&#xA;<li><p>In the application though we use a class "Location" that performs operations on lat/lng which are in double format (because the .net Math api works in doubles)</p></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Therefore, when we load lat/lng from database in decimal, it ends used by the application as double(s). And that's the problem! &#xA;Conversion of double -> dec (rounding occurs) and I know why it happens so what's the best work around this?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Example of the problem:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The rounding is a problem in cases where a user entered a lat in component form (DMS) and after the conversion and saving the lat into database a different value is saved. When it is loaded back and viewed by the user in component form, it is not what he entered initially. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Ex:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>User entered: N10-01-03.5 </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When loaded back: N10-01-03.468 (caused by dbl -> dec conversion) </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Possible solutions:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>1) Use decimals (for lat/lng) in my "Location" class and every time I do a calculation, I would convert lat/lng from dec -> dbl and then back to dec.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>2) Store lat/lng as doubles in the database (not sure if this will be a problem in the future). We want accuracy to 6 decimal places.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>3) Your suggestion .....</p>&#xA;

 all, . ;. ; my setup: . ;. ; . ;  we are storing lat/lng as decimal values (up to 6 decimal places) in database which are mapped in the domain model (loaded entity) as decimal values (of lat/lng)  . ;  in the application though we use a class "location" that performs operations on lat/lng which are in double format (because the .net math api works in doubles)  . ; . ;. ; therefore, when we load lat/lng from database in decimal, it ends used by the application as double(s). and that's the problem! . ;conversion of double -> dec (rounding occurs) and i know why it happens so what's the best work around this? . ;. ; example of the problem: . ;. ; the rounding is a problem in cases where a user entered a lat in component form (dms) and after the conversion and saving the lat into database a different value is saved. when it is loaded back and viewed by the user in component form, it is not what he entered initially.  . ;. ; ex: . ;. ; user entered: n10-01-03.5  . ;. ; when loaded back: n10-01-03.468 (caused by dbl -> dec conversion)  . ;. ; possible solutions: . ;. ; 1) use decimals (for lat/lng) in my "location" class and every time i do a calculation, i would convert lat/lng from dec -> dbl and then back to dec. . ;. ; 2) store lat/lng as doubles in the database (not sure if this will be a problem in the future). we want accuracy to 6 decimal places. . ;. ; 3) your suggestion ..... . ;

all
my setup
we are storing lat lng as decimal values up to 6 decimal places in database which are mapped in the domain model loaded entity as decimal values of lat lng
in the application though we use a class location that performs operations on lat lng which are in double format because the .net math api works in doubles
therefore when we load lat lng from database in decimal it ends used by the application as double s
and that s the problem
conversion of double - dec rounding occurs and i know why it happens so what s the best work around this
example of the problem
the rounding is a problem in cases where a user entered a lat in component form dms and after the conversion and saving the lat into database a different value is saved
when it is loaded back and viewed by the user in component form it is not what he entered initially
ex
user entered n10-01-03.5
when loaded back n10-01-03.468 caused by dbl - dec conversion
possible solutions
1 use decimals for lat lng in my location class and every time i do a calculation i would convert lat lng from dec - dbl and then back to dec
2 store lat lng as doubles in the database not sure if this will be a problem in the future
we want accuracy to 6 decimal places
3 your suggestion ...

<p>There is MPI version for Python <a href="http://pympi.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">[1]</a> <a href="http://mpi4py.scipy.org/" rel="nofollow">[2]</a>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_Passing_Interface" rel="nofollow">MPI</a> (Message Passing Interface) is a standardized interface and it is cool because you find it also in C, Java, (Fortran) etc.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It enables you to communicate between your processes that run remote. You use these messages for synchronization and for information passing.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You also have collective operations, like <code>broadcast</code>, <code>gather</code>, <code>reduce</code></p>&#xA;

 there is mpi version for python  [1]   [2] . . ;. ;  mpi  (message passing interface) is a standardized interface and it is cool because you find it also in c, java, (fortran) etc. . ;. ; it enables you to communicate between your processes that run remote. you use these messages for synchronization and for information passing. . ;. ; you also have collective operations, like  broadcast ,  gather ,  reduce  . ;

there is mpi version for python 1 2
mpi message passing interface is a standardized interface and it is cool because you find it also in c java fortran etc
it enables you to communicate between your processes that run remote
you use these messages for synchronization and for information passing
you also have collective operations like broadcast gather reduce

float64(17), int64(4)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There's too many columns for it to print out the contents.
