<p><strong>Background</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I want to insert the following into my web.config</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>  &lt;sectionGroup name="elmah"&gt;&#xA;    &lt;section name="security" requirePermission="false" type="Elmah.SecuritySectionHandler, Elmah"/&gt;&#xA;    &lt;section name="errorLog" requirePermission="false" type="Elmah.ErrorLogSectionHandler, Elmah"/&gt;&#xA;    &lt;section name="errorMail" requirePermission="false" type="Elmah.ErrorMailSectionHandler, Elmah"/&gt;&#xA;  &lt;/sectionGroup&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(no prizes for guessing what I am trying to achieve!) but I am getting thoroughly confused.  The docs on MSDN suggest that I need to create a subclass of ConfurationSection if I want to add one to a group.  I wrote myself a little windows application to help me figure it out but I did not get very far!  Here is the pertinent code - which tries to add the just the "security" section.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>private void AddElmahSectionGroup()&#xA;{&#xA;    string exePath = Path.Combine(Environment.CurrentDirectory, "NameOfExe.exe");&#xA;    Configuration configuration = ConfigurationManager.OpenExeConfiguration(exePath);&#xA;&#xA;    ConfigurationSectionGroup elmahGroup = configuration.GetSectionGroup(elmahSectionGroupName);&#xA;    if (elmahGroup != null)&#xA;    {&#xA;        Console.WriteLine("sectionGroup with name {0} already in web.config", elmahSectionGroupName);&#xA;        return;&#xA;    }&#xA;    elmahGroup = new ConfigurationSectionGroup();&#xA;    configuration.SectionGroups.Add(elmahSectionGroupName, elmahGroup);&#xA;&#xA;    var securitySection = new Section { Name = "security", RequirePermission = false, Type = "Elmah.SecuritySectionHandler, Elmah" };&#xA;    elmahGroup.Sections.Add("security", securitySection);&#xA;&#xA;    configuration.Save();&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;public class Section : ConfigurationSection&#xA;{&#xA;    [ConfigurationProperty("name", IsRequired = true)]&#xA;    public string Name { get { return (String)this["name"]; } set { this["name"] = value; } }&#xA;&#xA;    [ConfigurationProperty("requirePermission", IsRequired = true)]&#xA;    public bool RequirePermission { get { return (bool)this["requirePermission"]; } set { this["requirePermission"] = value; } }&#xA;&#xA;    [ConfigurationProperty("type", IsRequired = true)]&#xA;    public string Type { get { return (string)this["type"]; } set { this["type"] = value; } }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And here is the resultant configuration file</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    &lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?&gt;&#xA;&lt;configuration&gt;&#xA;    &lt;configSections&gt;&#xA;        &lt;sectionGroup name="elmah" type="System.Configuration.ConfigurationSectionGroup, System.Configuration, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a" &gt;&#xA;            &lt;section name="security" type="ConfigEditing.Form1+ElmahLogic+Section, ConfigEditing, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null" /&gt;&#xA;        &lt;/sectionGroup&gt;&#xA;    &lt;/configSections&gt;&#xA;    &lt;elmah&gt;&#xA;        &lt;security name="security" requirePermission="false" type="Elmah.SecuritySectionHandler, Elmah" /&gt;&#xA;    &lt;/elmah&gt;&#xA;&lt;/configuration&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Which completely twisted my melon: -</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>first of all the <code>type</code> of the <code>section</code> element is the type of my class (derived from ConfigurationSection) </li>&#xA;<li>second by adding a sectionGroup definition into the group, I (at the same time) adding the group into the config.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I am not really surprised by these findings because I really don't understand the API but I just have not found any decent docs about what I want to do.  Can anyone here help - even if it just pointing me at an MSDN example that is an actual full working example.</p>&#xA;

<p>This is driving me crazy, but first I would like to apologize. I am very new to javascript/jquery.  I did, however, do my best to solve this by searching relentlessly, and to no avail.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here's my issue: I am implementing a Flickr photo gallery for a client b/c she insists on using it to upload her pictures.  To do this I am using a slider gallery I purchased, and some jQuery/AJAX to create all the functions/requests.  The slider is a jQuery script that uses specifically structured selectors to create the slideshow. The structure is like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;div class="slider"&gt;&#xA;    &lt;div class="slider-item"&gt;&#xA;        &lt;img src="path/to/img.jpg"/&gt;&#xA;        &lt;img class="thumbnail" src="path/to/img_thumbnail.jpg"/&gt;&#xA;        &lt;div class="caption"&gt;My Caption&lt;/div&gt;&#xA;        &lt;div class="thumbnail-caption"&gt;My Thumb Caption&lt;/div&gt;&#xA;    &lt;/div&gt;&#xA;&lt;/div&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The function I setup is like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>   var $currentPage = 1;&#xA;    var $totalPages;&#xA;    var $sliderHTML = "&lt;div class='slider'&gt;&lt;/div&gt;";&#xA;    var $perPage = 18;&#xA;&#xA;    function flickr(){&#xA;       $(function (){&#xA;            $($sliderHTML).prependTo("#portfolio");&#xA;            $.getJSON('http://path/to/flickr?perpage=' + $perPage + '&amp;page=' + $currentPage + '&amp;format=json&amp;jsoncallback=?',&#xA;                function(data){&#xA;&#xA;                    $totalPages = Math.ceil(data.photos.total / $perPage);&#xA;&#xA;                    $.each(data.photos.photo, function(i,item){&#xA;&#xA;                   // Loop results and grab all variables I need - Examples omitted&#xA;&#xA;                   // After which, append variables to string&#xA;&#xA;               var $sliderItem = '&lt;div class="slider-item"&gt;&lt;img height="' + imgHeight + '" src="' + photoURLo + '" alt="' + photoTitle + '" /&gt;&lt;img height="75" width="75" class="thumbnail" src="' + photoURLm + '" alt="' + photoTitle + '" /&gt;&lt;div class="caption"&gt;' + photoTitle + '&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class="thumbnailCaption"&gt;' + photoTitle + '&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;';&#xA;&#xA;                   // Then append to the main div &#xA;&#xA;                  $($sliderItem).appendTo(".slider");&#xA;&#xA;           });&#xA;      });&#xA;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;// Finally call the function on document.ready&#xA;&#xA;$(document).ready(function(){&#xA;   flickr();&#xA;});&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>To make sure the slider doesn't load until the flickr function is completed (which was causing screw-ups) I just wrapped it in a function and call it on window.load. which works perfectly.  And finally I initialize the slider w/ a window.load event.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$(window).load(aSlider()); // loads the slider script&#xA;$(window).load(advSlider()); // initializes the slider&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The whole setup works great. Initially.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here's the issue.  I need to call more pictures and this is not working at all! Here's the code snippet in my HTML:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code> &lt;script type="text/javascript"&gt;&#xA;        $('#moreSlides').click(function (){&#xA;            if($totalPages == $currentPage){ //checks for last page&#xA;                $currentPage = 1;            //resets to page one&#xA;            }&#xA;            else {&#xA;                $currentPage++;      // increments page &#xA;            }&#xA;            $('.slider').remove();      //removes entire slider div              &#xA;            flickr();&#xA;            $(".slider-item").ajaxComplete(aSlider());&#xA;            advSlider();&#xA;        });&#xA; &lt;/script&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>One way or another this always fails.  I have tried stepping through this click event in the console and what it basically looks like is that it gets to the flickr() function and just passes over it instead of executing the function (which I can see happen if I step through it in the console on load).  However, it does eventually execute the function... it creates the div class=slider, and within it, my loading animation, but after that it does not load the slide-items until after it executes the aSlider() function.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I have reproduced what I want to happen in the console manually and it works fine: Increment the $currentPage: check.  Remove the .slider div: check. Execute flickr():check. Execute aSlider: check.  Initialize advSlider(): check.  Everything works perfectly with all the second page images showing up.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Something is wrong with the sequence and I simply do not know what it is.  I have tried everything I can find to get the aSlider to wait, but it doesn't work.  Please help!</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Thanks</p>&#xA;

<p>Make addresses <code>async</code> to load them on demand, or don't define it at all in the model definition if you plan on manually setting it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>addresses : DS.hasMany('address', {async:true})&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 make addresses  async  to load them on demand, or don't define it at all in the model definition if you plan on manually setting it. . ;. ;  . ;

make addresses async to load them on demand or don t define it at all in the model definition if you plan on manually setting it



<p>Have you tried this code? You can add Callback functions, and within them handle user responses.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(successCallback, errorCallback {maximumAge:600000});&#xA;&#xA;function successCallback(position) {&#xA;    // Handle Confirm button hit&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;function errorCallback(error) {&#xA;    // Other&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 have you tried this code? you can add callback functions, and within them handle user responses. . ;. ;  . ;

<p>I ran your code in BlueJ the error was that, in the main function, the line  <code>enter code here</code>  is a useless line. Therefore if we remove the line the program runs absolutely fine :).</p>&#xA;

<p>Use </p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://php.net/parse_url" rel="nofollow">parse_url</a> to split the URL into its components </li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://php.net/parse_str" rel="nofollow">parse_str</a> to parse the <code>query</code> component.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 use  . ;. ; . ;  parse_url  to split the url into its components  . ;  parse_str  to parse the  query  component. . ; . ;

use
parse_url to split the url into its components
parse_str to parse the query component



<p>Canvas's do not stretch to fill their given space.  So get rid of canvas2.</p>&#xA;

 canvas's do not stretch to fill their given space.  so get rid of canvas2. . ;

canvas s do not stretch to fill their given space
so get rid of canvas2



<p>Using Rhino Mocks, you could set an expectation for the property.  This basically states that you expect the property to be set to a certain value.  Using your example, an example test method body would be this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>&#xA;    var mock = MockRepository.GenerateMock();&#xA;    mock.Expect(x => x.Property1 = "Test");</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var classUnderTest = new ClassUnderTest(mock);&#xA;classUnderTest.MethodUnderTest();&#xA;&#xA;mock.VerifyAllExpectations();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This would check to see if <code>Property1</code> had been set to "Test" at some point between the call to <code>mock.Expect</code> and the call to <code>mock.MethodUnderTest</code> (technically, <code>Property1</code> could be set in the constructor of <code>ClassUnderTest</code>).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In order to test that the property was set and ignore what it was actually set to, just chain <code>IgnoreArguments</code> to the return of the <code>Expect</code> call, like so:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>&#xA;    mock.Expect(x => x.Property1 = "Test1").IgnoreArguments();</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>One way to test more complex write-only properties is to use the <code>GetArgumentsForCallsMadeOn</code> method.  This allows you to retrieve a list of the arguments passed to each "call" of the property.  The code to do this would be like the following:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>&#xA;    var mock = MockRepository.GenerateMock();</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var classUnderTest = new ClassUnderTest(mock);&#xA;classUnderTest.MethodUnderTest();&#xA;&#xA;//the argument in the Action is ignored, so just use null&#xA;//Property1 is of type List&lt;string&gt;&#xA;var arguments = mock.GetArgumentsForCallsMadeOn(x =&gt; x.Property1 = null);&#xA;&#xA;//arguments[0] contains the list of arguments for the first "call" of the&#xA;//property the first index (0) of that would contain the first argument&#xA;var firstCallArguments = arguments[0];&#xA;var firstArgument = (List&lt;string&gt;)firstCallArguments[0];&#xA;Assert.AreEqual(3, firstArgument.Count);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I am sure that Moq has similar functionality if you'd like to use that, instead.</p>&#xA;

 using rhino mocks, you could set an expectation for the property.  this basically states that you expect the property to be set to a certain value.  using your example, an example test method body would be this: . ;. ; . ;    var mock = mockrepository.generatemock();. ;    mock.expect(x => x.property1 = "test"); . ;. ;  . ;. ; this would check to see if  property1  had been set to "test" at some point between the call to  mock.expect  and the call to  mock.methodundertest  (technically,  property1  could be set in the constructor of  classundertest ). . ;. ; in order to test that the property was set and ignore what it was actually set to, just chain  ignorearguments  to the return of the  expect  call, like so: . ;. ; . ;    mock.expect(x => x.property1 = "test1").ignorearguments(); . ;. ; one way to test more complex write-only properties is to use the  getargumentsforcallsmadeon  method.  this allows you to retrieve a list of the arguments passed to each "call" of the property.  the code to do this would be like the following: . ;. ; . ;    var mock = mockrepository.generatemock(); . ;. ;  . ;. ; i am sure that moq has similar functionality if you'd like to use that, instead. . ;

using rhino mocks you could set an expectation for the property
this basically states that you expect the property to be set to a certain value
using your example an example test method body would be this
var mock mockrepository.generatemock
mock.expect x x.property1 test
this would check to see if property1 had been set to test at some point between the call to mock.expect and the call to mock.methodundertest technically property1 could be set in the constructor of classundertest
in order to test that the property was set and ignore what it was actually set to just chain ignorearguments to the return of the expect call like so
mock.expect x x.property1 test1 .ignorearguments
one way to test more complex write-only properties is to use the getargumentsforcallsmadeon method
this allows you to retrieve a list of the arguments passed to each call of the property
the code to do this would be like the following
var mock mockrepository.generatemock
i am sure that moq has similar functionality if you d like to use that instead



<p>This is probably a bit simple for many of you but on the off chance it's useful.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Based on richq's answer, I found these to be useful in my vimrc. Note, the second one is commented out normally because it makes dd a bit confusing since Vim will wait for another key stroke to work out if it's the mapped ex command.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre>&#xA;function! D2u()&#xA;    execute '%s/\r\(\n\)/\1/g'&#xA;endfunction&#xA;"map d2u :%s/\r\(\n\)/\1/g&#xA;</pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The first is run by typing <code>call D2u()</code> into ex and the second by pressing <code>D2u</code> in edit mode.</p>&#xA;

 this is probably a bit simple for many of you but on the off chance it's useful. . ;. ; based on richq's answer, i found these to be useful in my vimrc. note, the second one is commented out normally because it makes dd a bit confusing since vim will wait for another key stroke to work out if it's the mapped ex command. . ;. ; . ;function! d2u(). ;    execute '%s/\r\(\n\)/\1/g'. ;endfunction. ;"map d2u :%s/\r\(\n\)/\1/g. ; . ;. ; the first is run by typing  call d2u()  into ex and the second by pressing  d2u  in edit mode. . ;

this is probably a bit simple for many of you but on the off chance it s useful
based on richq s answer i found these to be useful in my vimrc
note the second one is commented out normally because it makes dd a bit confusing since vim will wait for another key stroke to work out if it s the mapped ex command
function
d2u
execute s r n 1 g
endfunction
map d2u s r n 1 g
the first is run by typing call d2u into ex and the second by pressing d2u in edit mode

<p>A little late to the game on this one, but I just worked out a solution to this so I thought I would share. In order to display the UI elements they have to be created on the UI thread on which they will be displayed. Since the long running task is on the UI thread, it will prevent a progress bar from updating. To get around this, I created the progress bar on a new UI thread and created the pages on the main UI thread.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>        Thread t = new Thread(() =&gt;&#xA;            {&#xA;                ProgressDialog pd = new ProgressDialog(context);&#xA;                pd.WindowStartupLocation = System.Windows.WindowStartupLocation.CenterScreen;&#xA;                pd.Show();&#xA;                System.Windows.Threading.Dispatcher.Run();&#xA;            });&#xA;        t.SetApartmentState(ApartmentState.STA);&#xA;        t.IsBackground = true;&#xA;        t.Start();&#xA;&#xA;        Action();   //we need to execute the action on the main thread so that UI elements created by the action can later be displayed in the main UI&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>'ProgressDialog' was my own WPF window for displaying progress information.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>'context' holds the progress data for my progress dialog. It includes a cancelled property so that I can abort the action running on the main thread. It also includes a complete property so the progress dialog can close when the Action has finished.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>'Action' is the method used to create all the UI elements. It monitors the context for the cancel flag and stops generating the UI elements if the flag is set. It sets the complete flag when it is done.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I don't remember the exact reason I had to set Thread 't' to an STA thread and IsBackground to true, but I am pretty sure it won't work without them.</p>&#xA;

 a little late to the game on this one, but i just worked out a solution to this so i thought i would share. in order to display the ui elements they have to be created on the ui thread on which they will be displayed. since the long running task is on the ui thread, it will prevent a progress bar from updating. to get around this, i created the progress bar on a new ui thread and created the pages on the main ui thread. . ;. ;  . ;. ; 'progressdialog' was my own wpf window for displaying progress information. . ;. ; 'context' holds the progress data for my progress dialog. it includes a cancelled property so that i can abort the action running on the main thread. it also includes a complete property so the progress dialog can close when the action has finished. . ;. ; 'action' is the method used to create all the ui elements. it monitors the context for the cancel flag and stops generating the ui elements if the flag is set. it sets the complete flag when it is done. . ;. ; i don't remember the exact reason i had to set thread 't' to an sta thread and isbackground to true, but i am pretty sure it won't work without them. . ;

a little late to the game on this one but i just worked out a solution to this so i thought i would share
in order to display the ui elements they have to be created on the ui thread on which they will be displayed
since the long running task is on the ui thread it will prevent a progress bar from updating
to get around this i created the progress bar on a new ui thread and created the pages on the main ui thread
progressdialog was my own wpf window for displaying progress information
context holds the progress data for my progress dialog
it includes a cancelled property so that i can abort the action running on the main thread
it also includes a complete property so the progress dialog can close when the action has finished
action is the method used to create all the ui elements
it monitors the context for the cancel flag and stops generating the ui elements if the flag is set
it sets the complete flag when it is done
i don t remember the exact reason i had to set thread t to an sta thread and isbackground to true but i am pretty sure it won t work without them

Because the feature was not added before most of the rows got created, I'm now stuck with an pre-set value in most of the tables.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I wondered if anyone knew a script/command in PhpMyAdmin to update every row with a random number ranging from 4 to 5 digits.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Table:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Unique_ID&#xA;ID&#xA;Username&#xA;Gold&#xA;Bank&#xA;Troop&#xA;Head&#xA;Body&#xA;Gloves&#xA;Legs&#xA;Feet&#xA;**PIN**&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>PIN needs to be automaticly set, the user can't set it himself. The system would be useless otherwise.&#xA;And the data is not hashed, since theres already an protective script with Python. </p>&#xA;

<p>Another major approach is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqueness_type">uniqueness typing</a>, as in <a href="http://wiki.clean.cs.ru.nl/Language_features">Clean</a>. The short story is that handles to state (including the real world) can only be used once, and functions that access mutable state return a new handle. This means that an output of the first call is an input of a second, forcing the sequential evaluation.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Effect typing is used in the <a href="http://disciple.ouroborus.net/">Disciple Compiler</a> for Haskell, but to the best of my knowledge it would take considerable compiler work to enable it in, say, GHC. I shall leave discussion of the details to those better-informed than myself.</p>&#xA;

 another major approach is  uniqueness typing , as in  clean . the short story is that handles to state (including the real world) can only be used once, and functions that access mutable state return a new handle. this means that an output of the first call is an input of a second, forcing the sequential evaluation. . ;. ; effect typing is used in the  disciple compiler  for haskell, but to the best of my knowledge it would take considerable compiler work to enable it in, say, ghc. i shall leave discussion of the details to those better-informed than myself. . ;

another major approach is uniqueness typing as in clean
the short story is that handles to state including the real world can only be used once and functions that access mutable state return a new handle
this means that an output of the first call is an input of a second forcing the sequential evaluation
effect typing is used in the disciple compiler for haskell but to the best of my knowledge it would take considerable compiler work to enable it in say ghc
i shall leave discussion of the details to those better-informed than myself

<p>This is a hard problem to solve, especially given the variation of colours depending on lighting and reflection. I have worked previously on finding skin in images, and generally the Cr (chroma red) component of the YCbCr colour space stands out prominently on skin. You might be able to exploit this information to find skin regions.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here are a couple of papers that attempt to use colour for locating human skin:&#xA;1. <a href="http://www.robots.ox.ac.uk/ActiveVision/Papers/mayol_etal_bmvc2004/mayol_etal_bmvc2004.pdf" rel="nofollow">Interaction between hands and wearable cameras</a>&#xA;2. <a href="http://www.cs.ucsb.edu/~holl/pubs/Lee-2007-ISWC.pdf" rel="nofollow">Markerless inspection of augmented reality objects</a></p>&#xA;

 this is a hard problem to solve, especially given the variation of colours depending on lighting and reflection. i have worked previously on finding skin in images, and generally the cr (chroma red) component of the ycbcr colour space stands out prominently on skin. you might be able to exploit this information to find skin regions. . ;. ; here are a couple of papers that attempt to use colour for locating human skin:. ;1.  interaction between hands and wearable cameras . ;2.  markerless inspection of augmented reality objects  . ;

i have worked previously on finding skin in images and generally the cr chroma red component of the ycbcr colour space stands out prominently on skin
you might be able to exploit this information to find skin regions
here are a couple of papers that attempt to use colour for locating human skin

<p>I would do the following modifications</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li>Create an abstract base model class with abstract CRUD functions and abstract variable which tells the table name the model will be working with.</li>&#xA;<li>For each of my table I would create a base table specific model inheriting my base model class and define table name and CRUD operations.</li>&#xA;<li>For defining all my extra functions I would make a model which may use the model(s) created in step 2 to do multiple operations</li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;&#xA;<p>PS: This is not my original idea. This pattern is used by many PHP MVC frameworks to structure their code.</p>&#xA;

 i would do the following modifications . ;. ; . ; create an abstract base model class with abstract crud functions and abstract variable which tells the table name the model will be working with. . ; for each of my table i would create a base table specific model inheriting my base model class and define table name and crud operations. . ; for defining all my extra functions i would make a model which may use the model(s) created in step 2 to do multiple operations . ; . ;. ; ps: this is not my original idea. this pattern is used by many php mvc frameworks to structure their code. . ;

i would do the following modifications
create an abstract base model class with abstract crud functions and abstract variable which tells the table name the model will be working with
for each of my table i would create a base table specific model inheriting my base model class and define table name and crud operations
for defining all my extra functions i would make a model which may use the model s created in step 2 to do multiple operations
ps this is not my original idea
this pattern is used by many php mvc frameworks to structure their code



<p>It is possible to refrase the description of needed regex to "contains at least one number" so the followind would work <code>/.*[\pN].*/</code>. Or, if you would like to limit your search to letters numbers and punctuation you shoud use <code>/[\pL\pN\pP]*[\pN][\pL\pN\pP]*/</code>. I've tested it on your examples and it works fine.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You can further refine your regexp by using lazy quantifiers like this <code>/.*?[\pN].*?/</code>. This way it would fail faster if there are no numbers.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I would like to recomend you a great book on regular expressions: <a href="http://oreilly.com/catalog/9780596528126?green=22189307057&amp;cmp=af-mybuy-9780596528126.IP" rel="nofollow">Mastering regular expressions</a>, it has a great introduction, in depth explanation of how regular expressions work and a chapter on regular expressions in java.</p>&#xA;

 it is possible to refrase the description of needed regex to "contains at least one number" so the followind would work . or, if you would like to limit your search to letters numbers and punctuation you shoud use . i've tested it on your examples and it works fine. . ;. ; you can further refine your regexp by using lazy quantifiers like this . this way it would fail faster if there are no numbers. . ;. ; i would like to recomend you a great book on regular expressions:  mastering regular expressions , it has a great introduction, in depth explanation of how regular expressions work and a chapter on regular expressions in java. . ;

or if you would like to limit your search to letters numbers and punctuation you shoud use
i ve tested it on your examples and it works fine
you can further refine your regexp by using lazy quantifiers like this
this way it would fail faster if there are no numbers
i would like to recomend you a great book on regular expressions mastering regular expressions it has a great introduction in depth explanation of how regular expressions work and a chapter on regular expressions in java

<p>It's not an Scala-IDE, but a scala issue.&#xA;You have to use an "object" instead of a "class".</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>object main {&#xA;    def main(args: Array[String]){&#xA;     val pt = "String";&#xA;     print(HelloFunction(pt));      &#xA;    }&#xA;    def HelloFunction(value: String) : String = {    &#xA;      return "Hello "+value;&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 it's not an scala-ide, but a scala issue.. ;you have to use an "object" instead of a "class". . ;. ;  . ;

it s not an scala-ide but a scala issue
you have to use an object instead of a class

<p>At certain times you want to expose only certain functions/variables to be <em>explicit</em> properties of the <code>window</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>(function() {&#xA;   var jQuery = function(selector) { alert( selector ) }&#xA;})();&#xA;&#xA;jQuery // not defined&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If we alter it to be:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>(function() {&#xA;   var jQuery = function(selector) { alert( selector ) }&#xA;   window.jQuery = jQuery;&#xA;})();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>then we "expose" it from a private namespace explicitly.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And yes, you do not have to explicitly declare <code>window.</code> to invoke methods such as <code>alert</code>, but everyone has their own style of coding and everyone has their own degree of how explicit their statements should be.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Some people explicitly prefix <code>window.</code> to global methods such as <code>alert</code> in order to avoid any confusion. Let's say you defined a function in a private namespace that was named <code>alert</code>, for example...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>(function() {&#xA;   function alert() {}&#xA;   alert('lol'); // does nothing&#xA;   window.alert('lol') // does something&#xA;})();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>We cannot use <code>alert</code> inside of that private namespace to do our alerting, since we defined a function with exactly the same name. We have to explicitly reference the <code>window.alert</code> method to get around that.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But for general purposes, I would say it's perfectly fine to not prefix things with <code>window.</code> unless you are exposing things in a private namespace to the global namespace. So please use <code>document</code> and <code>alert</code> and such as is, in your code.</p>&#xA;

 at certain times you want to expose only certain functions/variables to be  explicit  properties of the  window . . ;. ;  . ;. ; if we alter it to be: . ;. ;  . ;. ; then we "expose" it from a private namespace explicitly. . ;. ; and yes, you do not have to explicitly declare  window.  to invoke methods such as  alert , but everyone has their own style of coding and everyone has their own degree of how explicit their statements should be. . ;. ; some people explicitly prefix  window.  to global methods such as  alert  in order to avoid any confusion. let's say you defined a function in a private namespace that was named  alert , for example... . ;. ;  . ;. ; we cannot use  alert  inside of that private namespace to do our alerting, since we defined a function with exactly the same name. we have to explicitly reference the  window.alert  method to get around that. . ;. ; but for general purposes, i would say it's perfectly fine to not prefix things with  window.  unless you are exposing things in a private namespace to the global namespace. so please use  document  and  alert  and such as is, in your code. . ;

to global methods such as alert in order to avoid any confusion

we have to explicitly reference the window.alert method to get around that
but for general purposes i would say it s perfectly fine to not prefix things with window
unless you are exposing things in a private namespace to the global namespace
so please use document and alert and such as is in your code



<p>Converting to a list seems to work:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>dats = str(list(dates_list))&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But the more correct option is to change numpy's  <a href="http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.set_printoptions.html" rel="nofollow">printoptions</a>. There is a <code>threshold</code> option that sets the limit to print a summary instead of the full repr. Default is 1000. You can change it to infinity:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>import numpy as np&#xA;np.set_printoptions(threshold=np.inf)&#xA;&#xA;dats = str(dates_list)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 converting to a list seems to work: . ;. ;  . ;. ; but the more correct option is to change numpy's   printoptions . there is a  threshold  option that sets the limit to print a summary instead of the full repr. default is 1000. you can change it to infinity: . ;. ;  . ;

converting to a list seems to work
but the more correct option is to change numpy s printoptions
there is a threshold option that sets the limit to print a summary instead of the full repr
default is 1000
you can change it to infinity



<p>You shouldn't put them in the BIN folder for long, because if the node gets reimaged you may lose the files. It is better to put them into Windows Azure storage.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li><p>Copy the extra .jar for your UDF onto Windows Azure Storage Blobs...  WASB. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>You could make a "PigExtras" folder for example. Your source locations will vary, and your destination locations will be your container and account. </p></li>&#xA;<li><p>Upload via hadoop command line:</p></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p><code>hadoop fs -copyFromLocal C:\files\MyUDF.jar wasb://container@account.blob.core.windows.net/PigExtras/MyUDF.jar</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><code>hadoop fs -copyFromLocal c:\apps\dist\pig-0.11.0.1.3.1.0-06\piggybank.jar wasb://container@account.blob.core.windows.net/PigExtras/piggybank.jar</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>You can upload in other methods as well, such as:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>Through .Net code such as <a href="http://www.windowsazure.com/en-us/develop/net/how-to-guides/blob-storage/#upload-blob" rel="nofollow">http://www.windowsazure.com/en-us/develop/net/how-to-guides/blob-storage/#upload-blob</a></p></li>&#xA;<li><p>Through command line tools like AzCopy. Get it at <a href="https://github.com/downloads/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-downloads/AzCopy.zip" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/downloads/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-downloads/AzCopy.zip</a>&#xA;AzCopy  </p></li>&#xA;</ul></li>&#xA;</ul></li>&#xA;<li><p>Reference the .jar location in your Pig latin scripts. I believe a wildcard can be used to load all jars from a certain folder, but that may be inefficient if there are many in there.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><code>REGISTER wasb:///PigExtras/*.jar;&#xA;myset = load 'wasb://container@account.blob.core.windows.net/data/file.txt' using MyUDF();&#xA;dump myset</code></p></li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;

 you shouldn't put them in the bin folder for long, because if the node gets reimaged you may lose the files. it is better to put them into windows azure storage. . ;. ; . ;  copy the extra .jar for your udf onto windows azure storage blobs...  wasb.  . ;. ; . ;  you could make a "pigextras" folder for example. your source locations will vary, and your destination locations will be your container and account.   . ;  upload via hadoop command line:  . ; . ;. ;  hadoop fs -copyfromlocal c:\files\myudf.jar wasb://container@account.blob.core.windows.net/pigextras/myudf.jar  . ;. ;  hadoop fs -copyfromlocal c:\apps\dist\pig-0.11.0.1.3.1.0-06\piggybank.jar wasb://container@account.blob.core.windows.net/pigextras/piggybank.jar  . ;. ; . ;  you can upload in other methods as well, such as: . ;. ; . ;  through .net code such as      . ;  through command line tools like azcopy. get it at    . ;azcopy    . ;  . ;  . ;  reference the .jar location in your pig latin scripts. i believe a wildcard can be used to load all jars from a certain folder, but that may be inefficient if there are many in there. . ;. ;   . ; . ;

it is better to put them into windows azure storage

hadoop fs -copyfromlocal c apps dist pig-0.11.0.1.3.1.0-06 piggybank.jar wasb container account.blob.core.windows.net pigextras piggybank.jar

<p>Use a character that can never be in a file name - such as a null (<code>0x00</code>, <code>\0</code>, whatever you want to call it). Then send a 64 bit integer that indicates how long, in bytes, the file is (make sure you don't run into buffer overflows, little endian/big endian issues, etc... just test all edge cases). Then send the file data. Then the ending socket will know which part is the file name, the file length and the file data, and will even be ready for the next file name if you want to send another.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(if file names can be arbitrary characters including control characters, ouch! Maybe send a 64 bit integer length of file name, the file name, a 64 bit integer length of file data, the file data, repeat ad infinitum?)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>EDIT: To send a 64 bit integer over a socket, send its constituent bytes in a specific order, and make sure sender and receiver agree on the order. One example of how to do this is <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2641150/how-to-convert-a-java-long-to-byte-for-cassandra">How to convert a Java Long to byte[] for Cassandra?</a></p>&#xA;

 use a character that can never be in a file name - such as a null ( 0x00 ,  \0 , whatever you want to call it). then send a 64 bit integer that indicates how long, in bytes, the file is (make sure you don't run into buffer overflows, little endian/big endian issues, etc... just test all edge cases). then send the file data. then the ending socket will know which part is the file name, the file length and the file data, and will even be ready for the next file name if you want to send another. . ;. ; (if file names can be arbitrary characters including control characters, ouch! maybe send a 64 bit integer length of file name, the file name, a 64 bit integer length of file data, the file data, repeat ad infinitum?) . ;. ; edit: to send a 64 bit integer over a socket, send its constituent bytes in a specific order, and make sure sender and receiver agree on the order. one example of how to do this is  how to convert a java long to byte[] for cassandra?  . ;

use a character that can never be in a file name - such as a null 0x00 0 whatever you want to call it
then send a 64 bit integer that indicates how long in bytes the file is make sure you don t run into buffer overflows little endian big endian issues etc.
just test all edge cases
then send the file data
then the ending socket will know which part is the file name the file length and the file data and will even be ready for the next file name if you want to send another
if file names can be arbitrary characters including control characters ouch
maybe send a 64 bit integer length of file name the file name a 64 bit integer length of file data the file data repeat ad infinitum

edit to send a 64 bit integer over a socket send its constituent bytes in a specific order and make sure sender and receiver agree on the order
one example of how to do this is how to convert a java long to byte for cassandra

<p><strong>Solved</strong>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Reading <em><a href="http://developer.qt.nokia.com/forums/viewthread/4406">When is the parent set?</a></em> helped me to find what I needed to do. This plugin is a graphical component (i.e. has a visual interface) meaning it will be draw on screen at some point. When Qt finishes loading your component, it calls a method named <code>componentComplete()</code> to notify you of so.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>All I had to do was add this method to my class definition as a public method:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>virtual void componentComplete();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>and implement it as:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>void CustomElement::componentComplete()&#xA;{&#xA;    Q_D(CustomElement);    &#xA;&#xA;    // Call superclass method to set CustomElement() parent&#xA;    QDeclarativeItem::componentComplete();   &#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Calling the method of the superclass seems to set the parent of my plugin, and this gives me access to the information set by <code>anchors.fill: parent</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Then all I had to do retrieve this information was:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Q_Q(Video);&#xA;qDebug() &lt;&lt; "CustomElement::play: widget size is " &lt;&lt; q-&gt;width() &lt;&lt; "x" &lt;&lt; q-&gt;height();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

  solved . . ;. ; reading   when is the parent set?   helped me to find what i needed to do. this plugin is a graphical component (  has a visual interface) meaning it will be draw on screen at some point. when qt finishes loading your component, it calls a method named  componentcomplete()  to notify you of so. . ;. ; all i had to do was add this method to my class definition as a public method: . ;. ;  . ;. ; and implement it as: . ;. ;  . ;. ; calling the method of the superclass seems to set the parent of my plugin, and this gives me access to the information set by  anchors.fill: parent . . ;. ; then all i had to do retrieve this information was: . ;. ;  . ;

all i had to do was add this method to my class definition as a public method
and implement it as

<p>Merged cells do bad things to VBA code. You can figure them out, they're just no very intuitive.  For your case, you need</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Debug.Print Target.Cells(1).Name.Name&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Generally when you get an error with a merged cell, you either need <code>.Cells(1)</code> or <code>.MergeArea</code>, but I never which one so I try them both.</p>&#xA;

<p>A friend and I had a very interesting discussion about the construction of Objects that ended up with this piece of code:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>#include &lt;iostream&gt;&#xA;&#xA;class Parent {&#xA;  public:&#xA;    Parent( ) {&#xA;      this-&gt;doSomething( );&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    virtual void doSomething( ) = 0;&#xA;};&#xA;&#xA;class Child : public Parent {&#xA;    int param;&#xA;&#xA;  public:&#xA;    Child( ) {&#xA;      param = 1000;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    virtual void doSomething( ) {&#xA;      std::cout &lt;&lt; "doSomething( " &lt;&lt; param &lt;&lt; " )" &lt;&lt; std::endl;&#xA;    }&#xA;};&#xA;&#xA;int main( void ) {&#xA;    Child c;&#xA;    return 0;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I know that the standard does not define the behavior when a pure virtual function is called  from a constructor or destructor, also this is not a practical example of how i would write code in production, it is just a test to check what the compiler does. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Testing the same construct in Java prints </p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>doSomething( 0 )</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>That makes sense since <code>param</code> is not initialized at the point <code>doSomething()</code> is called from the parent constructor. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I would expect similar behavior in C++, with the difference that <code>param</code> contains anything at the time the function is called. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Instead compiling the above code results in a linker error with <code>(c++ (Ubuntu 4.4.3-4ubuntu5.1) 4.4.3)</code> saying that the reference to <code>Parent::doSomething( )</code> is undefined.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So, my question is: <strong>Why is this a linker error?</strong> If this is an error, I would expect the compiler to complain, especially because there is an implementation of the function.&#xA;Any insight of how the linker works in this case or a reference to further reading would be highly appreciated.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Thank you in advance! I hope that this question is not a duplicate, but i could not find a similar question..</p>&#xA;

 a friend and i had a very interesting discussion about the construction of objects that ended up with this piece of code: . ;. ;  . ;. ; i know that the standard does not define the behavior when a pure virtual function is called  from a constructor or destructor, also this is not a practical example of how i would write code in production, it is just a test to check what the compiler does.  . ;. ; testing the same construct in java prints  . ;. ; . ;   dosomething( 0 ) . ; . ;. ; that makes sense since  param  is not initialized at the point  dosomething()  is called from the parent constructor.  . ;. ; i would expect similar behavior in c++, with the difference that  param  contains anything at the time the function is called.  . ;. ; instead compiling the above code results in a linker error with  (c++ (ubuntu 4.4.3-4ubuntu5.1) 4.4.3)  saying that the reference to  parent::dosomething( )  is undefined. . ;. ; so, my question is:  why is this a linker error?  if this is an error, i would expect the compiler to complain, especially because there is an implementation of the function.. ;any insight of how the linker works in this case or a reference to further reading would be highly appreciated. . ;. ; thank you in advance! i hope that this question is not a duplicate, but i could not find a similar question.. . ;

testing the same construct in java prints
dosomething 0
that makes sense since param is not initialized at the point dosomething is called from the parent constructor
i would expect similar behavior in c++ with the difference that param contains anything at the time the function is called

so my question is why is this a linker error

<p>What you describe is called hashing, not encryption.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I think you can use some form of SHA-2, possibly after concatenating with a 'salt' string. Most common platforms provide built-in functions for such hashing algorithms. Details: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-2</a></p>&#xA;

 what you describe is called hashing, not encryption. . ;. ; i think you can use some form of sha-2, possibly after concatenating with a 'salt' string. most common platforms provide built-in functions for such hashing algorithms. details:     . ;

what you describe is called hashing not encryption
i think you can use some form of sha-2 possibly after concatenating with a salt string
most common platforms provide built-in functions for such hashing algorithms
details

<p>I'm trying to create a Bitmap from an existing URI, rotate the Bitmap and save it to the same place as a JPEG file. This is my current code after having tried several solutions:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>try {&#xA;    // Get the Bitmap from the known URI. This seems to work.&#xA;    Bitmap bmp = MediaStore.Images.Media.getBitmap(this.getContentResolver(), this.currUserImgUri);&#xA;&#xA;    // Rotate the Bitmap thanks to a rotated matrix. <p>HTML provides 2 keywords to prevent user's interaction of <code>input</code> elements: <code>disabled</code> and <code>readonly</code>. You should use them instead of using browser-attributed CSS.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>By the way, <code>disabled</code> is a boolean attribute. No need <code>disabled="disabled"</code>. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Correct usage: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;td&gt;&lt;input id="txtTicketCode" disabled /&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Last, you want read-only or disabled? Read more with this <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/7730719/188331">answer</a>.</p>&#xA;

 html provides 2 keywords to prevent user's interaction of  input  elements:  disabled  and  readonly . you should use them instead of using browser-attributed css. . ;. ; by the way,  disabled  is a boolean attribute. no need .  . ;. ; correct usage:  . ;. ;  . ;. ; last, you want read-only or disabled? read more with this  answer . . ;

html provides 2 keywords to prevent user s interaction of input elements disabled and readonly
you should use them instead of using browser-attributed css
by the way disabled is a boolean attribute
no need
correct usage
last you want read-only or disabled
read more with this answer

<p>Try <code>INSERT WHERE NOT EXISTS</code>, where <code>a</code>, <code>b</code> and <code>c</code> are relevant columns, <code>@a</code>, <code>@b</code> and <code>@c</code> are relevant values.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>INSERT INTO table&#xA;(&#xA;    a,&#xA;    b,&#xA;    c&#xA;)&#xA;VALUES&#xA;(&#xA;    @a,&#xA;    @b,&#xA;    @c&#xA;)&#xA;WHERE NOT EXISTS&#xA;(&#xA;    SELECT 0 FROM table WHERE a = @a, b = @b, c = @c&#xA;)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>I'm building a Selenium suite.  I am trying to figure out how to best run a TestFixture for all browsers and all our clients.  Here is what I tried to do, which doesn't work due for "not having a suitable constructor"</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here is my base class to give a browser and method to create a webdriver to the sub classes.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>[TestFixture(Browser.Chrome)]&#xA;[TestFixture(Browser.Firefox)]&#xA;[TestFixture(Browser.IE)]&#xA;[TestFixture(Browser.Safari)]&#xA;abstract class WebDriverTest&#xA;{&#xA;    protected IWebDriver driver;&#xA;    protected Browser browser;&#xA;&#xA;    public WebDriverTest(Browser browser)&#xA;    {&#xA;        this.browser = browser;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    protected IWebDriver CreateWebDriver()&#xA;    {&#xA;        CreateWebDriver(browser);&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And a TestFixture for all clients. I would have other similar tests classes for features belonging to certain sets of clients.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>[TestFixture(Client.Client1)]&#xA;[TestFixture(Client.Client2)]&#xA;abstract class AllClientsTest : WebDriverTest&#xA;{&#xA;    protected Client client;&#xA;&#xA;    public AllClientsTest(Browser browser, Client client) : base(browser)&#xA;    {&#xA;        this.client = client;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    protected Navigator GetNavigator()&#xA;    {&#xA;        return NewNavigator(client)&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>And finally the class where I would write a test with the webdriver that runs for all clients.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>class InheritanceTest : AllClientsTest&#xA;{&#xA;    public InheritanceTest(Browser browser, Client client) : base(browser, client)&#xA;    {&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    [Test]&#xA;    public void Print()&#xA;    {&#xA;        Console.WriteLine(browser + ":" + client);&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is something like this even possible?  I'm trying to keep configuration independent of TestRunner and not repeat myself in making lot's of parameters in test cases (which can be data driven initialized). I also tried adding an attribute like <code>[TestFixture(typeof(Browser), typeof(Client))]</code> in the <code>AllClientsTest</code> class.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If there was a data driven way to set up the <code>[TestFixture]</code> attribute, I could load both sets of config in the base class and load the config there and eliminate the need of the superclasses, which are basically solely being used to conveniently run a bunch of tests.</p>&#xA;

<p>I would say do something similar to this</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    while(fgets(buf, LEN, stdin)){&#xA;            z = strtok(buf, ",");&#xA;            *(*(matrix + i)) = atof(z);&#xA;            for(j = 1; j &lt; col; ++j){&#xA;                    z = strtok(NULL, ",");&#xA;                    *(*(matrix + i) + j) = atof(z);&#xA;            }&#xA;            ++i;&#xA;    }&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The only extra thing you would have to take care of is making sure that you strip the brackets off of the first and last element.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Of course, if you don't know the size of the final array, you might need something like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    struct data_t {&#xA;            int nval;               /* current number of values in array */&#xA;            int max;                /* allocated number of vlaues */&#xA;            char **words;           /* the data array */&#xA;    };&#xA;&#xA;    enum {INIT = 1, GROW = 2};&#xA;&#xA;    ...&#xA;    while (fgets(buf, LEN, stdin)) {&#xA;            if (data-&gt;words == NULL)&#xA;                    data-&gt;words = malloc(sizeof(char *));&#xA;            else if (data-&gt;nval &gt; data-&gt;max) {&#xA;                    data-&gt;words = realloc(data-&gt;words, GROW * data-&gt;max *sizeof(char *));&#xA;                    data-&gt;max = GROW * data-&gt;max;&#xA;            }&#xA;            z = strtok(buf, "\n");&#xA;            *(data-&gt;words + i) = malloc(sizeof(char) * (strlen(z) + 1));&#xA;            strcpy(*(data-&gt;words + i), z);&#xA;            i++;&#xA;            data-&gt;nval++;           &#xA;    }&#xA;    data-&gt;nval--;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you combine both of those while loops into a single one, you should be all set. The first one reads in floats, the second one is good for dynamically allocating space on the fly.</p>&#xA;

 i would say do something similar to this . ;. ;  . ;. ; the only extra thing you would have to take care of is making sure that you strip the brackets off of the first and last element. . ;. ; of course, if you don't know the size of the final array, you might need something like this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; if you combine both of those while loops into a single one, you should be all set. the first one reads in floats, the second one is good for dynamically allocating space on the fly. . ;

<p>In ES6 when you write a fat arrow / lamda function the <code>this</code> context is retained (which is why your second example works). </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But in your first example you use <code>function() {}</code> the <code>this</code> context is not retained, so the 'this' inside the function isn't what you're expecting it to be, it's a new context for the function.</p>&#xA;

 in es6 when you write a fat arrow / lamda function the  this  context is retained (which is why your second example works).  . ;. ; but in your first example you use  the  this  context is not retained, so the 'this' inside the function isn't what you're expecting it to be, it's a new context for the function. . ;

in es6 when you write a fat arrow lamda function the this context is retained which is why your second example works
but in your first example you use the this context is not retained so the this inside the function isn t what you re expecting it to be it s a new context for the function



<p>On a server with PHP 5.2.17 running, using any function which makes use of the built in ftp wrapper to upload a file, creates an empty file on the server:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><code>file_put_contents()</code> returns with the accurate number of bytes</li>&#xA;<li><code>copy()</code> also returns with true</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Both create the file, but it's empty.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When trying with <code>ftp_put()</code> from the FTP extension, both in binary and ascii mode, it works well.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>On my workstation with PHP 5.3.10 it somehow works also with the wrapper.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In code:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$source = '/tmp/testfile';&#xA;$target = 'ftp://user:pass@example.com/testfile';&#xA;&#xA;copy($source, $target);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>gives no error or warning, but leaves an empty file on the server.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$source = '/tmp/testfile';&#xA;$target = 'testfile';&#xA;&#xA;$ftp = ftp_connect('example.com');&#xA;ftp_login($ftp, 'user', 'pass');&#xA;ftp_put($ftp, $target, $source, FTP_ASCII);&#xA;ftp_close($ftp);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>works in every respect.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>thanks for any suggestion!</p>&#xA;

 on a server with php 5.2.17 running, using any function which makes use of the built in ftp wrapper to upload a file, creates an empty file on the server: . ;. ; . ;  file_put_contents()  returns with the accurate number of bytes . ;  copy()  also returns with true . ; . ;. ; both create the file, but it's empty. . ;. ; when trying with  ftp_put()  from the ftp extension, both in binary and ascii mode, it works well. . ;. ; on my workstation with php 5.3.10 it somehow works also with the wrapper. . ;. ; in code: . ;. ;  . ;. ; gives no error or warning, but leaves an empty file on the server. . ;. ;  . ;. ; works in every respect. . ;. ; thanks for any suggestion! . ;

<p>You shouldn't use \r\n.  Just use \n, but then open the stream in "text" mode, which than will do the conversion for you.  You may not care about cross-platform, but this is the official way of doing it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>That way, the same code will spit-out \n on unix, \r\n on windows, and \r on mac.</p>&#xA;

 you shouldn't use \r\n.  just use \n, but then open the stream in "text" mode, which than will do the conversion for you.  you may not care about cross-platform, but this is the official way of doing it. . ;. ; that way, the same code will spit-out \n on unix, \r\n on windows, and \r on mac. . ;

you shouldn t use r n
just use n but then open the stream in text mode which than will do the conversion for you
you may not care about cross-platform but this is the official way of doing it
that way the same code will spit-out n on unix r n on windows and r on mac

  . ;




<p>The error tells you that the object window.plugins does not have a "share property".</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Check that you followed the <a href="https://github.com/phonegap/phonegap-plugins/tree/master/Android/Share" rel="nofollow">installation steps</a> of the share plugin, and that you added the loading of the share.js file in your index.html, something the installation steps omits to tell you.</p>&#xA;

 the error tells you that the object window.plugins does not have a "share property". . ;. ; check that you followed the  installation steps  of the share plugin, and that you added the loading of the share.js file in your index.html, something the installation steps omits to tell you. . ;

the error tells you that the object window.plugins does not have a share property
check that you followed the installation steps of the share plugin and that you added the loading of the share.js file in your index.html something the installation steps omits to tell you

i get the same error when i just run cpan so i think it s deeper than just the php extension



<p>There are way too many assumptions built into this design. And those assumptions require you to compare rows between different days to make the assumption in the first place -- not to mention you have to duplicate unchanged rows from one day to the next in order to maintain the unbroken daily entry needed to feed the assumptions. Whew.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Rule 1: don't build assumptions into the design. If something is new, it should be marked, "HEY! I'm new here!" When a change has been made to the data, "OK, something changed. Here it is." and when the issue has finally been closed, "OK, that's it for me. I'm done for."</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>create table Bug_Static( -- Contains one entry for each bug&#xA;    ID     int identity,&#xA;    Opened date not null default sysdate,&#xA;    Closed date [null | not null default date '9999-12-31'],&#xA;    Title  varchar(...),&#xA;    Who    id references Who_Table,&#xA;    &lt;other non-changing data&gt;,&#xA;    constraint PK_Bug_Static primary key( ID )&#xA;);&#xA;create table Bug_Versions( -- Contains changing data, like status&#xA;    ID        int not null,&#xA;    Effective date not null,&#xA;    Status    varchar not null,  -- new,assigned,in work,closed,whatever&#xA;    &lt;other data that may change from day to day&gt;,&#xA;    constraint PK_Bug_Versions primary key( ID, Effective ),&#xA;    constraint FK_Bug_Versions_Static foreign key( ID )&#xA;        references Bug_Static( ID )&#xA;);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now you can select the bugs and the current data (the last change made) on any given day.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>select  s.ID, s.Opened, s.Title, v.Effective, v.Status&#xA;from    Bug_Static   s&#xA;join    Bug_Versions v&#xA;    on  v.ID = s.ID&#xA;    and v.Effective =(&#xA;        select  Max( Effective )&#xA;        from    Bug_Versions&#xA;        where   ID = v.ID&#xA;            and Effective &lt;= sysdate )&#xA;where   s.Closed &lt; sysdate;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The <code>where   s.Closed &lt; sysdate</code> is optional. What that gives you is all the bugs that were closed on the date the query is executed, but not the ones closed before then. That keeps the closed bugs from reappearing over and over again -- unless that's what you want.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Change the <code>sysdate</code> values to a particular date/time and you will get the data as it appeared as of that date and time.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Normally, when a bug is created, a row is entered into both tables. Then only new versions are entered as the status or any other data changes. If nothing changed on a day, nothing is entered. Then when the bug is finally closed, the <code>Closed</code> field of the static table is updated and a <code>closed</code> version is inserted into the version table. I've shown the <code>Closed</code> field with two options, null or with the defined "maximum date" of Dec 31, 9999. You can use either one but I like the max date method. It simplifies the queries.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I would also front both tables with a couple of views which joins the tables. One which shows only the last versions of each bug (Bug_Current) and one which shows every version of every bug (Bug_History). With triggers on Bug_Current, it can be the one used by the app to change the bugs. It would change, for instance, an update of any versioned field to an insert of a new version.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The point is, this is a very flexible design which you can easily show just the data you want, how you want it, as of any time you want.</p>&#xA;

 there are way too many assumptions built into this design. and those assumptions require you to compare rows between different days to make the assumption in the first place -- not to mention you have to duplicate unchanged rows from one day to the next in order to maintain the unbroken daily entry needed to feed the assumptions. whew. . ;. ; rule 1: don't build assumptions into the design. if something is new, it should be marked, "hey! i'm new here!" when a change has been made to the data, "ok, something changed. here it is." and when the issue has finally been closed, "ok, that's it for me. i'm done for." . ;. ;  . ;. ; now you can select the bugs and the current data (the last change made) on any given day. . ;. ;  . ;. ; the  is optional. what that gives you is all the bugs that were closed on the date the query is executed, but not the ones closed before then. that keeps the closed bugs from reappearing over and over again -- unless that's what you want. . ;. ; change the  sysdate  values to a particular date/time and you will get the data as it appeared as of that date and time. . ;. ; normally, when a bug is created, a row is entered into both tables. then only new versions are entered as the status or any other data changes. if nothing changed on a day, nothing is entered. then when the bug is finally closed, the  closed  field of the static table is updated and a  closed  version is inserted into the version table. i've shown the  closed  field with two options, null or with the defined "maximum date" of dec 31, 9999. you can use either one but i like the max date method. it simplifies the queries. . ;. ; i would also front both tables with a couple of views which joins the tables. one which shows only the last versions of each bug (bug_current) and one which shows every version of every bug (bug_history). with triggers on bug_current, it can be the one used by the app to change the bugs. it would change, for instance, an update of any versioned field to an insert of a new version. . ;. ; the point is, this is a very flexible design which you can easily show just the data you want, how you want it, as of any time you want. . ;

here it is. and when the issue has finally been closed ok that s it for me

normally when a bug is created a row is entered into both tables
then only new versions are entered as the status or any other data changes
if nothing changed on a day nothing is entered
then when the bug is finally closed the closed field of the static table is updated and a closed version is inserted into the version table
i ve shown the closed field with two options null or with the defined maximum date of dec 31 9999
you can use either one but i like the max date method
it simplifies the queries
i would also front both tables with a couple of views which joins the tables
one which shows only the last versions of each bug bug_current and one which shows every version of every bug bug_history
with triggers on bug_current it can be the one used by the app to change the bugs
it would change for instance an update of any versioned field to an insert of a new version
the point is this is a very flexible design which you can easily show just the data you want how you want it as of any time you want



<p>As <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/115211/tsf">Tsf</a> pointed out, the problem is due to a <a href="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/jaunty/%2Bsource/linux/%2Bbug/361508" rel="nofollow noreferrer">bug in kernel 2.6.28</a>. &#xA;I leave my original answer, because I think it could be helpful anyway.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>From the ulimit manpage</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p><code>-t   The maximum amount of cpu time</code>&#xA;  <code>in seconds.</code></p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>What counts in respect to ulimit is only <strong>CPU time</strong>.&#xA;Try to start your program like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>time myprogram&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>That will show you how much CPU time it really uses.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My suspicion is that your endless loop contains <code>sleep()</code>&#xA;and sleep time does not contribute to the CPU time of the process.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This gets killed after one second:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>me@host:~$ bash&#xA;me@host:~$ ulimit -t 1; for (( i=1; 1; i++ )); do a=1; done&#xA;Killed&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This seems to run forever (but of course does not):    </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>me@host:~$ bash&#xA;me@host:~$ ulimit -t 1; for (( i=1; 1; i++ )); do sleep 1; done&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Measure CPU time like this...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>me@host:~$  time for (( i=1; i&lt;5; i++ )); do sleep 1; done&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>...and 5 seconds later...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>real        0m4.008s&#xA;user        0m0.000s&#xA;sys         0m0.012s&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>...only 12 ms CPU time used.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I tried it on ubuntu Jaunty Jackalope (9.04)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Linux host 2.6.28-11-generic #42-Ubuntu SMP &#xA;Fri Apr 17 01:57:59 UTC 2009 i686 GNU/Linux&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>For <code>/accounts.ac045b73-8f9c-446f-9cc2-d86b01cea3b7</code> your app is taking as format <code>ac045b73-8f9c-446f-9cc2-d86b01cea3b7</code> but your controller only knows how to handle <code>html</code> and <code>json</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You should verify why <code>/users/sign_in</code> is redirecting to that weird link</p>&#xA;

<p>What you're seeing is just a representation of the instance you've got. Say you have a <code>title</code> attribute on the class <code>Role</code>, you could, instead of <code>logger.debug @role</code> do something like <code>logger.debug @role.title</code>. If you want just doing <code>logger.debug @role</code> to print out something more useful, define a <code>to_s</code> method on <code>Role</code>.</p>&#xA;

 what you're seeing is just a representation of the instance you've got. say you have a  title  attribute on the class  role , you could, instead of  logger.debug @role  do something like  logger.debug @role.title . if you want just doing  logger.debug @role  to print out something more useful, define a  to_s  method on  role . . ;

what you re seeing is just a representation of the instance you ve got
say you have a title attribute on the class role you could instead of logger.debug role do something like logger.debug role.title
if you want just doing logger.debug role to print out something more useful define a to_s method on role



<p>The <code>random1.nextFloat() %.1f</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>is basically using the <code>modulo(remainder)</code> operator to the random float. It is not used for formatting.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>lets look at the <strong>bytecode</strong>: of <code>float g0 = Math.abs(random1.nextFloat() % .1f); // 0.7220096</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>      public static void main(java.lang.String[]);&#xA;    Code:&#xA;       0: new           #16                 // class java/util/Random&#xA;       3: dup&#xA;       4: ldc2_w        #18                 // long 100l&#xA;       7: invokespecial #20                 // Method java/util/Random."&lt;init&gt;":&#xA;(J)V&#xA;      10: astore_1&#xA;      11: aload_1&#xA;      12: invokevirtual #23                 // Method java/util/Random.nextFloat&#xA;:()F&#xA;      15: ldc           #27                 // float 0.1f&#xA;      17: frem&#xA;      18: invokestatic  #28                 // Method java/lang/Math.abs:(F)F&#xA;      21: fstore_2&#xA;      22: return&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>As you can see directly the <strong>0.1f</strong> is a float not a String modifier.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now for <code>System.out.printf("%.2f", 3.1415);</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>  public static void main(java.lang.String[]);&#xA;    Code:&#xA;       0: getstatic     #16                 // Field java/lang/System.out:Ljava/&#xA;io/PrintStream;&#xA;       3: ldc           #22                 // String %.2f&#xA;       5: iconst_1&#xA;       6: anewarray     #3                  // class java/lang/Object&#xA;       9: dup&#xA;      10: iconst_0&#xA;      11: ldc2_w        #24                 // double 3.1415d&#xA;      14: invokestatic  #26                 // Method java/lang/Double.valueOf:(&#xA;D)Ljava/lang/Double;&#xA;      17: aastore&#xA;      18: invokevirtual #32                 // Method java/io/PrintStream.printf&#xA;:(Ljava/lang/String;[Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/io/PrintStream;&#xA;      21: pop&#xA;      22: return&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now you can see that it is now a String modifier(<code>// String %.2f</code>) not a type float</p>&#xA;

 the  random1.nextfloat() %.1f  . ;. ; is basically using the  modulo(remainder)  operator to the random float. it is not used for formatting. . ;. ; lets look at the  bytecode : of  . ;. ;  . ;. ; as you can see directly the  0.1f  is a float not a string modifier. . ;. ; now for  system.out.printf("%.2f", 3.1415);  . ;. ;  . ;. ; now you can see that it is now a string modifier( // string %.2f ) not a type float . ;

as you can see directly the 0.1f is a float not a string modifier
now for system.out.printf .2f 3.1415
now you can see that it is now a string modifier string .2f not a type float



<p>We noticed that queries executed with standard <code>SQL</code> are usually a bit slower and many times by a factor 5. The following query that gets the count of hits is done in 1.8s with legacy <code>SQL</code>, but takes 10s using standard <code>SQL</code>. The queries are: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Legacy SQL:</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>SELECT&#xA;  max_time,&#xA;  COUNT(*) AS cnt&#xA;FROM (&#xA;  SELECT&#xA;    MAX(hits.time) WITHIN RECORD AS max_time,&#xA;  FROM&#xA;    [google_analytics.ga_sessions_20160601])&#xA;GROUP BY 1&#xA;ORDER BY 2 DESC&#xA;LIMIT 100;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Standard SQL:</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>SELECT&#xA;  (SELECT MAX(time) FROM sessions.hits) AS max_time,&#xA;  COUNT(*) AS cnt&#xA;FROM&#xA;  `google_analytics.ga_sessions_20160601` AS sessions&#xA;GROUP BY 1&#xA;ORDER BY 2 DESC&#xA;LIMIT 100;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>We notice that the amount of "compute" in the first stage is usually a bit higher and there's more wait in the final stage. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Other queries like a simple <code>SELECT COUNT(*)</code> also have similar differences.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is it true that standard <code>SQL</code> is consistently slower than legacy <code>SQL</code>?</p>&#xA;

 we noticed that queries executed with standard  sql  are usually a bit slower and many times by a factor 5. the following query that gets the count of hits is done in 1.8s with legacy  sql , but takes 10s using standard  sql . the queries are:  . ;. ;  legacy sql:  . ;. ;  . ;. ;  standard sql:  . ;. ;  . ;. ; we notice that the amount of "compute" in the first stage is usually a bit higher and there's more wait in the final stage.  . ;. ; other queries like a simple  also have similar differences. . ;. ; is it true that standard  sql  is consistently slower than legacy  sql ? . ;

we noticed that queries executed with standard sql are usually a bit slower and many times by a factor 5
the following query that gets the count of hits is done in 1.8s with legacy sql but takes 10s using standard sql
the queries are
legacy sql
standard sql
we notice that the amount of compute in the first stage is usually a bit higher and there s more wait in the final stage
other queries like a simple also have similar differences
is it true that standard sql is consistently slower than legacy sql



<p>As I read Microsoft Jet (Access DB Engine) supports transactions. So you can create a transaction like this (example from <a href="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/database/transactions.aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">CodeProject</a>):</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>      SqlConnection db = new SqlConnection("connstringhere");&#xA;      SqlTransaction transaction;&#xA;&#xA;      db.Open();&#xA;      transaction = db.BeginTransaction();&#xA;      try &#xA;      {&#xA;         new SqlCommand("INSERT INTO TransactionDemo " +&#xA;            "(Text) VALUES ('Row1');", db, transaction)&#xA;            .ExecuteNonQuery();&#xA;         new SqlCommand("INSERT INTO TransactionDemo " +&#xA;            "(Text) VALUES ('Row2');", db, transaction)&#xA;            .ExecuteNonQuery();&#xA;         new SqlCommand("INSERT INTO CrashMeNow VALUES " +&#xA;            "('Die', 'Die', 'Die');", db, transaction)&#xA;            .ExecuteNonQuery();&#xA;         transaction.Commit();&#xA;      } &#xA;      catch (SqlException sqlError) &#xA;      {&#xA;         transaction.Rollback();&#xA;      }&#xA;      db.Close();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>An easier way is (example from <a href="http://www.15seconds.com/Issue/040914.htm" rel="nofollow noreferrer">15 Seconds</a>):</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>bool IsConsistent = false;&#xA;&#xA;using (System.Transactions.TransactionScope ts = new System.Transactions.TransactionScope())&#xA;&#xA;{&#xA;&#xA;      SqlConnection cn = newSqlConnection(CONNECTION_STRING );&#xA;&#xA;      string sql = "DELETE Categories";&#xA;&#xA;      SqlCommand cmd = newSqlCommand(sql, cn);&#xA;&#xA;      cn.Open();&#xA;&#xA;      cmd.ExecuteNonQuery();&#xA;&#xA;      cn.Close();&#xA;&#xA;      //Based on this property the transaction will commit if&#xA;&#xA;      //successful.  If it fails however, this property will&#xA;&#xA;      //not be set and the transaction will not commit.&#xA;&#xA;      ts.Consistent = IsConsistent;&#xA;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You will need MSDTC running on your machine if you are using <em>TransactionScope</em>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Unfortunately <strong>TableAdapter does not expose a connection property</strong>, so you need a workaround. So you need some workaround:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong><em>1) Reflection</em></strong> (example form <a href="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/database/TableAdapter-Transaction.aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">CodeProject</a>)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>conn = new SqlConnection(Properties.Settings.Default.NorthwindConnectionString);&#xA;conn.Open();&#xA;trans = conn.BeginTransaction();&#xA;1. &#xA;public SqlDataAdapter GetAdapter(object tableAdapter)&#xA;{&#xA;    Type tableAdapterType = tableAdapter.GetType();&#xA;    SqlDataAdapter adapter = (SqlDataAdapter)tableAdapterType.GetProperty("Adapter", BindingFlags.Instance | BindingFlags.NonPublic).GetValue(tableAdapter, null);&#xA;        return adapter;&#xA;}&#xA;2.&#xA;adapter.InsertCommand.Connection = trans.Connection;&#xA;adapter.UpdateCommand.Connection = trans.Connection;&#xA;adapter.DeleteCommand.Connection = trans.Connection;&#xA;&#xA;3.&#xA;adapter.InsertCommand.Transaction = trans;&#xA;adapter.UpdateCommand.Transaction = trans;&#xA;adapter.DeleteCommand.Transaction = trans;&#xA;&#xA;4. &#xA;-&#xA;&#xA;5. &#xA;trans.commit();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Reflection can be very slow!</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong><em>2) TransactionScope</em></strong> (example form <a href="http://www.devx.com/codemag/Article/31666/0/page/4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">DevX.com</a>)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    CustomersDataSet.CustomersDataTable customers = new CustomersDataSet.CustomersDataTable();&#xA;   CustomersDataSetTableAdapters.CustomersTableAdapter tblAdap = new &#xA;      CustomersDataSetTableAdapters.CustomersTableAdapter();&#xA;   using (TransactionScope txScope = new TransactionScope())&#xA;   {&#xA;       tblAdap.Fill(customers);&#xA;       customers.Rows[0]["ContactName"] = "Maria Velasquez";&#xA;       tblAdap.Update(customers);&#xA;       txScope.Complete();&#xA;   }&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You will need MSDTC!</p>&#xA;

 as i read microsoft jet (access db engine) supports transactions. so you can create a transaction like this (example from  codeproject ): . ;. ;  . ;. ; an easier way is (example from  15 seconds ): . ;. ;  . ;. ; you will need msdtc running on your machine if you are using  transactionscope . . ;. ; unfortunately  tableadapter does not expose a connection property , so you need a workaround. so you need some workaround: . ;. ;   1) reflection   (example form  codeproject ) . ;. ;  . ;. ; reflection can be very slow! . ;. ;   2) transactionscope   (example form  devx.com ) . ;. ;  . ;. ; you will need msdtc! . ;

as i read microsoft jet access db engine supports transactions
so you can create a transaction like this example from codeproject
an easier way is example from 15 seconds
you will need msdtc running on your machine if you are using transactionscope
unfortunately tableadapter does not expose a connection property so you need a workaround
so you need some workaround
1 reflection example form codeproject
reflection can be very slow
2 transactionscope example form devx.com
you will need msdtc



<p>I think you are looking for this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>final ActionBar bar = getActionBar();&#xA;bar.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This automatically makes the logo you have set look like its being pressed when its clicked. No need to have different images to show state change. Thats a pretty easy way. Though if you are using ActionBarSherlock this won't work, I think. Strictly 4.0 I believe. Check out the doc on <a href="http://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/ActionBar.html#setHomeButtonEnabled%28boolean%29" rel="nofollow">ActionBar</a>.</p>&#xA;

 i think you are looking for this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; this automatically makes the logo you have set look like its being pressed when its clicked. no need to have different images to show state change. thats a pretty easy way. though if you are using actionbarsherlock this won't work, i think. strictly 4.0 i believe. check out the doc on  actionbar . . ;
