<p>First: Strictly speaking, none of the tools quoted here so far are CVS <strong>clients</strong>. They're all "just" GUI frontends on top of the CVSNT commandline client (IIRC only SmartCvs uses a plain CVS client).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So, I'd be interested to hear what particular operations you think are slow in WinCvs. The real bottleneck is usually the CVS protocol itself and that will behave the same regardless of which GUI frontend you use.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Also, what exactly do you mean by "has no merge dialog"?<br>&#xA;WinCvs integrates nicely with WinMerge (also as conflict editor).<br>&#xA;And if you were talking about executing Merge operations you use the Update command which has a "Merge options" tab... </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>For previewing updates there are also several approaches in WinCvs: If you just want to see which files would get updated you can use the Query Update command (<code>cvs -n up</code>) or if you want the details you can simply Diff (using WinMerge) against <code>HEAD</code> (also works on multiple files and folders).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I've had both Tortoise and WinCvs installed for years but usually find that I do not use Tortoise except when I feel guilty about not getting what all the fuss is about... ;)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It's all a matter of taste I guess, especially whether you prefer an integrated solution that tries not to get in the way over a standalone app that forces you to make conscious decisions about your version control tasks.<br>&#xA;WinCvs for me does all I want and more, but then I'm probably considered a power user and a heavily biased one at that as I used to be a cvsgui mailing list moderator and FAQ author and also wrote many of the stock macros.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Then again, there hasn't really been any active development on WinCvs for quuuuiiiite some time... :(</p>&#xA;

 first: strictly speaking, none of the tools quoted here so far are cvs  clients . they're all "just" gui frontends on top of the cvsnt commandline client (iirc only smartcvs uses a plain cvs client). . ;. ; so, i'd be interested to hear what particular operations you think are slow in wincvs. the real bottleneck is usually the cvs protocol itself and that will behave the same regardless of which gui frontend you use. . ;. ; also, what exactly do you mean by "has no merge dialog"? . ;wincvs integrates nicely with winmerge (also as conflict editor). . ;and if you were talking about executing merge operations you use the update command which has a "merge options" tab...  . ;. ; for previewing updates there are also several approaches in wincvs: if you just want to see which files would get updated you can use the query update command ( cvs -n up ) or if you want the details you can simply diff (using winmerge) against  head  (also works on multiple files and folders). . ;. ; i've had both tortoise and wincvs installed for years but usually find that i do not use tortoise except when i feel guilty about not getting what all the fuss is about... ;) . ;. ; it's all a matter of taste i guess, especially whether you prefer an integrated solution that tries not to get in the way over a standalone app that forces you to make conscious decisions about your version control tasks. . ;wincvs for me does all i want and more, but then i'm probably considered a power user and a heavily biased one at that as i used to be a cvsgui mailing list moderator and faq author and also wrote many of the stock macros. . ;. ; then again, there hasn't really been any active development on wincvs for quuuuiiiite some time... :( . ;

first strictly speaking none of the tools quoted here so far are cvs clients
they re all just gui frontends on top of the cvsnt commandline client iirc only smartcvs uses a plain cvs client
so i d be interested to hear what particular operations you think are slow in wincvs
the real bottleneck is usually the cvs protocol itself and that will behave the same regardless of which gui frontend you use
also what exactly do you mean by has no merge dialog
wincvs integrates nicely with winmerge also as conflict editor
and if you were talking about executing merge operations you use the update command which has a merge options tab.
for previewing updates there are also several approaches in wincvs if you just want to see which files would get updated you can use the query update command cvs -n up or if you want the details you can simply diff using winmerge against head also works on multiple files and folders
i ve had both tortoise and wincvs installed for years but usually find that i do not use tortoise except when i feel guilty about not getting what all the fuss is about.

it s all a matter of taste i guess especially whether you prefer an integrated solution that tries not to get in the way over a standalone app that forces you to make conscious decisions about your version control tasks
wincvs for me does all i want and more but then i m probably considered a power user and a heavily biased one at that as i used to be a cvsgui mailing list moderator and faq author and also wrote many of the stock macros
then again there hasn t really been any active development on wincvs for quuuuiiiite some time.




<p>I'm having a problem with my time scale line graph in "real time", which is going out of graph container: See full code in action also here: <a href="https://jsfiddle.net/matjazzeleznik/h482j06d/" rel="nofollow">jsfiddle</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>What I want to achieve:</strong> Currently I have static/dummy data for <code>temp</code> and <code>time</code> which will be later populated via AJAX / JSON. Temp represents temperature and time represents Date in milliseconds which I get with custom <code>setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:50.000Z",0, true)</code> function (I saw that d3 has some time functions, but I didn't manage to dig in yet).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So basically I want to show in 5 second interval on X-axis the temperature with max. 6 ticks on axis, but as described, my LINE is moving out of graph container. <strong>More of the idea you can see in my code below</strong> ("working" example on above link of jsfiddle):</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>   &lt;script src="//d3js.org/d3.v3.min.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;&#xA;   &lt;div id="visualisation"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&#xA;   &lt;script&gt;&#xA;   /*&#xA;    * inputDate: date in ISO format&#xA;    * offset: offset time&#xA;    * isMili: true returns milliseconds, false returns Date object&#xA;    */&#xA;    function setDateTimezone(inputDate, offset, isMili){&#xA;        var d = new Date(inputDate);&#xA;        var utc = d.getTime() + (d.getTimezoneOffset() * 60000);&#xA;        if(isMili){&#xA;            var nd = +new Date(utc + (3600000*offset));&#xA;        }else{&#xA;            var nd = new Date(utc + (3600000*offset));&#xA;        }&#xA;        return nd;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    var data = [&#xA;        {&#xA;            "temp": -5.0,&#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:00.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        },                                                     &#xA;        {                                                      &#xA;            "temp": 18.0,                                      &#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:05.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        },                                                     &#xA;        {                                                      &#xA;            "temp": 22.0,                                      &#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:10.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        },                                                     &#xA;        {                                                      &#xA;            "temp": 17.0,                                      &#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:15.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        },                                                     &#xA;        {                                                      &#xA;            "temp": 26.0,                                      &#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:20.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        },                                                     &#xA;        {                                                     &#xA;            "temp": 20.0,                                      &#xA;            "time": setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:25.000Z",0, true)&#xA;        }&#xA;    ];&#xA;&#xA;    var margin = {top: 20, right: 35, bottom: 30, left: 35};&#xA;    var width = 960 - margin.left - margin.right;&#xA;    var height = 500 - margin.top - margin.bottom;&#xA;&#xA;    var x = d3.time.scale()&#xA;        .domain([setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:00.000Z",0, false), setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:25.000Z",0, false)])&#xA;        .range([0, width]);&#xA;&#xA;    var y = d3.scale.linear()&#xA;        .domain([-10,30])&#xA;        .range([height, 0]);&#xA;&#xA;    var xAxis = d3.svg.axis()&#xA;        .scale(x)&#xA;        .orient("bottom")&#xA;        .tickFormat(d3.time.format("%Hh %Mm %Ss"));&#xA;&#xA;    var yAxis = d3.svg.axis()&#xA;        .scale(y)&#xA;        .orient("left");&#xA;&#xA;    var line = d3.svg.line()&#xA;        //.interpolate('basis') //krivulja smooth&#xA;        .x(function(d) { return x(d.time); })&#xA;        .y(function(d) { return y(d.temp); });&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;    var svg = d3.select("#visualisation").append("svg")&#xA;        .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)&#xA;        .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)&#xA;        .append("g")&#xA;        .attr("transform", "translate(" + margin.left + "," + margin.top + ")");&#xA;&#xA;    var axisX = svg.append("g")&#xA;          .attr("class", "x axis")&#xA;          .attr("transform", "translate(0," + height + ")")&#xA;          .call(xAxis);&#xA;&#xA;    var axisY = svg.append("g")&#xA;          .attr("class", "y axis")&#xA;          .call(yAxis)&#xA;          .append("text")&#xA;          .attr("transform", "rotate(-90)")&#xA;          .attr("y", 6)&#xA;          .attr("dy", ".71em")&#xA;          .style("text-anchor", "end")&#xA;          .text("Temperature �C");&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;    var path = svg.append("g")&#xA;        .attr("clip-path", "url(#clip)")&#xA;        .append("path")&#xA;        .datum(data)&#xA;        .attr("class", "line")&#xA;        .attr("d", line);&#xA;&#xA;    //temporary data that automatically adds in tick() function new temperature and new date for testing&#xA;    var cTemp = 30.0;&#xA;    var cDate = setDateTimezone("2016-02-09T00:00:25.000Z",0, true);&#xA;&#xA;    tick();&#xA;&#xA;    function tick() {&#xA;&#xA;        // push a new data point onto the back&#xA;        cDate +=5000;&#xA;        cTemp++;&#xA;&#xA;        //add new data&#xA;        data.push({&#xA;            "temp": cTemp,                                      &#xA;            "time": cDate&#xA;        });&#xA;&#xA;        //remove first&#xA;        data.shift();&#xA;&#xA;        // update domain&#xA;        x.domain(d3.extent(data, function(d) { return d.time; }));&#xA;        y.domain(d3.extent(data, function(d) { return d.temp; }));&#xA;&#xA;        // Slide x-axis left&#xA;        svg.selectAll(".x.axis")&#xA;            .transition()&#xA;            .duration(5000)&#xA;            .ease('linear')&#xA;            .call(xAxis); &#xA;&#xA;        // Slide y-axis up/down &#xA;        svg.selectAll(".y.axis")&#xA;            .transition()&#xA;            .duration(5000)&#xA;            .ease('linear')&#xA;            .call(yAxis);&#xA;&#xA;        var historyTime = (data[0].time) - 5000;&#xA;        console.log(historyTime);&#xA;&#xA;        // redraw line&#xA;        path&#xA;            .attr("d", line)&#xA;            .attr("transform", null)&#xA;            .transition()&#xA;            .duration(5000)&#xA;            .ease("linear")&#xA;            .attr("transform", "translate(" + x(new Date(historyTime)) + ")")&#xA;            .each("end", tick);&#xA;&#xA;    }&#xA;    &lt;/script&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>and <strong>CSS style</strong> (if needed):</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>svg {&#xA;  font-size: 11px;&#xA;}&#xA;.line {&#xA;  fill: none;&#xA;  stroke: #337ab7;&#xA;  stroke-width: 1.5px;&#xA;}&#xA;.axis path,&#xA;.axis line {&#xA;  fill: none;&#xA;  stroke: #000;&#xA;  shape-rendering: crispEdges;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So any help will be appreciated, what have I missed or what am I doing wrong.. Thanks!</p>&#xA;

<p>What kind of application are you writing? If it's a webscript: keep it open. If it's an executable, pool your connections (if necessary, most of the times a singleton will do).</p>&#xA;

<p>You are trying to relate two completely different requirements.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Even if you got this working. What happens if Customer A has an ealier order deleted, are you going to renumber the all their existing records to keep them consecutive and starting from 1. Now that would be a locking a problem....</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Give the record an identity (or possibly a guid) When you want a count, query for it, if you want row number (never seen the point of that myself), use rowno.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You do not need a an auto increementing order per customer, you don't want one, and without a massive amount of locking can't have one. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Lateral thinking time.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you present</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Order Description Date Due&#xA;1     Staples     26/1/2012&#xA;2     Stapler     1/3/2012&#xA;3     Paper Clips 19/1/2012&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>it  doesn't mean (and in fact shouldn't mean) that the order keys are 1, 2 and 3, they can be anything as long as they fulfill a uniqueness requirement.</p>&#xA;

 you are trying to relate two completely different requirements. . ;. ; even if you got this working. what happens if customer a has an ealier order deleted, are you going to renumber the all their existing records to keep them consecutive and starting from 1. now that would be a locking a problem.... . ;. ; give the record an identity (or possibly a guid) when you want a count, query for it, if you want row number (never seen the point of that myself), use rowno. . ;. ; you do not need a an auto increementing order per customer, you don't want one, and without a massive amount of locking can't have one.  . ;. ; lateral thinking time. . ;. ; if you present . ;. ;  . ;. ; it  doesn't mean (and in fact shouldn't mean) that the order keys are 1, 2 and 3, they can be anything as long as they fulfill a uniqueness requirement. . ;

you are trying to relate two completely different requirements
even if you got this working
what happens if customer a has an ealier order deleted are you going to renumber the all their existing records to keep them consecutive and starting from 1
now that would be a locking a problem..
give the record an identity or possibly a guid when you want a count query for it if you want row number never seen the point of that myself use rowno
you do not need a an auto increementing order per customer you don t want one and without a massive amount of locking can t have one
lateral thinking time
if you present
it doesn t mean and in fact shouldn t mean that the order keys are 1 2 and 3 they can be anything as long as they fulfill a uniqueness requirement



<p>You will have to either pass some data using a query parameter or a fragment identifier.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>See:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_string" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_string</a></li>&#xA;<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fragment_identifier" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fragment_identifier</a></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In either case you will have something present in the url and it will look like:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>http://www.example.com/?page=about&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>or:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>http://www.example.com/#about&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>or - this would be best:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>http://www.example.com/#!/about&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>because it could let you make the website crawlable. See:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="https://developers.google.com/webmasters/ajax-crawling/" rel="nofollow">Making AJAX Applications Crawlable</a></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now after reading your comment to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13138937/passing-javascript-to-a-redirected-web-page/13139006#13139006">the answer by theredled</a> that you <em>"add new content regularly and loading that in embeded iframes is quicker than writing new html every time"</em> I have to ask this: <strong>aren't you using a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_template_system" rel="nofollow">templating system</a> in your website?</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Keep in mind that making AJAX-loaded content and using fragment identifiers to display the right content is not done because the page creation is easier (it isn't) but because the user experience is faster and more responsive. See for example the website for the SoundJS library:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://www.createjs.com/#!/SoundJS" rel="nofollow">http://www.createjs.com/#!/SoundJS</a></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When you click the link to PreloadJS at the top you go to:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://www.createjs.com/#!/PreloadJS" rel="nofollow">http://www.createjs.com/#!/PreloadJS</a></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The content is reloaded, the address bar changes, but the page is actually <strong>not</strong> reloaded. (You can see that it is properly crawlable because it shows in the results if you <a href="https://www.google.com/search?q=preloadjs" rel="nofollow">google for ReloadJS</a>.)</p>&#xA;

 you will have to either pass some data using a query parameter or a fragment identifier. . ;. ; see: . ;. ; . ;     . ;     . ; . ;. ; in either case you will have something present in the url and it will look like: . ;. ;  . ;. ; or: . ;. ;  . ;. ; or - this would be best: . ;. ;  . ;. ; because it could let you make the website crawlable. see: . ;. ; . ;  making ajax applications crawlable  . ; . ;. ; . ;. ; now after reading your comment to  the answer by theredled  that you  "add new content regularly and loading that in embeded iframes is quicker than writing new html every time"  i have to ask this:  aren't you using a  templating system  in your website?  . ;. ; keep in mind that making ajax-loaded content and using fragment identifiers to display the right content is not done because the page creation is easier (it isn't) but because the user experience is faster and more responsive. see for example the website for the soundjs library: . ;. ; . ;     . ; . ;. ; when you click the link to preloadjs at the top you go to: . ;. ; . ;     . ; . ;. ; the content is reloaded, the address bar changes, but the page is actually  not  reloaded. <p>Try to updated textview inside runOnUiThread() :</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>@Override&#xA;public boolean dispatchKeyEvent(KeyEvent event) {&#xA;   switch (event.getKeyCode()) {&#xA;     case KeyEvent.KEYCODE_VOLUME_UP:&#xA;          if (event.getAction() == KeyEvent.ACTION_DOWN) {&#xA;              runOnUiThread(new Runnable() {&#xA;                 @Override&#xA;                 public void run() {&#xA;                   int current =  Integer.parseInt((String)counter_view.getText());&#xA;                   counter_view.setText(current+1+"");        &#xA;                 }&#xA;              });&#xA;          }&#xA;          return true;&#xA;     default:&#xA;          return super.dispatchKeyEvent(event);&#xA;    }&#xA; }&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>Here's your problem.  In your app delegate, you need to call <code>alloc</code> instead of <code>new</code> on <code>UIWindow</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>@window = UIWindow.alloc.initWithFrame(UIScreen.mainScreen.bounds)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>There's something <em>fun</em> with this, both transaction are ready to get the real lock. As soon as one of the transaction will try to perform an insert the lock will be there. If both transactions try it one will get a <strong>deadlock</strong>  and rollback. If only one of them try it it will get a <strong>lock wait timeout</strong>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you detect the lock wait timeout you can rollback and this will allow the next transaction to perform the insert.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So I think you're likely to get a deadlock exception or a timeout exception quite fast and this should <em>save the situation</em>. But talking about perfect 'serializable' situation this is effectively a bad side effect of empty table. The engine cannot be perfect on all cases, at least No double-transaction-inserts can be done..</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I've send yesterday an interesting case of true seriability vs engine seriability, on potsgreSQl documentation, check this example it's <em>funny</em> : <a href="http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.4/static/transaction-iso.html#MVCC-SERIALIZABILITY" rel="nofollow">http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.4/static/transaction-iso.html#MVCC-SERIALIZABILITY</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Update: &#xA;Other interesting resource: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6269471/does-mysql-innodb-implement-true-serializable-isolation/8112871#8112871">Does MySQL/InnoDB implement true serializable isolation?</a> </p>&#xA;

 there's something  fun  with this, both transaction are ready to get the real lock. as soon as one of the transaction will try to perform an insert the lock will be there. if both transactions try it one will get a  deadlock   and rollback. if only one of them try it it will get a  lock wait timeout . . ;. ; if you detect the lock wait timeout you can rollback and this will allow the next transaction to perform the insert. . ;. ; so i think you're likely to get a deadlock exception or a timeout exception quite fast and this should  save the situation . but talking about perfect 'serializable' situation this is effectively a bad side effect of empty table. the engine cannot be perfect on all cases, at least no double-transaction-inserts can be done.. . ;. ; i've send yesterday an interesting case of true seriability vs engine seriability, on potsgresql documentation, check this example it's  funny  :     . ;. ; update: . ;other interesting resource:  does mysql/innodb implement true serializable isolation?   . ;

there s something fun with this both transaction are ready to get the real lock
as soon as one of the transaction will try to perform an insert the lock will be there
if both transactions try it one will get a deadlock and rollback
if only one of them try it it will get a lock wait timeout
if you detect the lock wait timeout you can rollback and this will allow the next transaction to perform the insert
so i think you re likely to get a deadlock exception or a timeout exception quite fast and this should save the situation
but talking about perfect serializable situation this is effectively a bad side effect of empty table
the engine cannot be perfect on all cases at least no double-transaction-inserts can be done
i ve send yesterday an interesting case of true seriability vs engine seriability on potsgresql documentation check this example it s funny
update
other interesting resource does mysql innodb implement true serializable isolation

<p>Based on the fact you are looking for a textbox (a known value) the WinForms application is helping you out filling the propertygrid. Like is true for most of your own controls in WinForms you need to suply the values yourself in WPF this time.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The how part of your question has in basis been answered <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/974598/find-all-controls-in-wpf-window-by-type">here</a> and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12229018/wpf-binding-builder-not-interrogating-nested-icustomtypedescriptor-path-empty">here</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Implementing the ICustomTypeDescriptor seems like a hard thing to do but actually most functions can just return the TypeDescriptor's implementation.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The only interesting one is GetProperties where you can return a new PropertyDescriptorCollection that contains the array returned from control.Children.OfType();</p>&#xA;

 based on the fact you are looking for a textbox (a known value) the winforms application is helping you out filling the propertygrid. like is true for most of your own controls in winforms you need to suply the values yourself in wpf this time. . ;. ; the how part of your question has in basis been answered  here  and  here  . ;. ; implementing the icustomtypedescriptor seems like a hard thing to do but actually most functions can just return the typedescriptor's implementation. . ;. ; the only interesting one is getproperties where you can return a new propertydescriptorcollection that contains the array returned from control.children.oftype(); . ;

based on the fact you are looking for a textbox a known value the winforms application is helping you out filling the propertygrid
like is true for most of your own controls in winforms you need to suply the values yourself in wpf this time
the how part of your question has in basis been answered here and here
implementing the icustomtypedescriptor seems like a hard thing to do but actually most functions can just return the typedescriptor s implementation
the only interesting one is getproperties where you can return a new propertydescriptorcollection that contains the array returned from control.children.oftype

<p>From a C11 draft:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <h2>3.4.3 undefined behavior</h2>&#xA;  &#xA;  <p>behavior, upon use of a nonportable or erroneous program construct or of erroneous data, for which this International Standard <strong>imposes no requirements</strong></p>&#xA;  &#xA;  <p><sub>NOTE Possible undefined behavior ranges from ignoring the situation completely with unpredictable results, to behaving during translation or program execution in a documented manner characteristic of the&#xA;  environment (with or without the issuance of a diagnostic message), <strong>to terminating a translation</strong> or execution (with the issuance of a diagnostic message).</sub></p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Terminating the translation is mentioned as a possible consequence of undefined behavior in the (non-normative) note, so compile-time effects are clearly not intended to be excluded. The normative part certainly allows it - it allows anything. So conforming compiler can terminate the translation if it detects undefined behavior during compilation.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Additionally, in <em>$4 Conformance</em>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>If a ��shall�� or ��shall not�� requirement that appears outside of a constraint or runtime-constraint is violated, the behavior is undefined. Undefined behavior is otherwise indicated in this International Standard by the words ��undefined behavior�� or by the omission of any explicit definition of behavior. There is no difference in emphasis among these three; they all describe ��behavior that is undefined��.</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There is no distinction made either in the normative definition or in the conformance description between "translation time" and "execution time". No difference is made between different "varieties" of undefined behavior.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Additionally, <a href="http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/docs/rr/dr_109.html">Defect Report #109</a> pointed out by <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/34557922/635608">ouah</a> in <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18385020/can-code-that-will-never-be-executed-invoke-undefined-behavior"><em>Can code that will never be executed invoke undefined behavior?</em></a> has this in its response:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>[...] If an expression whose evaluation would result in undefined behavior appears in a context where a constant expression is required, the containing program is not strictly conforming. Furthermore, if every possible execution of a given program would result in undefined behavior, the given program is not strictly conforming. </p>&#xA;  &#xA;  <p>A conforming implementation must not fail to translate a strictly conforming program simply because some possible execution of that program would result in undefined behavior. [...]</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This would indicate that a compiler cannot fail a translation if it cannot statically determine that all paths lead to undefined behavior.</p>&#xA;

 from a c11 draft: . ;. ; . ;   3.4.3 undefined behavior . ;  . ;   behavior, upon use of a nonportable or erroneous program construct or of erroneous data, for which this international standard  imposes no requirements  . ;  . ;    note possible undefined behavior ranges from ignoring the situation completely with unpredictable results, to behaving during translation or program execution in a documented manner characteristic of the. ;  environment (with or without the issuance of a diagnostic message),  to terminating a translation  or execution (with the issuance of a diagnostic message).  . ; . ;. ; terminating the translation is mentioned as a possible consequence of undefined behavior in the (non-normative) note, so compile-time effects are clearly not intended to be excluded. the normative part certainly allows it - it allows anything. so conforming compiler can terminate the translation if it detects undefined behavior during compilation. . ;. ; additionally, in  $4 conformance : . ;. ; . ;   if a ��shall�� or ��shall not�� requirement that appears outside of a constraint or runtime-constraint is violated, the behavior is undefined. undefined behavior is otherwise indicated in this international standard by the words ��undefined behavior�� or by the omission of any explicit definition of behavior. there is no difference in emphasis among these three; they all describe ��behavior that is undefined��. . ; . ;. ; there is no distinction made either in the normative definition or in the conformance description between "translation time" and "execution time". no difference is made between different "varieties" of undefined behavior. . ;. ; additionally,  defect report #109  pointed out by  ouah  in   can code that will never be executed invoke undefined behavior?   has this in its response: . ;. ; . ;   [...] if an expression whose evaluation would result in undefined behavior appears in a context where a constant expression is required, the containing program is not strictly conforming. furthermore, if every possible execution of a given program would result in undefined behavior, the given program is not strictly conforming.  . ;  . ;   a conforming implementation must not fail to translate a strictly conforming program simply because some possible execution of that program would result in undefined behavior. [...] . ; . ;. ; this would indicate that a compiler cannot fail a translation if it cannot statically determine that all paths lead to undefined behavior. . ;

from a c11 draft
3.4.3 undefined behavior
behavior upon use of a nonportable or erroneous program construct or of erroneous data for which this international standard imposes no requirements
note possible undefined behavior ranges from ignoring the situation completely with unpredictable results to behaving during translation or program execution in a documented manner characteristic of the
environment with or without the issuance of a diagnostic message to terminating a translation or execution with the issuance of a diagnostic message
terminating the translation is mentioned as a possible consequence of undefined behavior in the non-normative note so compile-time effects are clearly not intended to be excluded
the normative part certainly allows it - it allows anything
so conforming compiler can terminate the translation if it detects undefined behavior during compilation
additionally in 4 conformance
if a shall or shall not requirement that appears outside of a constraint or runtime-constraint is violated the behavior is undefined
undefined behavior is otherwise indicated in this international standard by the words undefined behavior or by the omission of any explicit definition of behavior
there is no difference in emphasis among these three
they all describe behavior that is undefined
there is no distinction made either in the normative definition or in the conformance description between translation time and execution time
no difference is made between different varieties of undefined behavior
additionally defect report #109 pointed out by ouah in can code that will never be executed invoke undefined behavior
has this in its response
... if an expression whose evaluation would result in undefined behavior appears in a context where a constant expression is required the containing program is not strictly conforming
furthermore if every possible execution of a given program would result in undefined behavior the given program is not strictly conforming
a conforming implementation must not fail to translate a strictly conforming program simply because some possible execution of that program would result in undefined behavior
...
this would indicate that a compiler cannot fail a translation if it cannot statically determine that all paths lead to undefined behavior



<p>If you are looking for simple Caching for Bitmap in Android, The following implementation will cache in both memory and file. when it load it bitmap resource again(identified by image file name), it will try to search the memory and then file cache for the bitmap.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Usage:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>imageLoader.DisplayImage("image_filename_in_resource_folder", imageView);</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>public class ImageLoader {&#xA;        final int stub_id = R.drawable.ic_thumbnail;&#xA;    private Context mContext;&#xA;    MemoryCache memoryCache = new MemoryCache();&#xA;    FileCache fileCache;&#xA;    ExecutorService executorService;&#xA;    private Map&lt;ImageView, String&gt; imageViews = Collections.synchronizedMap(new WeakHashMap&lt;ImageView, String&gt;());&#xA;&#xA;    public ImageLoader(Context context) {&#xA;        fileCache = new FileCache(context);&#xA;        executorService = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(5);&#xA;        this.mContext = context;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public void DisplayImage(String url, ImageView imageView) {&#xA;        imageViews.put(imageView, url);&#xA;        Bitmap bitmap = memoryCache.get(url);&#xA;        if (bitmap != null)&#xA;            imageView.setImageBitmap(bitmap);&#xA;        else {&#xA;            queuePhoto(url, imageView);&#xA;            imageView.setImageResource(stub_id);&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    private void queuePhoto(String url, ImageView imageView) {&#xA;        PhotoToLoad p = new PhotoToLoad(url, imageView);&#xA;        executorService.submit(new PhotosLoader(p));&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;    //decodes image and scales it to reduce memory consumption&#xA;    protected Bitmap decodeFile(File f) {&#xA;        try {&#xA;            //decode image size&#xA;            BitmapFactory.Options o = new BitmapFactory.Options();&#xA;            o.inJustDecodeBounds = true;&#xA;            BitmapFactory.decodeStream(new FileInputStream(f), null, o);&#xA;&#xA;            //Find the correct scale value. It should be the power of 2.&#xA;            final int REQUIRED_SIZE = 150;&#xA;            int width_tmp = o.outWidth, height_tmp = o.outHeight;&#xA;            int scale = 1;&#xA;            while (true) {&#xA;                if (width_tmp / 2 &lt; REQUIRED_SIZE || height_tmp / 2 &lt; REQUIRED_SIZE)&#xA;                    break;&#xA;                width_tmp /= 2;&#xA;                height_tmp /= 2;&#xA;                scale *= 2;&#xA;            }&#xA;&#xA;            //decode with inSampleSize&#xA;            BitmapFactory.Options o2 = new BitmapFactory.Options();&#xA;            o2.inSampleSize = scale;&#xA;            return BitmapFactory.decodeStream(new FileInputStream(f), null, o2);&#xA;        } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {&#xA;        }&#xA;        return null;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    boolean imageViewReused(PhotoToLoad photoToLoad) {&#xA;        String tag = imageViews.get(photoToLoad.imageView);&#xA;        if (tag == null || !tag.equals(photoToLoad.url))&#xA;            return true;&#xA;        return false;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public void clearCache() {&#xA;        memoryCache.clear();&#xA;        fileCache.clear();&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    //Task for the queue&#xA;    private class PhotoToLoad {&#xA;        public String url;&#xA;        public ImageView imageView;&#xA;&#xA;        public PhotoToLoad(String u, ImageView i) {&#xA;            url = u;&#xA;            imageView = i;&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    Bitmap getBitmap(String imageFileName) {&#xA;        File f = fileCache.getFile(imageFileName);&#xA;&#xA;        //from SD cache&#xA;        Bitmap b = decodeFile(f);&#xA;        if (b != null)&#xA;            return b;&#xA;&#xA;        try {&#xA;            Resources resource = mContext.getResources();&#xA;            int imageId = resource.getIdentifier(imageFileName, "drawable", mContext.getPackageName());&#xA;            Bitmap bitmap = null;&#xA;            InputStream is = resource.openRawResource(imageId);&#xA;            OutputStream os = new FileOutputStream(f);&#xA;            IOUtils.copy(is, os);&#xA;            os.close();&#xA;            bitmap = decodeFile(f);&#xA;            return bitmap;&#xA;        } catch (IOException e) {&#xA;            return null;&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;    class PhotosLoader implements Runnable {&#xA;        PhotoToLoad photoToLoad;&#xA;&#xA;        PhotosLoader(PhotoToLoad photoToLoad) {&#xA;            this.photoToLoad = photoToLoad;&#xA;        }&#xA;&#xA;        public void run() {&#xA;            if (imageViewReused(photoToLoad))&#xA;                return;&#xA;            Bitmap bmp = getBitmap(photoToLoad.url);&#xA;            memoryCache.put(photoToLoad.url, bmp);&#xA;            if (imageViewReused(photoToLoad))&#xA;                return;&#xA;            BitmapDisplayer bd = new BitmapDisplayer(bmp, photoToLoad);&#xA;            Activity a = (Activity) photoToLoad.imageView.getContext();&#xA;            a.runOnUiThread(bd);&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    //Used to display bitmap in the UI thread&#xA;    class BitmapDisplayer implements Runnable {&#xA;        Bitmap bitmap;&#xA;        PhotoToLoad photoToLoad;&#xA;&#xA;        public BitmapDisplayer(Bitmap b, PhotoToLoad p) {&#xA;            bitmap = b;&#xA;            photoToLoad = p;&#xA;        }&#xA;&#xA;        public void run() {&#xA;            if (imageViewReused(photoToLoad))&#xA;                return;&#xA;            if (null != bitmap) {&#xA;                photoToLoad.imageView.setImageBitmap(bitmap);&#xA;&#xA;            }&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The class for Memory Cache </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>public class MemoryCache {&#xA;    private HashMap&lt;String, SoftReference&lt;Bitmap&gt;&gt; cache = new HashMap&lt;String, SoftReference&lt;Bitmap&gt;&gt;();&#xA;&#xA;    public Bitmap get(String id) {&#xA;        if (!cache.containsKey(id))&#xA;            return null;&#xA;        SoftReference&lt;Bitmap&gt; ref = cache.get(id);&#xA;        return ref.get();&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public void put(String id, Bitmap bitmap) {&#xA;        cache.put(id, new SoftReference&lt;Bitmap&gt;(bitmap));&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public void clear() {&#xA;        cache.clear();&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The class for File Cache </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>public class FileCache {&#xA;&#xA;    private File cacheDir;&#xA;&#xA;    public FileCache(Context context) {&#xA;        //Find the dir to save cached images&#xA;        if (android.os.Environment.getExternalStorageState().equals(android.os.Environment.MEDIA_MOUNTED))&#xA;            cacheDir = new File(android.os.Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory(), "LazyList");&#xA;        else&#xA;            cacheDir = context.getCacheDir();&#xA;        if (!cacheDir.exists())&#xA;            cacheDir.mkdirs();&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public File getFile(String url) {&#xA;        //Identify images by hashcode. Not a perfect solution.&#xA;        String filename = String.valueOf(url.hashCode());&#xA;&#xA;        //Another possible solution, using cypto hashing functions like md5&#xA;        //String filename = md5(url);&#xA;        File f = new File(cacheDir, filename);&#xA;        return f;&#xA;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public void clear() {&#xA;        File[] files = cacheDir.listFiles();&#xA;        if (files == null)&#xA;            return;&#xA;        for (File f : files)&#xA;            f.delete();&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 if you are looking for simple caching for bitmap in android, the following implementation will cache in both memory and file. when it load it bitmap resource again(identified by image file name), it will try to search the memory and then file cache for the bitmap. . ;. ; usage: . ;. ; imageloader.displayimage("image_filename_in_resource_folder", imageview); . ;. ;  . ;. ; the class for memory cache  . ;. ;  . ;. ; the class for file cache  . ;. ;  . ;

if you are looking for simple caching for bitmap in android the following implementation will cache in both memory and file
when it load it bitmap resource again identified by image file name it will try to search the memory and then file cache for the bitmap
usage
imageloader.displayimage image_filename_in_resource_folder imageview
the class for memory cache
the class for file cache

 how do you split a string   "a:b:c:d" into tokens for parsing in perl? . ;. ; (  using split?) . ;. ; looking for clear, straightforward answer above all (but do add any interesting tidbits of info afterwards). . ;

<p>I'm writing a simple signup page for a small-scale text message service - sort of like a mailing list, but instead of emails, I send text messages to those who sign up with me.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Since its small-scale and I don't want it to get too complicated my current idea is to add users to a mySQL database and then manually add the <em>new</em> users to the texting list (which is managed separate unfortunately).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I was wondering if there's a way to generate a daily email digest of new registrations, so that it would just email me all the new registrations that happened today instead of an email every time someone signs up. Is this possible? Perhaps a CRONTAB?</p>&#xA;

 i'm writing a simple signup page for a small-scale text message service - sort of like a mailing list, but instead of emails, i send text messages to those who sign up with me. . ;. ; since its small-scale and i don't want it to get too complicated my current idea is to add users to a mysql database and then manually add the  new  users to the texting list (which is managed separate unfortunately). . ;. ; i was wondering if there's a way to generate a daily email digest of new registrations, so that it would just email me all the new registrations that happened today instead of an email every time someone signs up. is this possible? perhaps a crontab? . ;

i m writing a simple signup page for a small-scale text message service - sort of like a mailing list but instead of emails i send text messages to those who sign up with me
since its small-scale and i don t want it to get too complicated my current idea is to add users to a mysql database and then manually add the new users to the texting list which is managed separate unfortunately

<p>davenewza's answer suffices if catching the exceptions from tasks application wide is acceptable.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If not then you have to do what you don't want to do (observe the exception in some way).  You have two options:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li>Create a continuation for each task that runs in the <code>OnlyOnFaulted</code> case whose only job is to observe the exception by looking at the <code>Exception</code> property on the task.</li>&#xA;<li><p>In your continuation for ContinueWhenAll, you can split the tasks into those with exceptions and those without:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    Task.Factory.ContinueWhenAll(tasks, ts =&gt;&#xA;    {&#xA;        var lookup = ts.ToLookup(t =&gt; t.Exception != null);&#xA;        var faultedTasks = lookup[true];&#xA;        var nonFaultedTasks = lookup[false];&#xA;    });&#xA;</code></pre></li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;

 davenewza's answer suffices if catching the exceptions from tasks application wide is acceptable. . ;. ; if not then you have to do what you don't want to do (observe the exception in some way).  you have two options: . ;. ; . ; create a continuation for each task that runs in the  onlyonfaulted  case whose only job is to observe the exception by looking at the  exception  property on the task. . ;  in your continuation for continuewhenall, you can split the tasks into those with exceptions and those without: . ;. ;   . ; . ;

davenewza s answer suffices if catching the exceptions from tasks application wide is acceptable
if not then you have to do what you don t want to do observe the exception in some way
you have two options
create a continuation for each task that runs in the onlyonfaulted case whose only job is to observe the exception by looking at the exception property on the task
in your continuation for continuewhenall you can split the tasks into those with exceptions and those without



<p>You don't need XML Path, just a select will do</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>DECLARE @p VARCHAR(200)&#xA;DECLARE @phn TABLE (Phone VARCHAR(25))&#xA;INSERT INTO @phn VALUES('204-721-1532')&#xA;INSERT INTO @phn VALUES('306-922-2058')&#xA;INSERT INTO @phn VALUES('204-728-3852')&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;SET @p = ''&#xA;SELECT @p = @p + phone + ', '  from @phn&#xA;&#xA;SELECT @P&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://sqlfiddle.com/#!6/d41d8/3444" rel="nofollow">DEMO</a> </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>How you want to deal with nulls is up to you. You could </p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>add <code>COALESCE(Phone,'')</code> </li>&#xA;<li>use a case statement <code>CASE WHEN phone is not null THEN phone + ', ' ELSE '' END</code>   </li>&#xA;<li>use a where <code>WHERE phone is not null</code></li>&#xA;<li>or even <code>CONCAT_NULL_YIELDS_NULL = OFF</code> but that's supposed to be deprecated</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 you don't need xml path, just a select will do . ;. ;  . ;. ;  demo   . ;. ; how you want to deal with nulls is up to you. you could  . ;. ; . ; add  coalesce(phone,'')   . ; use a case statement  case when phone is not null then phone + ', ' else '' end     . ; use a where  where phone is not null  . ; or even  but that's supposed to be deprecated . ; . ;

you don t need xml path just a select will do
demo
how you want to deal with nulls is up to you
you could
add coalesce phone
use a case statement case when phone is not null then phone + else end
use a where where phone is not null
or even but that s supposed to be deprecated

<p>In practice: Ignore the <code>declare()</code> directive. Unless you run into code that makes use of it ��which is very rare ?you can safely forget that it ever existed.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>That being said, here's the details. The <code>declare()</code> directive is currently used for two completely unrelated things:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>As <code>declare(encoding=?</code>, for declaring the encoding of a PHP file. (In this sense, it's comparable to a server-side version of <code>&lt;meta charset="?&gt;</code>.)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But don't use this. Under most circumstances, the script encoding doesn't matter. If by some chance it does, the PHP encoding should be set globally (hopefully to "UTF-8") by the <code>zend.script_encoding</code> configuration value. Setting it at the file level is confusing and unnecessary.</p></li>&#xA;<li><p>As <code>declare(ticks=?</code>, for defining the frequency at which tick functions are called. Tick functions are called periodically by the PHP interpreter, and are set up using <a href="http://php.net/manual/en/function.register-tick-function.php"><code>register_tick_function</code></a>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>While some of the comments on php.net suggest using it to implement timeouts on network accesses, that doesn't actually work as expected, as ticks are not fired while the interpreter is blocked in a native function call. It might have some applications in benchmarking, but outside of that it's basically useless. I'd avoid it.</p></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 in practice: ignore the  declare()  directive. unless you run into code that makes use of it ��which is very rare ?you can safely forget that it ever existed. . ;. ; that being said, here's the details. the  declare()  directive is currently used for two completely unrelated things: . ;. ; . ;  as , for declaring the encoding of a php file. (in this sense, it's comparable to a server-side version of .) . ;. ; but don't use this. under most circumstances, the script encoding doesn't matter. if by some chance it does, the php encoding should be set globally (hopefully to "utf-8") by the  zend.script_encoding  configuration value. setting it at the file level is confusing and unnecessary.  . ;  as , for defining the frequency at which tick functions are called. tick functions are called periodically by the php interpreter, and are set up using   register_tick_function  . . ;. ; while some of the comments on php.net suggest using it to implement timeouts on network accesses, that doesn't actually work as expected, as ticks are not fired while the interpreter is blocked in a native function call. it might have some applications in benchmarking, but outside of that it's basically useless. i'd avoid it.  . ; . ;

in practice ignore the declare directive
unless you run into code that makes use of it which is very rare you can safely forget that it ever existed
that being said here s the details
the declare directive is currently used for two completely unrelated things
as for declaring the encoding of a php file
in this sense it s comparable to a server-side version of .
but don t use this
under most circumstances the script encoding doesn t matter
if by some chance it does the php encoding should be set globally hopefully to utf-8 by the zend.script_encoding configuration value
setting it at the file level is confusing and unnecessary
as for defining the frequency at which tick functions are called
tick functions are called periodically by the php interpreter and are set up using register_tick_function
while some of the comments on php.net suggest using it to implement timeouts on network accesses that doesn t actually work as expected as ticks are not fired while the interpreter is blocked in a native function call
it might have some applications in benchmarking but outside of that it s basically useless
i d avoid it



<p>The API won't provide that detailed a breakdown without requesting a permission.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The <code>signed_request</code> will return ranges of </p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>&lt;18</li>&#xA;<li>18-21</li>&#xA;<li>21+</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;&#xA;<p>but for anything more than that, you're going to need <code>user_birthday</code> and/or <code>friends_birthday</code></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>As you've mentioned though, insights gives more detail on ages, but not at a per user level.</p>&#xA;

 the api won't provide that detailed a breakdown without requesting a permission. . ;. ; the  signed_request  will return ranges of  . ;. ; . ;  18 . ; 18-21 . ; 21+ . ; . ;. ; but for anything more than that, you're going to need  user_birthday  and/or  friends_birthday  . ;. ; as you've mentioned though, insights gives more detail on ages, but not at a per user level. . ;

the api won t provide that detailed a breakdown without requesting a permission
the signed_request will return ranges of
18
18-21
21+
but for anything more than that you re going to need user_birthday and or friends_birthday
as you ve mentioned though insights gives more detail on ages but not at a per user level



<p>in linux to copy and paste a file we have cp command</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>cp [OPTION]... SOURCE... DIRECTORY&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But what if I don't want to paste the file to any directory right now and I just want to copy it for future use? <p>From this <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12599889/how-to-get-runtime-access-to-version-number-of-a-running-clojure-application?rq=1">so question</a> I developed the code below.  For now its only purpose (compiled as an uberjar) is to print its version number and exit.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>; core.clj&#xA;&#xA;(ns clojure-test-vnum.core&#xA;   (:gen-class))&#xA;&#xA;(defn implementation-version []&#xA;  (-&gt; (eval 'clojure-test-vnum.core) .getPackage .getImplementationVersion))&#xA;&#xA;(defn -main&#xA;  "I don't do a whole lot ... yet."&#xA;  [&amp; args]&#xA;  ;; work around dangerous default behaviour in Clojure&#xA;  (alter-var-root #'*read-eval* (constantly false))&#xA;&#xA;  (println (implementation-version)))&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;&#xA;  ;project.clj&#xA;&#xA;  (def version "0.1.0-SNAPSHOT")&#xA;&#xA;  (defproject clojure-test-vnum version&#xA;     :manifest {"Implementation-Version" ~version}&#xA;     :description "Test to see if I can get a version number from an uberjar." &#xA;     :url "http://example.com/FIXME"&#xA;     :license {:name "Eclipse Public License"&#xA;     :url "http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html"}&#xA;     :dependencies [[org.clojure/clojure "1.5.1"]]&#xA;     :main clojure-test-vnum.core&#xA;     :aot [clojure-test-vnum.core])&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>While this code compiles fine, I am getting a ClassNotFoundException at runtime. <p>following <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8300546/couchdb-share-functions-across-views-across-design-documents-across-database">this</a> post, I took a look at kanso.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>From this I learnt that people are not afraid to load to the database context complicated modules if they need them, and that encouraged me a lot.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So I tried kanso. It gave me some trouble that implied immaturity - however, it demonstrateds a great potential.&#xA;(mostly compatibiliy view with npm, with node 0.6.x, and some open edge-cases)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So I looked a little deeper.&#xA;I saw it comes with a templates engine of it's own.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But what if I want to reuse templates that are written already by another standard?&#xA;(for example - <a href="http://haml-lang.com/" rel="nofollow">haml</a>, or even better - <a href="http://jade-lang.com/" rel="nofollow">jade</a> that has also a nice text-to-text <a href="http://howtonode.org/haml-for-javascript" rel="nofollow">JS implementation</a>, and a well growing jQuery plugin - same link - see end of document ).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Does anybody here know how coupled the templates engine with the kanso types mechanism, and how simple should it be to use other template engines instead?&#xA;Or, what are the limitations I take upon myself when trying to use my own templates?</p>&#xA;

If it fails, then it just prints out an error message.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>How do I test if <code>true</code> or <code>false</code> so that I can tell if the rename function succeeded, without the error message?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is this the correct way?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>error_reporting(0);&#xA;if(rename('test/test1/','test/test1/test2/test1/')===true){&#xA;   print 'true';&#xA;} else{&#xA;   print 'false';&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>Given that your <code>dates</code> and <code>values</code> properties are mutable lists, you could just read a row at a time (ungrouped), and key a dictionary keyed by name, adding dates and values as you go:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var readings = new Dictionary&lt;string, MeterReadingsChartData&gt;();&#xA;while (reader.Read())&#xA;{&#xA;     string name = reader.GetString(0);&#xA;     DateTime date = reader.GetDateTime(1);&#xA;     double value = reader.GetDouble(2);&#xA;&#xA;     MeterReadingsChartData group;&#xA;     if (!readings.TryGetValue(name, out group))&#xA;     {&#xA;         group = new MeterReadingsChartData {&#xA;             Name = name, &#xA;             Values = new List&lt;double&gt;(),&#xA;             Dates = new List&lt;DateTime&gt;()&#xA;         };&#xA;         readings[name] = group;    &#xA;     }&#xA;     group.Values.Add(value);&#xA;     group.Dates.Add(date);&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>A few notes:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>I've PascalCased your property names to follow .NET naming conventions</li>&#xA;<li>In your LINQ code you've use <code>ToArray</code>, which wouldn't actually compile if your properties are really lists... if your properties are actually arrays, the approach above wouldn't work</li>&#xA;<li>Rather than have two separate lists, you may want to use a single <code>List&lt;Tuple&lt;DateTime, double&gt;&gt;</code> or even create a separate <code>Reading</code> class with just a date and a value.</li>&#xA;<li>You could give your DTO a constructor accepting the name, initialize the list in the constructor, make the list properties read-only, and also create an <code>AddReading(DateTime, double)</code> method to make the calling code cleaner.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 given that your  dates  and  values  properties are mutable lists, you could just read a row at a time (ungrouped), and key a dictionary keyed by name, adding dates and values as you go: . ;. ;  . ;. ; a few notes: . ;. ; . ; i've pascalcased your property names to follow .net naming conventions . ; in your linq code you've use  toarray , which wouldn't actually compile if your properties are really lists... if your properties are actually arrays, the approach above wouldn't work . ; rather than have two separate lists, you may want to use a single  or even create a separate  reading  class with just a date and a value. . ; you could give your dto a constructor accepting the name, initialize the list in the constructor, make the list properties read-only, and also create an  addreading(datetime, double)  method to make the calling code cleaner. . ; . ;

given that your dates and values properties are mutable lists you could just read a row at a time ungrouped and key a dictionary keyed by name adding dates and values as you go
a few notes
i ve pascalcased your property names to follow .net naming conventions
in your linq code you ve use toarray which wouldn t actually compile if your properties are really lists.
if your properties are actually arrays the approach above wouldn t work
rather than have two separate lists you may want to use a single or even create a separate reading class with just a date and a value
you could give your dto a constructor accepting the name initialize the list in the constructor make the list properties read-only and also create an addreading datetime double method to make the calling code cleaner

<p>Error says the exact problem - you are missing correct path to WSDL file. In your case, you have given "db.wsdl" as a path, that appearantly does not exist.&#xA;Confirm that "db.wsdl" is inside your script directory or default include directory (configured in PHP configs).</p>&#xA;

 error says the exact problem - you are missing correct path to wsdl file. in your case, you have given "db.wsdl" as a path, that appearantly does not exist.. ;confirm that "db.wsdl" is inside your script directory or default include directory (configured in php configs). . ;

error says the exact problem - you are missing correct path to wsdl file
in your case you have given db.wsdl as a path that appearantly does not exist
confirm that db.wsdl is inside your script directory or default include directory configured in php configs

String&#xA;&#xA;    let currentUser = Firebase(url: "\(FIREBASE_REF)").childByAppendingPath("users").childByAppendingPath(userID)&#xA;&#xA;    return currentUser!&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>always get error. <p>So if i got it right, you want to fill the FormData object. Because currently it's blank.&#xA;You can use append method:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    var formData = new FormData();&#xA;    var $myField = $('#myField');&#xA;    formData.append('myField', $myField.val());&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>To append file:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    var $fileField = $('#fileField');&#xA;    var myFile = $fileField.get(0).files[0];&#xA;    formData.append('myFile', myFile);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>To append multiplie files you should set the name properly:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    formData.append('myFile[]', myFileFirst);&#xA;    formData.append('myFile[]', myFileSecond);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Check it here: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12989442/uploading-multiple-files-using-formdata">Uploading multiple files using formData()</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Also, you can grab the whole form data through constructor:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    var form = $('form').get(0);&#xA;    var formData = new FormData(form);&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 so if i got it right, you want to fill the formdata object. because currently it's blank.. ;you can use append method: . ;. ;  . ;. ; to append file: . ;. ;  . ;. ; to append multiplie files you should set the name properly: . ;. ;  . ;. ; check it here:  uploading multiple files using formdata()  . ;. ; also, you can grab the whole form data through constructor: . ;. ;  . ;

because currently it s blank
you can use append method
to append file
to append multiplie files you should set the name properly
check it here uploading multiple files using formdata
also you can grab the whole form data through constructor

<p>Django (and relational data bases in general) do not work this way. Even when using an ORM like Django's you don't work with class hierarchies like this.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There are two possible solutions to your problem:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(1) give a "name" attibute the the Animal model, then add entities with names from ['Dog', 'Cat']. This will show the animals' names in the foreign key selection box.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(2) If you <strong>really need to</strong> link your foreign key to different models (which really is not the usual way to use an RDBMS) you should read about <a href="http://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/contenttypes/#id1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Generic Relations</a> in the docs on the contenttypes framework.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My advice is (1), though.</p>&#xA;

 django (and relational data bases in general) do not work this way. even when using an orm like django's you don't work with class hierarchies like this. . ;. ; there are two possible solutions to your problem: . ;. ; (1) give a "name" attibute the the animal model, then add entities with names from ['dog', 'cat']. this will show the animals' names in the foreign key selection box. . ;. ; (2) if you  really need to  link your foreign key to different models (which really is not the usual way to use an rdbms) you should read about  generic relations  in the docs on the contenttypes framework. . ;. ; my advice is (1), though. . ;

django and relational data bases in general do not work this way
even when using an orm like django s you don t work with class hierarchies like this
there are two possible solutions to your problem
1 give a name attibute the the animal model then add entities with names from dog cat
this will show the animals names in the foreign key selection box
2 if you really need to link your foreign key to different models which really is not the usual way to use an rdbms you should read about generic relations in the docs on the contenttypes framework
my advice is 1 though



<p>I have two tables in a dataset:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Schedules&#xA;-------------&#xA;id INT&#xA;schedule_date DATETIME&#xA;service_id INT FOREIGN KEY REFERENCES services(id)&#xA;&#xA;Services&#xA;-------------&#xA;id INT&#xA;name VARCHAR&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I can easily bind a <code>DataGridComboBoxColumn</code> and get the result I want in the following way:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;DataGridComboBoxColumn Header="Service" &#xA;    ItemsSource="{Binding Source={StaticResource schedulesDataSet}, Path=services}"&#xA;    DisplayMemberPath="name"&#xA;    SelectedValueBinding="{Binding Path=service_id}" &#xA;    SelectedValuePath="id" /&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>But how do I do it with a <code>DataGridTemplateColumn</code>? <p>This is the full script to get this working fully, not just after the slide is triggered. As pointed out by Mihai, for some reason I need to use the slid.bs.carousel event not 'slid':</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$('.carousel').carousel({&#xA;    interval: false,&#xA;})&#xA;&#xA;$(document).ready(function () {               // on document ready&#xA;    checkitem();&#xA;});&#xA;&#xA;$('#myCarousel').on('slid.bs.carousel', checkitem);&#xA;&#xA;function checkitem()                        // check function&#xA;{&#xA;    var $this = $('#myCarousel');&#xA;    if ($('.carousel-inner .item:first').hasClass('active')) {&#xA;        $this.children('.left.carousel-control').hide();&#xA;    } else if ($('.carousel-inner .item:last').hasClass('active')) {&#xA;        $this.children('.right.carousel-control').hide();&#xA;    } else {&#xA;        $this.children('.carousel-control').show();&#xA;&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Carousel events documentation - getbootstrap.com/javascript/#carousel-events</p>&#xA;

<p>Your first SQL query is wrong. You have to enclose string values with quotation marks in SQL:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>mysql_query("INSERT INTO likes (`like`) VALUES ('$like')");&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The rest of your PHP part will not perform as you wish either. $id will be a resultset, not a value. You'll have to fetch the row like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$result = mysql_query("SELECT id FROM likes WHERE `like`='$like'");&#xA;$row = mysql_fetch_assoc($result);&#xA;$id = $row['id'];&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Or even better, just replace the second SQL query with a call to <a href="http://php.net/mysql_insert_id" rel="nofollow">mysql_insert_id</a>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$id = mysql_insert_id();&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Still more possibilities for improvement:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li>Don't forget to call <code>exit</code> after you've done a <code>header('Location: ...');</code> call, otherwise you may get unexpected results since the script will continue running.</li>&#xA;<li>Add some error handling of your insert. At least check with an if statement that it succeeded.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 your first sql query is wrong. you have to enclose string values with quotation marks in sql: . ;. ;  . ;. ; the rest of your php part will not perform as you wish either. $id will be a resultset, not a value. you'll have to fetch the row like this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; or even better, just replace the second sql query with a call to  mysql_insert_id : . ;. ;  . ;. ; . ;. ; still more possibilities for improvement: . ;. ; . ; don't forget to call  exit  after you've done a  header('location: ...');  call, otherwise you may get unexpected results since the script will continue running. . ; add some error handling of your insert. at least check with an if statement that it succeeded. . ; . ;

you have to enclose string values with quotation marks in sql
the rest of your php part will not perform as you wish either

you ll have to fetch the row like this
or even better just replace the second sql query with a call to mysql_insert_id
still more possibilities for improvement
don t forget to call exit after you ve done a header location ...

add some error handling of your insert
at least check with an if statement that it succeeded

<p>Does MVC have to be RESTful?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is there a way to make a <code>SOAP</code> service using <code>MVC</code> pattern?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Would the input request actually go into the <code>View</code> first and then into the <code>Controller</code> then the <code>Model</code> eg:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Request -&gt; View -&gt; Controller -&gt; Model&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>but in doing so, that's no longer MVC pattern. (that's right isn't it?)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>How else would we get a typed response using <code>SOAP</code> but still adhere to (or be close to) the <code>MVC</code> pattern. Would MVVM be more suitable pattern to this situation at all instead?</p>&#xA;

(that's right isn't it?) . ;. ; how else would we get a typed response using  soap  but still adhere to (or be close to) the  mvc  pattern. would mvvm be more suitable pattern to this situation at all instead? . ;

<p>I feel really dumb about this one, but I am having a real hard time finding documentation on this. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If I declare a struct like so:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>type BuildNumber = &#xA;    struct&#xA;        val major : int&#xA;        val minor : int&#xA;        val build : int&#xA;        val revision : int&#xA;    end&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Then how do I make a new instance of the <code>BuildNumber</code> type?</p>&#xA;

<p>Use <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener" rel="nofollow">addEventListener</a> to add events, do not set them as an attribute.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>href.addEventListener("click", function() { displayer(uid); });&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The reason why your code did not work is it is adding it as an attribute. When it renders it renders as</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;a href="xxxxxx" onclick="displayer(hEIsrMeIN4M5OoLYTlGUQg9paL73)"&gt;...&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>so when you click on it, it is looking for the variable <code>hEIsrMeIN4M5OoLYTlGUQg9paL73</code>, not a string.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So what do you need to do? Wrap it quotes so it is a string.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>href.setAttribute("onclick","displayer('"+uid+"');");&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now why is this solution bad. Well, first the proper way to add events is with addEventListener. Second if the string inside of uid has a <code>'</code> or a <code>"</code> it will break the event handler. The string may never have those characters in it, but if they do, that is trouble. </p>&#xA;

 use  addeventlistener  to add events, do not set them as an attribute. . ;. ;  . ;. ; the reason why your code did not work is it is adding it as an attribute. when it renders it renders as . ;. ;  . ;. ; so when you click on it, it is looking for the variable  heisrmein4m5oolytlguqg9pal73 , not a string. . ;. ; so what do you need to do? wrap it quotes so it is a string. . ;. ;  . ;. ; now why is this solution bad. well, first the proper way to add events is with addeventlistener. second if the string inside of uid has a  '  or a  "  it will break the event handler. the string may never have those characters in it, but if they do, that is trouble.  . ;

use addeventlistener to add events do not set them as an attribute
the reason why your code did not work is it is adding it as an attribute
when it renders it renders as
so when you click on it it is looking for the variable heisrmein4m5oolytlguqg9pal73 not a string
so what do you need to do
wrap it quotes so it is a string
now why is this solution bad
well first the proper way to add events is with addeventlistener
second if the string inside of uid has a or a it will break the event handler
the string may never have those characters in it but if they do that is trouble



<p>Without more information (a simple code sample that doesn't work as you expect, perhaps) it's tough to give a thorough answer.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>However, here are two pointers which may help you:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><a href="http://twistedmatrix.com/documents/current/api/twisted.pair.html" rel="nofollow">Twisted Pair</a>, a (unfortunately very rudimentary and poorly documented) low-level/raw sockets networking library within Twisted itself, which may be able to implement the packet capture directly in a Twisted-friendly way, or</li>&#xA;<li>The recently-released <a href="http://blog.futurefoundries.com/2013/10/announcing-crochet-v10-use-twisted.html" rel="nofollow">Crochet</a>, which will allow you to manage the background Twisted thread and its interactions with your pcapy-based capture code.</li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

 without more information (a simple code sample that doesn't work as you expect, perhaps) it's tough to give a thorough answer. . ;. ; however, here are two pointers which may help you: . ;. ; . ;  twisted pair , a (unfortunately very rudimentary and poorly documented) low-level/raw sockets networking library within twisted itself, which may be able to implement the packet capture directly in a twisted-friendly way, or . ; the recently-released  crochet , which will allow you to manage the background twisted thread and its interactions with your pcapy-based capture code. . ; . ;

without more information a simple code sample that doesn t work as you expect perhaps it s tough to give a thorough answer
however here are two pointers which may help you
twisted pair a unfortunately very rudimentary and poorly documented low-level raw sockets networking library within twisted itself which may be able to implement the packet capture directly in a twisted-friendly way or
the recently-released crochet which will allow you to manage the background twisted thread and its interactions with your pcapy-based capture code

<p>When the browser gets too small to support alignment, you could use a media query to change the CSS. Something along the lines of: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>.two-col {&#xA;    width:48%;&#xA;    float:left;&#xA;    height:300px;&#xA;    background:#222;&#xA;    margin:0 1% 0 1%;&#xA;}&#xA;@media screen and (max-width: 768px) {&#xA;    .two-col {&#xA;        width:100%;&#xA;        float:none;&#xA;        margin:0 0 15px 0;&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="http://jsfiddle.net/145fbw6k/" rel="nofollow">http://jsfiddle.net/145fbw6k/</a></p>&#xA;

<p>Meta: this feels like a duplicate but I couldn't easily find a match so ...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>SSL/TLS server must have a certificate WITH MATCHING PRIVATE KEY</strong> <em>and</em> chain certs if applicable. A single certificate by itself, or even several certificates, is not sufficient. First do </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code> keytool -list -v -keystore $d.jks&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>and look for a PrivateKey entry (NOT a trustedCert entry). If that is present, look at the cert(s) to determine whether they are the certs you want. If they aren't the desired cert(s), but you do have the desired cert(s) in your .crt and bundle files, then describe the contents of your .crt and especially bundle files and we can work out how to use them to fix the .jks. In particular, there are two formats commonly used for single certs and several for CA "bundles"; if you open the files in an editor like notepad or vi and the first line is <code>-----BEGIN something-----</code> followed by a block of almost all letters and digits then <code>----END same----</code> and maybe more of the same, post the somethings; if they appear to be all random characters and you have a hex dump tool available post the first 64 bytes at least, or if you have OpenSSL or any other ASN.1 (binary) parser available post the results of that. If there is no privatekey at all, this .jks is useless; discard it and continue.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Your <code>.key</code> file sounds likely to contain a private key, but there are dozens of different formats people label <code>.key</code> and it's very unlikely this file is in a usable format. If the key is not more conveniently in the p12, we can come back to this.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Your <code>.p12</code> file almost certainly contains the private key and some cert(s), but not necessarily the desired cert(s). (Technically the PKCS#12 standard allows a file with no private key, but all common tools that create PKCS#12 don't ever do that.) To see what you have now, do </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>keytool -list -v -keystore $d.jks -storetype pkcs12&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If it is what you want, Tomcat (and Java/JSSE) can actually use a pkcs12 directly as a keystore in place of a JKS: just set <code>keystoreFile</code> and <code>keystorePass</code> for it and add <code>keystoreType="pkcs12"</code>. Alternatively you can convert the pkcs12 to JKS with</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore $d.p12 -srcstoretype pkcs12 -destkeystore $d.jks &#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If .p12 contains the privatekey but the wrong cert(s), there are two approaches:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ul>&#xA;<li><p>first convert the pkcs12 to JKS as just above, then fix the certs in the JKS; this is now the same case as my first paragraph: JKS contains privatekey but wrong cert(s)</p></li>&#xA;<li><p>if you have or get OpenSSL, use it to "unpack" the pkcs12 into separate privatekey and cert files, replace the wrong cert files with the right ones, and reconstruct a new pkcs12. This puts you back in my fourth paragraph: pkcs12 with correct cert(s) which you can either use or convert to JKS and use that.</p></li>&#xA;</ul>&#xA;

(technically the pkcs#12 standard allows a file with no private key, but all common tools that create pkcs#12 don't ever do that.) to see what you have now, do  . ;. ;  . ;. ; if it is what you want, tomcat (and java/jsse) can actually use a pkcs12 directly as a keystore in place of a jks: just set  keystorefile  and  keystorepass  for it and add . alternatively you can convert the pkcs12 to jks with . ;. ;  . ;. ; if .p12 contains the privatekey but the wrong cert(s), there are two approaches: . ;. ; . ;  first convert the pkcs12 to jks as just above, then fix the certs in the jks; this is now the same case as my first paragraph: jks contains privatekey but wrong cert(s)  . ;  if you have or get openssl, use it to "unpack" the pkcs12 into separate privatekey and cert files, replace the wrong cert files with the right ones, and reconstruct a new pkcs12. this puts you back in my fourth paragraph: pkcs12 with correct cert(s) which you can either use or convert to jks and use that.  . ; . ;

if .p12 contains the privatekey but the wrong cert s there are two approaches
