<p>First classify into depth classes with cut: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>depth.class &lt;- cut(quakes$depth, c(40, 120, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 680), include.lowest = TRUE)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(Note that your class definitions may need to vary for exactly what you are after and given the details of cut()'s behaviour). </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Find the mean magnitude within each depth.class (assumes no NAs): </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>mean.mag &lt;- tapply(quake$mag, depth.class, mean)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>(Add  na.rm e.g. <code>mean.mag &lt;- tapply(quake$mag, depth.class, mean, na.rm = TRUE)</code> for data sets with missing values where appropriate). </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Plot as a line: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>plot(mean.mag, type = "l", xlab = "magnitude class")&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It's a little extra work to put the class labels on the X-axis, but at that point you might question if a line plot is really appropriate here. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>A quick stab, turn off the axes and then put up the classes directly from the cut factor: </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>plot(mean.mag, type = "l", xlab = "magnitude class", axes = FALSE)&#xA;axis(1, 1:nlevels(depth.class), levels(depth.class))&#xA;axis(2)&#xA;box()&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>I understand the annoyance of the simulator popping up in unit tests.  The best remedy I've been able to find is to do Command + U, followed by Command + H when launching unit tests.  (Control + H hides the simulator after it appears.)  Since it appears nearly instantaneously, this can be an effective way of getting it out of your range of vision.</p>&#xA;

(control + h hides the simulator after it appears.)  since it appears nearly instantaneously, this can be an effective way of getting it out of your range of vision. . ;

<p>Store it under the home directory of the user, who is running the program - in a hidden directory (preceded with dot), for example: .program-data.  The short path to it would be: ~/.program-data and a full path to it depends on the distro of the OS - usually /home/[user name]/.program-data </p>&#xA;

<p>If you're using version 3.5 or higher of the .NET Framework, <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/vstudio/bb397926.aspx" rel="nofollow">LINQ</a> allows you to project operations from the ids stored in <code>arrSelectedItems</code> with <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb548891.aspx" rel="nofollow">Select()</a>, then use <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb336390.aspx" rel="nofollow">Except()</a> to compute the intersection between <code>arrTotalItems</code> and this projection:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>IEnumerable&lt;Operation&gt; totalOps = arrTotalItems.Cast&lt;Operation&gt;();&#xA;yourDataList.DataSource = totalOps.Except(arrSelectedItems.Cast&lt;string&gt;().Select(&#xA;    id =&gt; totalOps.Where(op =&gt; op.ID == id).FirstOrDefault()));&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Note you first have to apply <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb341406.aspx" rel="nofollow"><code>Cast&lt;T&gt;()</code></a> to your <code>ArrayLists</code> in order to obtain instances of <code>IEnumerable&lt;T&gt;</code> that can be used with LINQ methods.</p>&#xA;

<p>It looks like you're trying to create a many-to-many relationship between categories and events. <p>I'm new to Golang and have the following code. I want to be able to fetch questions for different question tags in a new Goroutine. But I'm confused by Sync Wait Groups. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My program seems to be blocking forever, and never reaches the print statement at the bottom. Could somebody point me in the right direction?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I'm trying to build from the fairly straight-forward example in the documentation here <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow">https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup</a>&#xA;    package main</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>import (&#xA;    "fmt"&#xA;    "log"&#xA;    "os"&#xA;    "sync"&#xA;&#xA;    "github.com/PuerkitoBio/goquery"&#xA;)&#xA;&#xA;type question struct {&#xA;    lang, text, url string&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;var url string = "http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/"&#xA;&#xA;func scrapePage(url string) *goquery.Document {&#xA;    doc, err := goquery.NewDocument(url)&#xA;    if err != nil {&#xA;        log.Fatal(err)&#xA;    }&#xA;    return doc&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;func getQuestions(lang string, ch chan&lt;- question, wg sync.WaitGroup) {&#xA;    defer wg.Done()&#xA;    doc := scrapePage(url + lang)&#xA;    doc.Find(".summary .question-hyperlink").Each(func(i int, s *goquery.Selection) {&#xA;        url, _ := s.Attr("href")&#xA;        text := s.Text()&#xA;        ch &lt;- question{lang, text, url}&#xA;    })&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;func main() {&#xA;    tags := os.Args[1:]&#xA;&#xA;    var wg sync.WaitGroup&#xA;    wg.Add(len(tags))&#xA;&#xA;    ch := make(chan question)&#xA;    for index := range tags {&#xA;        lang := tags[index]&#xA;        go getQuestions(lang, ch, wg)&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    go func() {&#xA;        for i := range ch {&#xA;            fmt.Println(i)&#xA;        }&#xA;    }()&#xA;&#xA;    wg.Wait()&#xA;&#xA;    // Never reached :(&#xA;    fmt.Println("Done")&#xA;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>update</strong>&#xA;Still no luck with the following after someone pointed out I was incorrectly passing a copy of the wg.WaitGroup </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>package main&#xA;&#xA;import (&#xA;    "fmt"&#xA;    "log"&#xA;    "os"&#xA;    "sync"&#xA;&#xA;    "github.com/PuerkitoBio/goquery"&#xA;)&#xA;&#xA;type question struct {&#xA;    lang, text, url string&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;var url string = "http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/"&#xA;&#xA;var wg sync.WaitGroup&#xA;&#xA;func main() {&#xA;    tags := os.Args[1:]&#xA;&#xA;    wg.Add(len(tags))&#xA;&#xA;    ch := make(chan question)&#xA;    for index := range tags {&#xA;        lang := tags[index]&#xA;        go getQuestions(lang, ch)&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    wg.Wait()&#xA;    fmt.Println("After WAIT")&#xA;    close(ch)&#xA;&#xA;    for i := range ch {&#xA;        fmt.Println(&lt;-ch, i)&#xA;    }&#xA;    ch = nil&#xA;    fmt.Println("Done")&#xA;&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;func getQuestions(lang string, ch chan question) {&#xA;    doc := scrapePage(url + lang)&#xA;    doc.Find(".summary .question-hyperlink").Each(func(i int, s *goquery.Selection) {&#xA;        url, _ := s.Attr("href")&#xA;        text := s.Text()&#xA;        ch &lt;- question{lang, text, url}&#xA;    })&#xA;    wg.Done()&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;func scrapePage(url string) *goquery.Document {&#xA;    doc, err := goquery.NewDocument(url)&#xA;    if err != nil {&#xA;        log.Fatal(err)&#xA;    }&#xA;    return doc&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>It will make the biggest difference for the first request before the worker process is warmed up. Users will the HTML markup right away instead of staring at a blank page before all the modules load. But the same approach can be done by having the default application page to be a static HTML file that redirects to an MVC route using the refresh meta tag.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>As mentioned, there will be a slight performance advantage otherwise. It is up to you to decide whether it is worth the missing functionality.</p>&#xA;

 it will make the biggest difference for the first request before the worker process is warmed up. users will the html markup right away instead of staring at a blank page before all the modules load. but the same approach can be done by having the default application page to be a static html file that redirects to an mvc route using the refresh meta tag. . ;. ; as mentioned, there will be a slight performance advantage otherwise. it is up to you to decide whether it is worth the missing functionality. . ;

it will make the biggest difference for the first request before the worker process is warmed up
users will the html markup right away instead of staring at a blank page before all the modules load
but the same approach can be done by having the default application page to be a static html file that redirects to an mvc route using the refresh meta tag
as mentioned there will be a slight performance advantage otherwise
it is up to you to decide whether it is worth the missing functionality



<p>You can use following regex</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>((?:\w+-)+\w+)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li><code>(?:\w+-)+</code>: Matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol followed by a hyphen. <code>(?:</code> will make it not add in captured group</li>&#xA;<li><code>\w+</code>: Matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol</li>&#xA;<li><code>()</code>: Capturing group. The matches can be accessed by using <code>$n</code> where <code>n</code> is the capturing group number. <code>$1</code> in this case as it is first capturing group.</li>&#xA;<li><code>g</code>: Use global flag to get all possible matches</li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Demo</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><div class="snippet" data-lang="js" data-hide="false">&#xD;&#xA;<div class="snippet-code">&#xD;&#xA;<pre class="snippet-code-js lang-js prettyprint-override"><code>var string = "time to eval-u-ate Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. A sed, illum veritatis aut recusandae tempora possimus iure totam distinctio necessitatibus temporibus labore-numquam-dignissimos, officiis velit error-dolores nostrum ipsam.";&#xD;&#xA;var matches = string.match(/((?:\w+-)+\w+)/g);&#xD;&#xA;&#xD;&#xA;document.write('&lt;pre&gt;' + JSON.stringify(matches, 0, 4) + '&lt;/pre&gt;');</code></pre>&#xD;&#xA;</div>&#xD;&#xA;</div>&#xD;&#xA;</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="https://regex101.com/r/jN7iT1/2" rel="nofollow"><strong>Regex101 Demo</strong></a></p>&#xA;

 you can use following regex . ;. ;  . ;. ; . ;  (?:\w+-)+ : matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol followed by a hyphen.  (?:  will make it not add in captured group . ;  \w+ : matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol . ;  () : capturing group. the matches can be accessed by using  where  n  is the capturing group number.  in this case as it is first capturing group. . ;  g : use global flag to get all possible matches . ; . ;. ;  demo  . ;. ;  &#xd;. ; &#xd;. ;  &#xd;. ; &#xd;. ; &#xd;. ; . ;. ;   regex101 demo   . ;

you can use following regex

w+- + matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol followed by a hyphen

will make it not add in captured group
w+ matches one or more alphanumeric characters including underscore symbol
capturing group
the matches can be accessed by using where n is the capturing group number
in this case as it is first capturing group
g use global flag to get all possible matches
demo
regex101 demo



<p>I also encountered this issue, the fix is to upgrade your <code>sympy</code> version. I found that 0.7.6 reproduces the error, but 0.7.7 has it fixed. At the moment this isn't available via <code>pip</code>, but can be found via the <a href="https://github.com/sympy/sympy">github repo</a>.</p>&#xA;

 i also encountered this issue, the fix is to upgrade your  sympy  version. i found that 0.7.6 reproduces the error, but 0.7.7 has it fixed. at the moment this isn't available via  pip , but can be found via the  github repo . . ;

<p>Start by simplifying your query as you do not need to do multiple <code>DISTINCT</code>s (it's only necessary in the final output) and you are selecting many columns that you are not outputting. You are also joining some tables which you are not selecting from and if there are multiple matching rows for these then it may generate duplicate rows - using something like <code>EXISTS</code> can eliminate these joins.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>WITH MARC_SEL AS (&#xA;  SELECT A.SOURCE,&#xA;         MARA.MATNR,&#xA;         MARC.WERKS&#xA;  FROM   XXX_MAIN.XXX_XSAP A&#xA;         INNER JOIN XXX_MAIN.XXX_SAP_MARA MARA&#xA;         ON (    A.MATNR = MARA.MATNR &#xA;             AND A.MTART = MARA.MTART )&#xA;         INNER JOIN XXX_MAIN.XXX_SAP_MARC MARC&#xA;         ON (    MARA.MATNR = MARC.MATNR )&#xA;  WHERE  EXISTS( SELECT 'X'&#xA;                 FROM   XXX_MAIN.XXX_MP_WERKS_PLANT_XREF PX&#xA;                 WHERE  PX.LEGACY_PLANT = MARC.WERKS&#xA;                 AND    PX.SOURCE = 'SP' )&#xA;  AND    EXISTS( SELECT 'X'&#xA;                 FROM   XXX_MAIN.XXX_SAP_MBEW MBEW&#xA;                 WHERE  MARC.MATNR = MBEW.MATNR&#xA;                 AND    MARC.WERKS = MBEW.BWKEY )&#xA;  AND    A.SOURCE  = 'SP'&#xA;)&#xA;, MVKE_SEL AS (&#xA;  SELECT  NVL(MX_VKORG.SAP_DE_VAL,'/') VKORG,&#xA;          NVL(SUBSTR(MX_VKORG.SAP_DE,6,2),'/') VTWEG,&#xA;          MX_VKORG.DESC4 &#xA;  FROM    XXX_MAIN.XXX_MP_VKVT_XREF MX_VKORG&#xA;  WHERE   EXISTS ( SELECT 'X'&#xA;                   FROM   XXX_MAIN.XXX_SAP_MVKE MVKE&#xA;                   WHERE  MX_VKORG.SOURCE_DE_VAL = MVKE.VKORG&#xA;                   AND    SUBSTR(MX_VKORG.SAP_DE,6,2) = MVKE.VTWEG )&#xA;  AND     MX_VKORG.SOURCE_TBL = 'SP'&#xA;  AND     MX_VKORG.SOURCE_DE = 'MVKE'&#xA;  AND     SUBSTR(MX_VKORG.SAP_DE,1,5)= 'VKORG'&#xA;  AND     MX_VKORG.DESC2 IS NULL&#xA;)&#xA;SELECT DISTINCT&#xA;       MARC.SOURCE,&#xA;       MARC.MATNR,&#xA;       MVKE.VKORG,&#xA;       MARC.WERKS,&#xA;       MVKE.VTWEG  &#xA;FROM   MARC_SEL MARC&#xA;       INNER JOIN MVKE_SEL MVKE&#xA;       ON (    MARC.MATNR = MVKE.MATNR   &#xA;           AND MARC.WERKS = MVKE.DESC4 )&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 start by simplifying your query as you do not need to do multiple  distinct s (it's only necessary in the final output) and you are selecting many columns that you are not outputting. you are also joining some tables which you are not selecting from and if there are multiple matching rows for these then it may generate duplicate rows - using something like  exists  can eliminate these joins. . ;. ; like this: . ;. ;  . ;

<p>I was able to figure out what I needed to do after some messing around, I just needed to do multiple queries.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var craftList = from craft in db.GetTable&lt;Craft&gt;()&#xA;                join craftProduct in db.GetTable&lt;CraftProduct&gt;() on craft.ID equals craftProduct.CraftID into&#xA;                    craftProducts&#xA;                join craftMaterial in db.GetTable&lt;CraftMaterial&gt;() on craft.ID equals craftMaterial.CraftID into&#xA;                    craftMaterials&#xA;                select new&#xA;                {&#xA;                    Craft = craft,&#xA;                    CraftProducts = from craftProduct in craftProducts&#xA;                                    join item in db.GetTable&lt;Item&gt;() on craftProduct.ItemID equals item.ID&#xA;                                    select CraftProduct.Build(craftProduct, item),&#xA;                    CraftMaterials = from craftMaterial in craftMaterials&#xA;                                     join item in db.GetTable&lt;Item&gt;() on craftMaterial.ItemID equals item.ID&#xA;                                     select CraftMaterial.Build(craftMaterial, item)&#xA;                };&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>Try using a <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/awt/image/PixelGrabber.html" rel="nofollow"><code>PixelGrabber</code></a>. It accepts an <code>Image</code> or <code>ImageProducer</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Here's an example adapted from the documentation:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code> public void handleSinglePixel(int x, int y, int pixel) {&#xA;      int alpha = (pixel &gt;&gt; 24) &amp; 0xff;&#xA;      int red   = (pixel &gt;&gt; 16) &amp; 0xff;&#xA;      int green = (pixel &gt;&gt;  8) &amp; 0xff;&#xA;      int blue  = (pixel      ) &amp; 0xff;&#xA;      // Deal with the pixel as necessary...&#xA; }&#xA;&#xA; public void handlePixels(Image img, int x, int y, int w, int h) {&#xA;      int[] pixels = new int[w * h];&#xA;      PixelGrabber pg = new PixelGrabber(img, x, y, w, h, pixels, 0, w);&#xA;      try {&#xA;          pg.grabPixels();&#xA;      } catch (InterruptedException e) {&#xA;          System.err.println("interrupted waiting for pixels!");&#xA;          return;&#xA;      }&#xA;      if ((pg.getStatus() &amp; ImageObserver.ABORT) != 0) {&#xA;          System.err.println("image fetch aborted or errored");&#xA;          return;&#xA;      }&#xA;      for (int j = 0; j &lt; h; j++) {&#xA;          for (int i = 0; i &lt; w; i++) {&#xA;              handleSinglePixel(x+i, y+j, pixels[j * w + i]);&#xA;          }&#xA;      }&#xA; }&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In your case, you would have:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>public void handleSinglePixel(int x, int y, int pixel) {&#xA;      int target = 0xFFABCDEF; // or whatever&#xA;      if (pixel == target) {&#xA;          myArrayList.add(new java.awt.Point(x, y));&#xA;      }&#xA; }&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p><strike>Well, based on what I can find in the <a href="https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/manipulation.js#L440-482" rel="nofollow">source code of jQuery</a>, the engine itself will not create tags (or fragments) that are not "properly seated". Even when passing a string, jQuery recognizes that the header has already been supplied and will not generate it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>After all, when jQuery is passed a string of HTML, it's actually calling <code>document.createElement</code> and creating an array list of those elements.</strike></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>EDIT</strong>: After a little more investigation, it looks like it's the browser actually limiting element creation, not jQuery. Either way, you're left with absent tags. Which brings me to my same conclusion below.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>As much as I don't like it, may be time for regex/string manipulation.</p>&#xA;

  well, based on what i can find in the  source code of jquery , the engine itself will not create tags (or fragments) that are not "properly seated". even when passing a string, jquery recognizes that the header has already been supplied and will not generate it. . ;. ; after all, when jquery is passed a string of html, it's actually calling  document.createelement  and creating an array list of those elements.  . ;. ;  edit : after a little more investigation, it looks like it's the browser actually limiting element creation, not jquery. either way, you're left with absent tags. which brings me to my same conclusion below. . ;. ; as much as i don't like it, may be time for regex/string manipulation. . ;

well based on what i can find in the source code of jquery the engine itself will not create tags or fragments that are not properly seated
even when passing a string jquery recognizes that the header has already been supplied and will not generate it
after all when jquery is passed a string of html it s actually calling document.createelement and creating an array list of those elements

either way you re left with absent tags
which brings me to my same conclusion below

<p>I am trying to implement a Codeigniter based app on Android via phonegap, all works well apart from logging in/out with tank auth. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When the login form is submitted it keeps showing a dialog saying 'Complete action using' with an option to select a browser, rather than staying in the app window. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you select a browser it opens a browser window with the login page again, but if the app is re-started it is logged in.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>How can I stop this jump to the browser so the app is seamless? I think it is when tank auth is writing/destroying the cookie info. This is running in an /android subfolder off the root as the client host does not support subdomains.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This is the tank auth login code. Note that 'home' is the default controller.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>EDIT: I actually don't need to accept the 'Complete action using' dialog - if I just click back and restart the app it is logged in! Wish I knew what was making that dialog pop up, I'm actually pretty impressed that phonegap has managed to wrap around a full CI site with authentication at all...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>function login()&#xA;    {&#xA;        if ($this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;is_logged_in()) {                                 // logged in&#xA;            redirect('home');&#xA;        } elseif ($this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;is_logged_in(FALSE)) {                      // logged in, not activated&#xA;            redirect('/auth/send_again/');&#xA;        } else {&#xA;            $data['login_by_username'] = ($this-&gt;config-&gt;item('login_by_username', 'tank_auth') AND&#xA;                    $this-&gt;config-&gt;item('use_username', 'tank_auth'));&#xA;            $data['login_by_email'] = $this-&gt;config-&gt;item('login_by_email', 'tank_auth');&#xA;&#xA;            $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_rules('login', 'Login', 'trim|required|xss_clean');&#xA;            $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_rules('password', 'Password', 'trim|required|xss_clean');&#xA;            $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_rules('remember', 'Remember me', 'integer');&#xA;&#xA;            // Get login for counting attempts to login&#xA;            if ($this-&gt;config-&gt;item('login_count_attempts', 'tank_auth') AND&#xA;                    ($login = $this-&gt;input-&gt;post('login'))) {&#xA;                $login = $this-&gt;security-&gt;xss_clean($login);&#xA;            } else {&#xA;                $login = '';&#xA;            }&#xA;&#xA;            $data['use_recaptcha'] = $this-&gt;config-&gt;item('use_recaptcha', 'tank_auth');&#xA;            if ($this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;is_max_login_attempts_exceeded($login)) {&#xA;                if ($data['use_recaptcha'])&#xA;                    $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_rules('recaptcha_response_field', 'Confirmation Code', 'trim|xss_clean|required|callback__check_recaptcha');&#xA;                else&#xA;                    $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_rules('captcha', 'Confirmation Code', 'trim|xss_clean|required|callback__check_captcha');&#xA;            }&#xA;            $data['errors'] = array();&#xA;&#xA;            if ($this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;run()) {                                // validation ok&#xA;                if ($this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;login(&#xA;                        $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_value('login'),&#xA;                        $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_value('password'),&#xA;                        $this-&gt;form_validation-&gt;set_value('remember'),&#xA;                        $data['login_by_username'],&#xA;                        $data['login_by_email'])) { // success&#xA;&#xA;                        $this-&gt;load-&gt;library('user_agent');&#xA;                        redirect('home'); // Adds this onto /android/&#xA;&#xA;                } else {&#xA;                    $errors = $this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;get_error_message();&#xA;                    if (isset($errors['banned'])) {                             // banned user&#xA;                        $this-&gt;_show_message($this-&gt;lang-&gt;line('auth_message_banned').' '.$errors['banned']);&#xA;&#xA;                    } elseif (isset($errors['not_activated'])) {                // not activated user&#xA;                        redirect('/auth/send_again/');&#xA;&#xA;                    } else {                                                    // fail&#xA;                        foreach ($errors as $k =&gt; $v)   $data['errors'][$k] = $this-&gt;lang-&gt;line($v);&#xA;                    }&#xA;            }&#xA;        }&#xA;        $data['show_captcha'] = FALSE;&#xA;        if ($this-&gt;tank_auth-&gt;is_max_login_attempts_exceeded($login)) {&#xA;            $data['show_captcha'] = TRUE;&#xA;            if ($data['use_recaptcha']) {&#xA;                $data['recaptcha_html'] = $this-&gt;_create_recaptcha();&#xA;            } else {&#xA;                $data['captcha_html'] = $this-&gt;_create_captcha();&#xA;            }&#xA;        }&#xA;        $this-&gt;load-&gt;view('view_header');&#xA;        $this-&gt;load-&gt;view('auth/login_form', $data);&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>KO doesn't care if your view model has multiple functions.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Your problem exists somewhere else, perhaps inside the functions themselves. Check your browser's output for javascript errors. Also try making those functions empty functions, just to verify it's a javascript error inside those functions.</p>&#xA;

<p><code>NOPASS</code> in the configuration on your target machine is the solution. Continue reading at <a href="http://maestric.com/doc/unix/ubuntu_sudo_without_password" rel="nofollow">http://maestric.com/doc/unix/ubuntu_sudo_without_password</a></p>&#xA;

<p>The change event will only fire on the radio you "checked", and if you use attr('checked', 'checked') to set/unset the radio, it will not fire the change event.</p>&#xA;

 the change event will only fire on the radio you "checked", and if you use attr('checked', 'checked') to set/unset the radio, it will not fire the change event. . ;

the change event will only fire on the radio you checked and if you use attr checked checked to set unset the radio it will not fire the change event



<p>I would suggest doing something like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>1) Assuming this is something you are developing yourself, make sure your data structure is all in order first. Since I dislike relatively code-hostile identifiers, I'd have the tables as so -</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><em>Properties</em> - <code>PropertyID</code> (AutoNumber, primary key), <code>HouseNumberOrName</code>, <code>Street</code>, etc.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><em>Viewings</em> - <code>ViewingID</code> (AutoNumber, primary key), <code>PropertyID</code> (Number/Long Integer), <code>ViewingDate</code>, etc.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In the Relationships view, <code>Properties.PropertyID</code> would then be set up to point to <code>Viewings.PropertyID</code> in a one-to-many relation.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>2) Your actual query I would then break into two, the first to compile the data and the second to format it for display. The first would go like this, saved as <code>ViewingCounts</code>...</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>SELECT Properties.PropertyID, Count(Viewings.PropertyID) As ViewingCount&#xA;FROM Properties LEFT JOIN Viewings ON Properties.PropertyID = Viewings.PropertyID&#xA;GROUP BY Properties.PropertyID;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>... and the second like this, saved as <code>ViewingCountsForDisplay</code>:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>SELECT Properties.*, IIf(ViewingCount = 0, 'No viewings', ViewingCount) AS Viewings&#xA;FROM Properties INNER JOIN ViewingCounts ON Properties.PropertyID = ViewingCounts.PropertyID&#xA;ORDER BY Properties.PropertyID;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 i would suggest doing something like this: . ;. ; 1) assuming this is something you are developing yourself, make sure your data structure is all in order first. since i dislike relatively code-hostile identifiers, i'd have the tables as so - . ;. ;  properties  -  propertyid  (autonumber, primary key),  housenumberorname ,  street , etc. . ;. ;  viewings  -  viewingid  (autonumber, primary key),  propertyid  (number/long integer),  viewingdate , etc. . ;. ; in the relationships view,  properties.propertyid  would then be set up to point to  viewings.propertyid  in a one-to-many relation. . ;. ; 2) your actual query i would then break into two, the first to compile the data and the second to format it for display. the first would go like this, saved as  viewingcounts ... . ;. ;  . ;. ; ... and the second like this, saved as  viewingcountsfordisplay : . ;. ;  . ;

since i dislike relatively code-hostile identifiers i d have the tables as so -
properties - propertyid autonumber primary key housenumberorname street etc
viewings - viewingid autonumber primary key propertyid number long integer viewingdate etc
in the relationships view properties.propertyid would then be set up to point to viewings.propertyid in a one-to-many relation
2 your actual query i would then break into two the first to compile the data and the second to format it for display

<p>In order for you to retrieve all of your products without input parameters, you can use the Reports API to request an inventory report or active listings reports or any of the report types here: <a href="http://docs.developer.amazonservices.com/en_US/reports/Reports_ReportType.html#ReportTypeCategories__ListingsReports" rel="nofollow">http://docs.developer.amazonservices.com/en_US/reports/Reports_ReportType.html#ReportTypeCategories__ListingsReports</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You can call the Reports API just like the Products API, but there are extra steps involved.  You first request the report using the <code>RequestReport</code> operation, then you'll get back a <code>GeneratedReportId</code>.  Take that Id and call the <code>GetReport</code> operation and you'll get back the report once it's available.  If you need more than a report, but need to work with the data in some other way, you can just write a routine in whatever language you're using to parse out the data in memory.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Have you seen the client libraries?  They do most of the work already, just plug in your keys. <a href="https://developer.amazonservices.com/gp/mws/api.html/188-4747010-1589520?ie=UTF8&amp;group=bde&amp;section=reports&amp;version=latest" rel="nofollow">https://developer.amazonservices.com/gp/mws/api.html/188-4747010-1589520?ie=UTF8&amp;group=bde&amp;section=reports&amp;version=latest</a></p>&#xA;

 in order for you to retrieve all of your products without input parameters, you can use the reports api to request an inventory report or active listings reports or any of the report types here:     . ;. ; you can call the reports api just like the products api, but there are extra steps involved.  you first request the report using the  requestreport  operation, then you'll get back a  generatedreportid .  take that id and call the  getreport  operation and you'll get back the report once it's available.  if you need more than a report, but need to work with the data in some other way, you can just write a routine in whatever language you're using to parse out the data in memory. . ;. ; have you seen the client libraries?  they do most of the work already, just plug in your keys.    group=bde section=reports version=latest  . ;

<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>How to make sure that function calls from AA.so go to CC.a version 1 and calls from BB.so go to CC.a version 2?</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You can't: making sure involves building <code>AA.so</code> and <code>BB.so</code> in a self-contained manner, and you can't rebuild them.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>What you can do is <em>try</em> to make this work by loading the libraries at runtime using <code>dlopen("AA.so", RTLD_LAZY|RTLD_LOCAL)</code> and same for <code>BB.so</code>, and <em>hope</em> that the libraries don't step on each other.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In theory that (<code>RTLD_LOCAL</code> is the important bit) should work. In practice, there are many ways this could still break; you are venturing into very dangerous ground.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It could also work today, but break when either shared library is updated. You <em>really</em> should work with your library suppliers to get out of this multiple incompatible version mess.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Update:</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>I believe shared objects do not depend on anything else and in that sense they are self-contained.</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The "not depend on anything else" part is necessary, but not sufficient.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Normally, a shared library <em>exports</em> all global functions and data linked into it. Suppose <code>CC.a</code> contains a global function <code>foo</code>; suppose that versions 1 and 2 of this function are not compatible, and that <code>foo</code> is <em>exported</em> from both <code>AA.so</code> and <code>BB.so</code>. In that case, whichever library is loaded first will win. If <code>AA.so</code> is loaded first, then a call from <code>BB.so</code> to <code>foo</code> will get resolved to the definition inside <code>AA.so</code>, and your program will either corrupt its state, or crash.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>To verify that this is not the case, you should run <code>nm -D</code> on <code>AA.so</code> and <code>BB.so</code>, and confirm that the intersection of symbols exported from these libraries is empty. If it is not empty, you have to verify that the two definitions are compatible.</p>&#xA;

 . ;   how to make sure that function calls from aa.so go to cc.a version 1 and calls from bb.so go to cc.a version 2? . ; . ;. ; you can't: making sure involves building  aa.so  and  bb.so  in a self-contained manner, and you can't rebuild them. . ;. ; what you can do is  try  to make this work by loading the libraries at runtime using  dlopen("aa.so", rtld_lazy|rtld_local)  and same for  bb.so , and  hope  that the libraries don't step on each other. . ;. ; in theory that ( rtld_local  is the important bit) should work. in practice, there are many ways this could still break; you are venturing into very dangerous ground. . ;. ; it could also work today, but break when either shared library is updated. you  really  should work with your library suppliers to get out of this multiple incompatible version mess. . ;. ;  update:  . ;. ; . ;   i believe shared objects do not depend on anything else and in that sense they are self-contained. . ; . ;. ; the "not depend on anything else" part is necessary, but not sufficient. . ;. ; normally, a shared library  exports  all global functions and data linked into it. suppose  cc.a  contains a global function  foo ; suppose that versions 1 and 2 of this function are not compatible, and that  foo  is  exported  from both  aa.so  and  bb.so . in that case, whichever library is loaded first will win. if  aa.so  is loaded first, then a call from  bb.so  to  foo  will get resolved to the definition inside  aa.so , and your program will either corrupt its state, or crash. . ;. ; to verify that this is not the case, you should run  nm -d  on  aa.so  and  bb.so , and confirm that the intersection of symbols exported from these libraries is empty. if it is not empty, you have to verify that the two definitions are compatible. . ;

how to make sure that function calls from aa.so go to cc.a version 1 and calls from bb.so go to cc.a version 2
you can t making sure involves building aa.so and bb.so in a self-contained manner and you can t rebuild them
what you can do is try to make this work by loading the libraries at runtime using dlopen aa.so rtld_lazy|rtld_local and same for bb.so and hope that the libraries don t step on each other
in theory that rtld_local is the important bit should work
in practice there are many ways this could still break
you are venturing into very dangerous ground
it could also work today but break when either shared library is updated
you really should work with your library suppliers to get out of this multiple incompatible version mess
update
i believe shared objects do not depend on anything else and in that sense they are self-contained
the not depend on anything else part is necessary but not sufficient
normally a shared library exports all global functions and data linked into it
suppose cc.a contains a global function foo
suppose that versions 1 and 2 of this function are not compatible and that foo is exported from both aa.so and bb.so
in that case whichever library is loaded first will win
if aa.so is loaded first then a call from bb.so to foo will get resolved to the definition inside aa.so and your program will either corrupt its state or crash
to verify that this is not the case you should run nm -d on aa.so and bb.so and confirm that the intersection of symbols exported from these libraries is empty
if it is not empty you have to verify that the two definitions are compatible



<p>My solution was to delve into the attachment_fu plugin folder (vendor/plugins) and edit the rmagick_processor.rb file. First I renamed resize_image to resize_image_internal, then added:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>  def resize_image(img, size)  &#xA;    # resize_image take size in a number of formats, we just want  &#xA;    # Strings in the form of "square: WxH"  &#xA;    if (size.is_a?(String) &amp;&amp; size =~ /^square: (\d*)x(\d*)/i) ||  &#xA;        (size.is_a?(Array) &amp;&amp; size.first.is_a?(String) &amp;&amp;  &#xA;          size.first =~ /^square: (\d*)x(\d*)/i)  &#xA;        iw, ih = img.columns, img.rows&#xA;        aspect = iw.to_f / ih.to_f&#xA;        if aspect &gt; 1&#xA;            shave_off = (iw - ih) / 2&#xA;            img.shave!(shave_off, 0)&#xA;        else&#xA;            shave_off = (ih-iw) / 2&#xA;            img.shave!(0, shave_off)&#xA;        end&#xA;        resize_image_internal(img, "#{$1}x#{$2}!")&#xA;    else  &#xA;      resize_image_internal(img, size) # Otherwise let attachment_fu handle it  &#xA;    end  &#xA;  end&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I can now use 'square: 100x100' as my geometry string. Note that the above code assumes the required output is square.</p>&#xA;

<p><code>dplyr</code> isn't suitable for such operations, try <code>data.table</code>s <code>foverlaps</code> functions instead</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>library(data.table)&#xA;class(LargeDF) &lt;- "data.frame" ## Removing all the dplyr classes&#xA;setDT(LargeDF)[, `:=`(left = timestamp, right = timestamp)] # creating min and max boundaries in the large table&#xA;setkey(setDT(Categories)) # keying by all columns (necessary for `foverlaps` to work)&#xA;LargeDF[, left_boundary := foverlaps(LargeDF, Categories)$left][] # Creating left_boundary &#xA;#    ts  timestamp   signal       left      right left_boundary&#xA;# 1:  A 0.46771516 10.72175 0.46771516 0.46771516             0&#xA;# 2:  A 0.58841492 10.35459 0.58841492 0.58841492             0&#xA;# 3:  A 1.14494484 10.50301 1.14494484 1.14494484             1&#xA;# 4:  A 1.18298225 10.82431 1.18298225 1.18298225             1&#xA;# 5:  A 1.69822678 10.04780 1.69822678 1.69822678             1&#xA;# 6:  A 1.83189609 10.75001 1.83189609 1.83189609             1&#xA;# 7:  A 1.90947475 10.94715 1.90947475 1.90947475             1&#xA;# 8:  A 2.73305266 10.14449 2.73305266 2.73305266             2&#xA;# 9:  A 3.02371968 10.17724 3.02371968 3.02371968             3&#xA;# ...&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>You almost have it right.  </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>(ydim,xdim,dummy) = img.shape&#xA;# make an open grid of x,y&#xA;y,x = np.ogrid[0:ydim, 0:xdim, ]&#xA;y -= ydim/2                 # centered at the origin&#xA;x -= xdim/2&#xA;# now make a mask&#xA;mask = x**2+y**2 &lt;= radius**2 # start with 2d&#xA;img[mask,:] = color&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>the extra ",:" at the end of the assignment lets you assign the color throughout the 3 channels in one shot.</p>&#xA;

<p>I'm ok with using Cygwin or MinGW, but I need to end up with 64-bit code, not 32-bit.  This is because I will be calling the DLL from 64-bit managed C#.  I can't seem to find and good references for setting up those tools to create 64-bit binaries.  Also, it would be nice if the GCC was version 4, not version 3 as came with my Cygwin install.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>An alternative would be some form of interprocess communication.  I will research that, but what I laid out above is what I really want.</p>&#xA;

<p>When your app first loaded as a tab, you can read the "<a href="http://developers.facebook.com/docs/authentication/signed_request/" rel="nofollow">signed_request</a>" and compose the redirect_uri with it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>var encodeURI = encodeURIComponent("http://myapp.com?pageid=123");&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>and redirect your user to somewhere like</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>https://www.facebook.com/dialog/oauth?&#xA;     client_id=YOUR_APP_ID&amp;redirect_uri=encodeURI&amp;response_type=token&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>In fact, you could create <code>Directive</code> to append default option and handle two-way binding:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>import {Directive, ElementRef, Input, OnInit, Output, EventEmitter, HostListener} from 'angular2/core';&#xA;&#xA;/**&#xA; * &lt;select [ngSelect]="'select number...'" [(ngSelectModel)]="model" &gt;&#xA; *    &lt;option *ngFor="#item of ['1', '2', '3']" [value]="item"&gt;{{item}}&lt;/option&gt;&#xA; * &lt;/select&gt;&#xA; */&#xA;@Directive({&#xA;    selector: '[ngSelect]'&#xA;})&#xA;export class DefaultOption implements OnInit&#xA;{&#xA;    private _el:HTMLSelectElement;&#xA;&#xA;    @Input('ngSelect')&#xA;    private defaultText:string;&#xA;&#xA;    @Output()&#xA;    private ngSelectModelChange:EventEmitter = new EventEmitter();&#xA;&#xA;    private _ngSelectModel:any;&#xA;&#xA;    constructor(el:ElementRef)&#xA;    {&#xA;        this._el = el.nativeElement;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    @Input()&#xA;    public get ngSelectModel():any&#xA;    {&#xA;        return this._ngSelectModel;&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public set ngSelectModel(value:any)&#xA;    {&#xA;        this._ngSelectModel = value;&#xA;        if (this.ngSelectModel !== undefined)&#xA;        {&#xA;            this._el.value = this.ngSelectModel;&#xA;        }&#xA;        else&#xA;        {&#xA;            this._el.value = '';&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    protected ngOnInit():any&#xA;    {&#xA;        var element:HTMLOptionElement = document.createElement('option');&#xA;        element.text = this.defaultText;&#xA;        element.value = '';&#xA;        this._el.insertBefore(element, this._el.firstChild);&#xA;&#xA;        //delayed execution&#xA;        setTimeout(()=&gt;&#xA;        {&#xA;            if (this.ngSelectModel !== undefined)&#xA;            {&#xA;                this._el.value = this.ngSelectModel;&#xA;            }&#xA;            else&#xA;            {&#xA;                this._el.value = '';&#xA;            }&#xA;        }, 0);&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    @HostListener('change', ['$event.target.value'])&#xA;    private onInput(value):void&#xA;    {&#xA;        if(value !== '')&#xA;        {&#xA;            this.ngSelectModelChange.emit(value);&#xA;        }&#xA;        else&#xA;        {&#xA;            this.ngSelectModelChange.emit(undefined);&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 in fact, you could create  directive  to append default option and handle two-way binding: . ;. ;  . ;

in fact you could create directive to append default option and handle two-way binding

<h2>Use object keys</h2>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When you get an object from the DB and then manipulate it and after some time (after context has been discarded) want to save it back, use primary key values.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>create a new instance of the correct entity object and set key properties (and those that have to be changes) and then save it against newly created context.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>Or</strong> you can get it again before saving. It's a waste of resources but it is the most bullet proof way of doing it. Eve though I wouldn't recomend it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<h2>Using ASP? Go with MVC then</h2>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I highly recomend you rather switch to Asp.net MVC if you're used to ASP, then you'll be better and easier at home in MVC.</p>&#xA;

 use object keys . ;. ; when you get an object from the db and then manipulate it and after some time (after context has been discarded) want to save it back, use primary key values. . ;. ; create a new instance of the correct entity object and set key properties (and those that have to be changes) and then save it against newly created context. . ;. ;  or  you can get it again before saving. it's a waste of resources but it is the most bullet proof way of doing it. eve though i wouldn't recomend it. . ;. ; using asp? go with mvc then . ;. ; i highly recomend you rather switch to asp.net mvc if you're used to asp, then you'll be better and easier at home in mvc. . ;

use object keys
when you get an object from the db and then manipulate it and after some time after context has been discarded want to save it back use primary key values
create a new instance of the correct entity object and set key properties and those that have to be changes and then save it against newly created context
or you can get it again before saving
it s a waste of resources but it is the most bullet proof way of doing it
eve though i wouldn t recomend it
using asp
go with mvc then
i highly recomend you rather switch to asp.net mvc if you re used to asp then you ll be better and easier at home in mvc



<p>My goal is to display a .NET Windows forms message box from a pure C++ native Windows API-level program (not managed C++ or C++/CLI).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>That is, for learning purposes I want to implementing the C# code shown in the comment below, in pure C++:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>/*&#xA;    // C# code that this C++ program should implement:&#xA;    using System.Windows.Forms;&#xA;&#xA;    namespace hello&#xA;    {&#xA;        class Startup&#xA;        {&#xA;            static void Main( string[] args )&#xA;            {&#xA;                MessageBox.Show(&#xA;                    "Hello, world!",&#xA;                    ".NET app:",&#xA;                    MessageBoxButtons.OK,&#xA;                    MessageBoxIcon.Information&#xA;                    );&#xA;            }&#xA;        }&#xA;    }&#xA;*/&#xA;&#xA;#include &lt;stdexcept&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;string&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;iostream&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;         // EXIT_SUCCESS, EXIT_FAILURE&#xA;&#xA;#undef  UNICODE&#xA;#define UNICODE&#xA;#include &lt;windows.h&gt;&#xA;&#xA;#include &lt;Mscoree.h&gt;&#xA;#include &lt;comdef.h&gt;&#xA;_COM_SMARTPTR_TYPEDEF( ICorRuntimeHost, IID_ICorRuntimeHost );      // ICorRuntimeHostPtr&#xA;&#xA;// #import is an MS extension, generates a header file. Will be replaced with #include.&#xA;#import "C:\\WINDOWS\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework\\v1.1.4322\\mscorlib.tlb" \&#xA;    raw_interfaces_only rename( "ReportEvent", "reportEvent" )&#xA;typedef mscorlib::_AppDomainPtr     AppDomainPtr;&#xA;typedef mscorlib::_ObjectHandlePtr  ObjectHandlePtr;&#xA;typedef mscorlib::_AssemblyPtr      AssemblyPtr;&#xA;&#xA;bool throwX( std::string const&amp; s ) { throw std::runtime_error( s ); }&#xA;&#xA;template&lt; class Predicate &gt;&#xA;struct Is: Predicate&#xA;{};&#xA;&#xA;template&lt; class Type, class Predicate &gt;&#xA;bool operator&gt;&gt;( Type const&amp; v, Is&lt; Predicate &gt; const&amp; check )&#xA;{&#xA;    return check( v );&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;struct HrSuccess&#xA;{&#xA;    bool operator()( HRESULT hr ) const&#xA;    {&#xA;        ::SetLastError( hr );&#xA;        return SUCCEEDED( hr );&#xA;    }&#xA;};&#xA;&#xA;void cppMain()&#xA;{&#xA;    ICorRuntimeHostPtr  pCorRuntimeHost;&#xA;    CorBindToRuntimeEx(&#xA;        L"v1.1.4322",           // LPWSTR pwszVersion,  // RELEVANT .NET VERSION.&#xA;        L"wks",                 // LPWSTR pwszBuildFlavor, // "wks" or "svr"&#xA;        0,                      // DWORD flags,&#xA;        CLSID_CorRuntimeHost,   // REFCLSID rclsid,&#xA;        IID_ICorRuntimeHost,    // REFIID riid,&#xA;        reinterpret_cast&lt;void**&gt;( &amp;pCorRuntimeHost )&#xA;        )&#xA;        &gt;&gt; Is&lt; HrSuccess &gt;()&#xA;        || throwX( "CorBindToRuntimeEx failed" );&#xA;&#xA;    pCorRuntimeHost-&gt;Start()    // Without this GetDefaultDomain fails.&#xA;        &gt;&gt; Is&lt; HrSuccess &gt;()&#xA;        || throwX( "CorRuntimeHost::Start failed" );&#xA;&#xA;    IUnknownPtr     pAppDomainIUnknown;&#xA;    pCorRuntimeHost-&gt;GetDefaultDomain( &amp;pAppDomainIUnknown )&#xA;        &gt;&gt; Is&lt; HrSuccess &gt;()&#xA;        || throwX( "CorRuntimeHost::GetDefaultDomain failed" );&#xA;&#xA;    AppDomainPtr    pAppDomain  = pAppDomainIUnknown;&#xA;    (pAppDomain != 0)&#xA;        || throwX( "Obtaining _AppDomain interface failed" );&#xA;&#xA;    // This fails because Load requires a fully qualified assembly name.&#xA;    // I want to load the assembly given only name below + relevant .NET version.&#xA;    AssemblyPtr     pFormsAssembly;&#xA;    pAppDomain-&gt;Load_2( _bstr_t( "System.Windows.Forms" ), &amp;pFormsAssembly )&#xA;        &gt;&gt; Is&lt; HrSuccess &gt;()&#xA;        || throwX( "Loading System.Windows.Forms assembly failed" );    &#xA;&#xA;    // ... more code here, not yet written.&#xA;}&#xA;&#xA;int main()&#xA;{&#xA;    try&#xA;    {&#xA;        cppMain();&#xA;        return EXIT_SUCCESS;&#xA;    }&#xA;    catch( std::exception const&amp; x )&#xA;    {&#xA;        std::cerr &lt;&lt; "!" &lt;&lt; x.what() &lt;&lt; std::endl;&#xA;    }&#xA;    return EXIT_FAILURE;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The plan is, having loaded the assembly, proceed to <code>MessageBox</code> class and invoke <code>Show</code>. But this just may be a mistaken way of doing it. So I'm equally happy with an answer showing how to do that without finding the fully qualified name of the assembly (of course, without hardcoding that fully qualified name!).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The <code>gacutil</code> utility is evidently able to find fully qualified names:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre>&#xA;C:\test> gacutil /l System.Windows.Forms&#xA;Microsoft (R) .NET Global Assembly Cache Utility. <p>I've set the click event on a parent row of a div to select the child checkbox when clicked. The problem is that when you click the actual checkbox, the parent click overrides the checkbox click event, which prevents the checkbox from checking.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I'm not sure how to solve this problem other than changing the entire solution so that the checkbox is no longer a child of the parent div? The table rows are dynamically generated, so there is a variable number.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>function SelectChildCheckBox(element) {&#xA;    var $chkBox = $(element).children().find("input:checkbox:first"),&#xA;        value = $chkBox.attr("checked");&#xA;    $chkBox.attr("checked", !value);&#xA;&#xA;    if (!$chkBox.attr("checked")) {&#xA;        $(element).attr("class", "dg_row");&#xA;    }&#xA;    else {&#xA;        $(element).attr("class", "dg_row_sel");&#xA;    }&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I've created an example here: <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/6sStE/3/" rel="nofollow">http://jsfiddle.net/6sStE/3/</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>UPDATE:</strong></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>I was able to resolve this problem by adding an onmouseup event to the actual checkbox. This is probably not the most elegant solution, so please feel free to post alternatives if you have one. Thanks!</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>$.OnMouseUpChkBoxEvent = function(element) {&#xA;    var $chkBox = $(element)&#xA;    value = $chkBox.attr("checked");&#xA;    $chkBox.attr("checked", !value);&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 i've set the click event on a parent row of a div to select the child checkbox when clicked. the problem is that when you click the actual checkbox, the parent click overrides the checkbox click event, which prevents the checkbox from checking. . ;. ; i'm not sure how to solve this problem other than changing the entire solution so that the checkbox is no longer a child of the parent div? the table rows are dynamically generated, so there is a variable number. . ;. ;  . ;. ; i've created an example here:     . ;. ;  update:  . ;. ; i was able to resolve this problem by adding an onmouseup event to the actual checkbox. this is probably not the most elegant solution, so please feel free to post alternatives if you have one. thanks! . ;. ;  . ;

i ve set the click event on a parent row of a div to select the child checkbox when clicked
the problem is that when you click the actual checkbox the parent click overrides the checkbox click event which prevents the checkbox from checking
i m not sure how to solve this problem other than changing the entire solution so that the checkbox is no longer a child of the parent div
the table rows are dynamically generated so there is a variable number
i ve created an example here
update

<p>Your server:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<blockquote>&#xA;<pre><code>var Server = http.createServer(function(request, response) {&#xA;  var filename = path.join(__dirname, 'index.html');&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>?is configured to ignore everything in the request and always return the contents of <code>index.html</code>.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So when the browser requests <code>/assets/bundle.js</code> it is given <code>index.html</code> (and errors because that isn't JavaScript).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You need to pay attention to the path and serve up appropriate content, with the appropriate content type. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>This would probably be best done by finding a static file serving module (Google turns up <a href="https://github.com/cloudhead/node-static">node-static</a>) for Node (or replacing Node with something like Lighttpd or Apache HTTPD). </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you want to serve up dynamic content as well as static content, then <a href="http://expressjs.com/">Express</a> is a popular choice (and has <a href="http://expressjs.com/starter/static-files.html">support for static files</a>).</p>&#xA;

 your server: . ;. ; . ;  . ; . ;. ; ?is configured to ignore everything in the request and always return the contents of  index.html . . ;. ; so when the browser requests  /assets/bundle.js  it is given  index.html  (and errors because that isn't javascript). . ;. ; you need to pay attention to the path and serve up appropriate content, with the appropriate content type.  . ;. ; this would probably be best done by finding a static file serving module (google turns up  node-static ) for node (or replacing node with something like lighttpd or apache httpd).  . ;. ; if you want to serve up dynamic content as well as static content, then  express  is a popular choice (and has  support for static files ). . ;

your server
is configured to ignore everything in the request and always return the contents of index.html
so when the browser requests assets bundle.js it is given index.html and errors because that isn t javascript
you need to pay attention to the path and serve up appropriate content with the appropriate content type
this would probably be best done by finding a static file serving module google turns up node-static for node or replacing node with something like lighttpd or apache httpd
if you want to serve up dynamic content as well as static content then express is a popular choice and has support for static files



<p>[Expanding comments into a summary answer]</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Your code is unknowingly relying on undefined behaviour (the order of destruction of translation unit objects) and there is no real workaround other than to explicitly control and lifespan of objects containing CUDA runtime API calls in their destructor, or simply avoid using those API calls in destructors altogether.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>In detail:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The CUDA front end invoked by nvcc silently adds a lot of boilerplate code and translation unit scope objects which perform CUDA context setup and teardown. That code <em>must</em> run before any API calls which rely on a CUDA context can be executed. If your object containing CUDA runtime API calls in its destructor invokes the API after the context is torn down, your code may fail with a runtime error. C++ doesn't define the   order of destruction when objects fall out of scope. Your singleton or object needs to be destroyed before the CUDA context is torn down, but there is no guarantee that will occur. This is effectively undefined behaviour.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>You can see a more complete example of what happens (in the context of a kernel launch) in this <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/24883665/681865">answer</a>.</p>&#xA;

 [expanding comments into a summary answer] . ;. ; your code is unknowingly relying on undefined behaviour (the order of destruction of translation unit objects) and there is no real workaround other than to explicitly control and lifespan of objects containing cuda runtime api calls in their destructor, or simply avoid using those api calls in destructors altogether. . ;. ; in detail: . ;. ; the cuda front end invoked by nvcc silently adds a lot of boilerplate code and translation unit scope objects which perform cuda context setup and teardown. that code  must  run before any api calls which rely on a cuda context can be executed. if your object containing cuda runtime api calls in its destructor invokes the api after the context is torn down, your code may fail with a runtime error. c++ doesn't define the   order of destruction when objects fall out of scope. your singleton or object needs to be destroyed before the cuda context is torn down, but there is no guarantee that will occur. this is effectively undefined behaviour. . ;. ; you can see a more complete example of what happens (in the context of a kernel launch) in this  answer . . ;

expanding comments into a summary answer
your code is unknowingly relying on undefined behaviour the order of destruction of translation unit objects and there is no real workaround other than to explicitly control and lifespan of objects containing cuda runtime api calls in their destructor or simply avoid using those api calls in destructors altogether
in detail
the cuda front end invoked by nvcc silently adds a lot of boilerplate code and translation unit scope objects which perform cuda context setup and teardown
that code must run before any api calls which rely on a cuda context can be executed
if your object containing cuda runtime api calls in its destructor invokes the api after the context is torn down your code may fail with a runtime error
c++ doesn t define the order of destruction when objects fall out of scope
your singleton or object needs to be destroyed before the cuda context is torn down but there is no guarantee that will occur
this is effectively undefined behaviour
you can see a more complete example of what happens in the context of a kernel launch in this answer



<blockquote>&#xA;  <p>Can a chained store be define using Ext.define statement?</p>&#xA;</blockquote>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Definitely yes. But the <a href="http://docs.sencha.com/extjs/6.2.0/classic/Ext.data.ChainedStore.html#cfg-source" rel="nofollow noreferrer">source config</a> of the <a href="http://docs.sencha.com/extjs/6.2.0/classic/Ext.data.ChainedStore.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">chained store</a> says that it should be either a store instance or the id of an existing store.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>So the code would look like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>Ext.define('MyApp.store.MyChainedStore', {&#xA;    extend: 'Ext.data.ChainedStore',&#xA;&#xA;    storeId: 'MyChainedStore',&#xA;    //source using storeID&#xA;    source: 'OriginalStore'&#xA;&#xA;});&#xA;&#xA;Ext.define('MyApp.store.OriginalStore', {&#xA;    extend: 'Ext.data.Store',&#xA;&#xA;    requires: [&#xA;        'Ext.data.field.Field'&#xA;    ],&#xA;&#xA;    storeId: 'OriginalStore',&#xA;    data: [{&#xA;        id: 1,&#xA;        name: 'commodi'&#xA;    }],&#xA;    fields: [{&#xA;        name: 'id'&#xA;    }, {&#xA;        name: 'name'&#xA;    }]&#xA;});&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Check out this fiddle example <a href="https://fiddle.sencha.com/#view/editor&amp;fiddle/1kk4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://fiddle.sencha.com/#view/editor&amp;fiddle/1kk4</a></p>&#xA;

 . ;   can a chained store be define using ext.define statement? . ; . ;. ; definitely yes. but the  source config  of the  chained store  says that it should be either a store instance or the id of an existing store. . ;. ; so the code would look like this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; check out this fiddle example    fiddle/1kk4  . ;

can a chained store be define using ext.define statement
definitely yes
but the source config of the chained store says that it should be either a store instance or the id of an existing store
so the code would look like this
check out this fiddle example fiddle 1kk4



<p><code>PaintCell</code> is declared <code>abstract</code> not <code>virtual</code> so you can't do the <code>base.PaintCell</code> call. It is up to your code to create the <code>Control</code> object and return it.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If you don't want to be creating the <code>Control</code> you may want to inherit from a more derived class than <code>BaseCellType</code> and overriding that derived classes <code>PaintCell</code> method.</p>&#xA;

  paintcell  is declared  abstract  not  virtual  so you can't do the  base.paintcell  call. it is up to your code to create the  control  object and return it. . ;. ; if you don't want to be creating the  control  you may want to inherit from a more derived class than  basecelltype  and overriding that derived classes  paintcell  method. . ;

paintcell is declared abstract not virtual so you can t do the base.paintcell call
it is up to your code to create the control object and return it
if you don t want to be creating the control you may want to inherit from a more derived class than basecelltype and overriding that derived classes paintcell method

<p>One way is to get rid of the diagonal 1s by subtracting a identity matrix of the same order. If you don't want to do any reassigning or subtracting (I don't see a reason why - probably to practice using many functions in Pandas), I would suggest something like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>def closest(x):&#xA;  return mat.loc[x['id']].nlargest(2).values.tolist()[1]&#xA;&#xA;def closest_label(x):&#xA;  return mat.loc[x['id']].nlargest(2).index[1]&#xA;&#xA;df['closest'] = df.apply(closest, axis=1)&#xA;df['closest_label'] = df.apply(closest_label, axis=1)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Output:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    id  closest closest_label&#xA;0  id1      0.3           id3&#xA;1  id2      0.7           id1&#xA;2  id3      0.4           id2&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

 one way is to get rid of the diagonal 1s by subtracting a identity matrix of the same order. if you don't want to do any reassigning or subtracting (i don't see a reason why - probably to practice using many functions in pandas), i would suggest something like this: . ;. ;  . ;. ; output: . ;. ;  . ;

one way is to get rid of the diagonal 1s by subtracting a identity matrix of the same order
if you don t want to do any reassigning or subtracting i don t see a reason why - probably to practice using many functions in pandas i would suggest something like this

<p>I am trying to develop a plug-in for the Protege desktop application and I would like to find any reusable piece of code in the default views  that Protege comes with.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The whole application can be downloaded using, a svn client, from <code>https://smi-protege.stanford.edu/repos/protege/protege4/ide/eclipse/protege4.1/trunk/</code>&#xA;For more information on how to set up Eclipse and run the application, please refer to <a href="http://protegewiki.stanford.edu/wiki/CompileProtege4InEclipseFromSvn" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this</a> </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now, when a tab is loaded into the program, it is loaded according to the <code>viewconfig-xxx.xml</code> file associated. In the case of the DLQuery tab, for example, the <code>viewconfig-dlquerytab.xml</code> looks like this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?&gt;&#xA;&lt;layout&gt;&#xA;    &lt;VSNode splits="0.3 0.7"&gt;&#xA;&#xA;        &lt;CNode&gt;&#xA;            &lt;Component label="Asserted hierarchy"&gt;&#xA;                &lt;Property id="pluginId" value="org.protege.editor.owl.OWLAssertedClassHierarchy"/&gt;&#xA;            &lt;/Component&gt;&#xA;        &lt;/CNode&gt;&#xA;&#xA;        &lt;CNode&gt;&#xA;            &lt;Component label="DL Query"&gt;&#xA;                &lt;Property id="pluginId" value="org.coode.dlquery.OWLClassExpressionEditorViewComponent"/&gt;&#xA;            &lt;/Component&gt;&#xA;        &lt;/CNode&gt;&#xA;&#xA;    &lt;/VSNode&gt;&#xA;&#xA;&lt;/layout&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Saying that the default configuration of the DLQuery tab shows the following views:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<ol>&#xA;<li><p>Asserted hierrarchy, which can be found (supposedly) in org.protege.editor.owl.OWLAssertedClassHierarchy</p></li>&#xA;<li><p>DL Query, which can be found (actually) in org.coode.dlquery.OWLClassExpressionEditorViewComponent</p></li>&#xA;</ol>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Now, this source files that point to the views are somewhat elusive and I cannot find most of them (the ones referring to <code>org.protege.owl.editor</code>, which contains just 4 classes as indicated in the picture). I would really like to take a look at them and look for reusable code, since I am kinda new to Swing and plugin development.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/LxRfO.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/LxRfO.png" alt="picture"></a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Please, any guidance will be greatly appreciated :'( </p>&#xA;

<p>I've been experimenting with Russian Doll fragment caching on a Rails app, more specifically on its main Dashboard page. This is the first page the user sees after he logs in and is a great candidate for Russian Doll, since it contains many nested elements.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Caching is working well in situations when the user himself makes changes which requires the app to re-render the Dashboard. Load time with caching is about 4x faster than rendering the full page.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>There are, however, situations when the data is changed by the system. For example, every night, we update all the values by the new exchange rate for the previous day. This will automatically expire most of the fragments in the Dashboard and the next morning the user will hit a cold cache when logging in.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>It is possible to regenerate these fragment caches after the system updates in order to keep them warm? I guess I could manually <code>write</code> the fragments after any system update, but I would have to manage the keys and dependencies manually as well. (I'm currently using the <code>cache_digest</code> gem, which is very convenient.).</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Any ideas?</p>&#xA;

 i've been experimenting with russian doll fragment caching on a rails app, more specifically on its main dashboard page. this is the first page the user sees after he logs in and is a great candidate for russian doll, since it contains many nested elements. . ;. ; caching is working well in situations when the user himself makes changes which requires the app to re-render the dashboard. load time with caching is about 4x faster than rendering the full page. . ;. ; there are, however, situations when the data is changed by the system. for example, every night, we update all the values by the new exchange rate for the previous day. this will automatically expire most of the fragments in the dashboard and the next morning the user will hit a cold cache when logging in. . ;. ; it is possible to regenerate these fragment caches after the system updates in order to keep them warm? i guess i could manually  write  the fragments after any system update, but i would have to manage the keys and dependencies manually as well. (i'm currently using the  cache_digest  gem, which is very convenient.). . ;. ; any ideas? . ;

this is the first page the user sees after he logs in and is a great candidate for russian doll since it contains many nested elements
caching is working well in situations when the user himself makes changes which requires the app to re-render the dashboard
load time with caching is about 4x faster than rendering the full page
there are however situations when the data is changed by the system
for example every night we update all the values by the new exchange rate for the previous day
this will automatically expire most of the fragments in the dashboard and the next morning the user will hit a cold cache when logging in
it is possible to regenerate these fragment caches after the system updates in order to keep them warm
i guess i could manually write the fragments after any system update but i would have to manage the keys and dependencies manually as well
i m currently using the cache_digest gem which is very convenient.

<p>The same result as mentioned in your question would be given by the following statement that has to be manually generated in contrast to the Python solution:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>public class Letters {&#xA;&#xA;    public static String asString() {&#xA;        StringBuffer buffer = new StringBuffer();&#xA;        for (char c = 'a'; c &lt;= 'z'; c++)&#xA;            buffer.append(c);&#xA;        for (char c = 'A'; c &lt;= 'Z'; c++)&#xA;            buffer.append(c);&#xA;        return buffer.toString();&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;    public static void main(String[] args) {&#xA;        System.out.println(Letters.asString());&#xA;    }&#xA;&#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;

<p>I think you're being caught in a classic mistake. item:saved will also fire for your items as they're being published. </p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>My initial guess would be, that you should expand your check to be</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>if ( item != null &amp;&amp; item.Database.Name == "master" )&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>to prevent your code from attempting to publish the item, as the item:saved event fires on "web" during publishing.</p>&#xA;

<p>I have always assumed that <code>std::lower_bound()</code> runs in logarithmic time if I pass a pair of red-black tree iterators (<code>set::iterator</code> or <code>map::iterator</code>) to it. I had to burn myself twice to notice that <code>std::lower_bound()</code> runs in O(n) time in this case, at least with the libstdc++ implementation. I understand that the standard doesn't have the concept of red-black tree iterators; <code>std::lower_bound()</code> will treat them as bidirectional iterators and <code>advance</code> them in linear time. <strong>I still don't see any reason why the implementation couldn't create an implementation specific iterator tag for red-black tree iterators</strong>  and call a specialized <code>lower_bound()</code> if the passed in iterators happen to be red-black tree iterators.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Is there any technical reason why <code>std::lower_bound()</code> is not specialized for red-black tree iterators?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>UPDATE:</strong> Yes, <strong>I am aware of the find member functions but it is so not the point.</strong> (In a templated code I may not have access to the container or work only on a part of container.)</p>&#xA;&#xA;<hr>&#xA;&#xA;<p><strong>After the bounty has expired:</strong> I find Mehrdad's and Yakk's answers the most convincing. I couldn't decide between the too; I am giving the bounty to Mehrdad and accepting Yakk's answer.</p>&#xA;

 i have always assumed that  std::lower_bound()  runs in logarithmic time if i pass a pair of red-black tree iterators ( set::iterator  or  map::iterator ) to it. i had to burn myself twice to notice that  std::lower_bound()  runs in o(n) time in this case, at least with the libstdc++ implementation. i understand that the standard doesn't have the concept of red-black tree iterators;  std::lower_bound()  will treat them as bidirectional iterators and  advance  them in linear time.  i still don't see any reason why the implementation couldn't create an implementation specific iterator tag for red-black tree iterators   and call a specialized  lower_bound()  if the passed in iterators happen to be red-black tree iterators. . ;. ; is there any technical reason why  std::lower_bound()  is not specialized for red-black tree iterators? . ;. ; . ;. ;  update:  yes,  i am aware of the find member functions but it is so not the point.  (in a templated code i may not have access to the container or work only on a part of container.) . ;. ; . ;. ;  after the bounty has expired:  i find mehrdad's and yakk's answers the most convincing. i couldn't decide between the too; i am giving the bounty to mehrdad and accepting yakk's answer. . ;

i have always assumed that std lower_bound runs in logarithmic time if i pass a pair of red-black tree iterators set iterator or map iterator to it
i had to burn myself twice to notice that std lower_bound runs in o n time in this case at least with the libstdc++ implementation
i understand that the standard doesn t have the concept of red-black tree iterators
std lower_bound will treat them as bidirectional iterators and advance them in linear time
i still don t see any reason why the implementation couldn t create an implementation specific iterator tag for red-black tree iterators and call a specialized lower_bound if the passed in iterators happen to be red-black tree iterators
is there any technical reason why std lower_bound is not specialized for red-black tree iterators
update yes i am aware of the find member functions but it is so not the point
in a templated code i may not have access to the container or work only on a part of container.
after the bounty has expired i find mehrdad s and yakk s answers the most convincing
i couldn t decide between the too
i am giving the bounty to mehrdad and accepting yakk s answer



<p>Do this:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>protected void BindServiceList(DropDownList ddlService)&#xA;{&#xA;    DropDownList ddl = (DropDownList)GV_MJJ.HeaderRow.FindControl("ddlProgram");&#xA;    string program = ddl.SelectedValue;&#xA;    String strConnString = System.Configuration.ConfigurationManager&#xA;                .ConnectionStrings["myConn"].ConnectionString;&#xA;    using (var con = new SqlConnection(strConnString) )&#xA;    using (var cmd = new SqlCommand("select distinct LOCATION from myTable where PROGRAM LIKE @Program", con) )&#xA;    {&#xA;         //guessing at column type/length here&#xA;         cmd.Parameters.Add("@Program", SqlDbType.NVarChar, 20).Value = program;&#xA;&#xA;        con.Open();&#xA;        ddlService.DataSource = cmd.ExecuteReader();&#xA;        ddlService.DataTextField = "LOCATION";&#xA;        ddlService.DataValueField = "LOCATION";&#xA;        ddlService.DataBind();&#xA;    }&#xA;    ddlService.Items.FindByValue(ViewState["Filter_Serv"].ToString())&#xA;            .Selected = true; &#xA;}&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Notice that I fixed your sql injection vulnerability! Also notice that I changed the <code>=</code> to a <code>LIKE</code>. Then you can set the <code>value</code> property for the <code>All</code> item  in the <code>ddlProgram</code> control to: <code>%</code>. (See the <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.web.ui.webcontrols.listcontrol.appenddatabounditems%28v=vs.110%29.aspx" rel="nofollow"><code>AppendDataBoundItems</code></a> property if you need help getting that working with a databound ddl). Using that wildcard with the <code>LIKE</code> operator will result in the query returning all locations. </p>&#xA;

<p>Azure Service Bus has a lot of rich messaging features to help with both the Pub/Sub aspect of your requirement as well as the request/response correlation. The concept of sessions (grouped/related) messages along with session state can be very helpful here. Following are some specific links that may help:&#xA;MSDN article on sessions: <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/jj863132.aspx" rel="nofollow">http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/jj863132.aspx</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Sample for using sessions: <a href="http://code.msdn.microsoft.com/windowsazure/Brokered-Messaging-Session-41c43fb4" rel="nofollow">http://code.msdn.microsoft.com/windowsazure/Brokered-Messaging-Session-41c43fb4</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Request/Response sample: <a href="http://code.msdn.microsoft.com/windowsazure/Brokered-Messaging-Request-0ce8fcaf" rel="nofollow">http://code.msdn.microsoft.com/windowsazure/Brokered-Messaging-Request-0ce8fcaf</a></p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Talk on correlation etc.: <a href="http://channel9.msdn.com/Blogs/Subscribe/Service-Bus-Messaging-Deep-Dive" rel="nofollow">http://channel9.msdn.com/Blogs/Subscribe/Service-Bus-Messaging-Deep-Dive</a></p>&#xA;

They would need to be manually passed from within a click handler that invokes the function.</p>&#xA;

<p>If your first table has all the key values, then you can do:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>select t1.a, nz(t1.b, t2.b), nz(t1.c, t2.c) as c&#xA;from table1 as t1 left join&#xA;     table2 as t2&#xA;     on t1.a = t2.a;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>If this isn't the case, you can use this rather arcane looking construct:</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>select t1.a, nz(t1.b, t2.b), nz(t1.c, t2.c) as c&#xA;from table1 as t1 left join&#xA;     table2 as t2&#xA;     on t1.a = t2.a&#xA;union all&#xA;select t2.a, t2.b, t2.c&#xA;from table2 as t2&#xA;where not exists (select 1 from table1 as t1 where t1.key = t2.key)&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>The first part of the union gets the rows where there is a key value in the first table.  The second gets the rows where the key value is in the second but not the first.</p>&#xA;&#xA;<p>Note this is much harder in Access than in other (dare I say "real") databases.  MS Access doesn't support common table expressions (CTEs), <code>union</code>s in subqueries, or <code>full outer join</code> -- all of which would help simplify the query.</p>&#xA;

 if your first table has all the key values, then you can do: . ;. ;  . ;. ; if this isn't the case, you can use this rather arcane looking construct: . ;. ;  . ;. ; the first part of the union gets the rows where there is a key value in the first table.  the second gets the rows where the key value is in the second but not the first. . ;. ; note this is much harder in access than in other (dare i say "real") databases.  ms access doesn't support common table expressions (ctes),  union s in subqueries, or  full outer join  -- all of which would help simplify the query. . ;

<p>This is what I suggest, tried to work my way around with pull and push but i haven't found a solution with that. You can use the hidden-xs, visible-xs to create two different text-area, one visible only on small screen and the other on large screens only. <p>Now in my page I have a parameter call personid,if visitor input the url like &#xA;:<code>http://helloworld.com?personid=123</code>,and I will return the person information whitch personid is 123.I can not known whether this person is real.So I decide  when the person visit the page  first time,I will use sendRedirect and then attatch the other parameter.But now this way is wrong.Can I use session or other way to only refresh the page one time?</p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    &lt;%&#xA; String personid = request.getParameter("personid ");&#xA;String vpersonid= request.getParameter("vpersonid");&#xA; if (vpersonid== null) {&#xA;  String url="http://myserver/distinguishusrtoken.do?redirect_uri=http://helloworld.com/index.jsp?personid=123&amp;personid ="+personid ;   &#xA;  response.sendRedirect(url);&#xA;} &#xA;%&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;&#xA;<p>When people visit the web <code>http://helloworld.com?personid=123</code>,the final url is <code>http://helloworld.com?personid=123&amp;ppersonid=123</code>;but if people see the keyword and input the url <code>http://helloworld.com?personid=123&amp;ppersonid=123</code>  directly,althought it is a fake url,but I can not do anything.How to redirect  to the self page only one time?I try to use session,but it is a endless loop? </p>&#xA;&#xA;<pre><code>    &lt;%&#xA;  String personid = request.getParameter("personid ");&#xA; String vpersonid = request.getParameter("vpersonid "); &#xA; if(response.getHeader("personid")==null||!personid.equals(response.getHeader("personid"))){&#xA;String url="http://myserver/distinguishusrtoken.do?redirect_uri=http://helloworld.com/index.jsp?personid=123&amp;personid ="+personid ; &#xA; vpersonid =personid ;&#xA; response.setHeader("personid ", personid );&#xA;response.sendRedirect(url);  &#xA;} &#xA;%&gt;&#xA;</code></pre>&#xA;
